definition: Ἄβαντες (θοοί, μεγάθυμοι, μένεα πνείοντες, ὄπιθεν κομόωντες ). The men of Euboea Il. 2.536, 541, 542, Il. 4.464.
Ἀβαρβαρέη A <corr change="sea-nymph:from errata">Naiad</corr>. Mother by Boucolion of Aesepus-2 and Pedasus-3 (twins) Il. 6.22.
Ἄβας Trojan. Son of Eurydamas-1. With his brother Polyidus-1 killed by Diomedes Il. 5.148.
Ἄβιοι (δικαιότατοι ἀνθρώπων). An unknown race so described Il. 13.6.
Ἄβληρος Trojan. killed by Antilochus Il. 6.32.
Ἄβυδος A city on the southeast of the Hellespont, a little below Sestus on the other side Il. 2.836. Ἀβυδόθεν [-θεν], from Abydus Il. 4.500 . Ἀβυδόθι [-θι], at Abydus Il. 16.584 .
Ἀγάθων (δῖος). A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.249.
Ἀγακλέης (μεγάθυμος.) Father of Epeigeus Il. 16.571.
Ἀγαμεμνόνεος Adj. from Ἀγαμέμνων Il. 10.326, Il. 23.295, 525 : Od. 3.264.
Ἀγαμεμνονίδης Patronymic from next. Of Orestes-3 Od. 1.30 .

Ἀγαμέμνων (ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν, βασιλεύς , δὶος, εὐρὺ κρείων , κλυτός, κοσμήτωρ λαῶν , κρείων, κύδιστος , πελώριος, ποιμὴν λαῶν ). Patronymic Ἀτρεΐδης, Ἀτρεΐων. King of Mycenae and great suzerain of the Greeks. Son of Atreus, brother of Menelaus, husband of Clytaemnestra, and father by her of Orestes-3, Chrysothemis, Laodice-2 and Iphianassa. Dismisses Chryses with menaces Il. 1.26; in the assembly summoned by Achilles abuses Calchas Il. 1.106, addresses Agamemnon and proposes to send back Chryseis 131, addresses him again and threatens to take Briseis from him 173, addresses Nestor 286 ; has a ship prepared to carry back Chryseis Il. 1.308, bids the people cleanse themselves 313, sends his heralds to bring away Briseis 320; Zeus sends Oneirus to beguile him Il. 2.8, he summons the council of chiefs and relates his dream 53, the sceptre bequeathed to him by Thyestes 107, addresses the assembly and counsels a return home 110, assents to the opposite counsel of Nestor 370, summons the host to the fight 441; enumeration of his followers Il. 2.569; described on the walls by Helen to Priam Il. 3.172; prays to Zeus and performs the oath-sacrifice Il. 3.276; sends for Machaon to see the wounded Menelaus Il. 4.193; goes round and inspects the host and the chiefs Il. 4.223 ; slays Adrestus-3 taken by Menelaus Il. 6.63; accepts Hector's challenge, but does not get the lot Il. 7.162; refuses the proposals of the Trojan herald except as to the burning of the dead Il. 7.406; reproaches the Greeks retreating before Hector Il. 8.217; calls an assembly Il. 9.9, addresses it and again counsels a return home 17, reproved by Diomedes 32 , in a gathering in his hut agrees, on the suggestion of Nestor, to placate Achilles 115, an embassy is dispatched accordingly 178, but returns unsuccessful 669; Agamemnon cannot sleep (1), goes to rouse Nestor and other chiefs 17; his ἀριστεία 15, is wounded by Coon 248, but continues to fight 255, retires 280; with the other wounded chiefs encounters Nestor Il. 14.27, advises the launching of the ships 65, reproved by Odysseus 83, accepts the reproof 104; his speech in the assembly on the renunciation by Achilles of his wrath Il. 19.78, his oath about Briseis 258; receives the prize for spear-throwing without a contest Il. 23.884; etc.: after the taking of Troy advised, opposing Menelaus, delay in returning home in order to placate Athene Od. 3.141 , remained accordingly 155; his death at the hands of Aegisthus Od. 1.32, 298, Od. 3.194, 234, 250, 303, Od. 4.519, Od. 11.384, 409, Od. 13.383, Od. 24.96 (see also Orestes-3); in the Shades Od. 11.387, Od. 24.19; etc.
Ἀγαμήδη (ξανθή). Eldest daughter of Augeias and wife of Moulius-1. Skilled in drugs Il. 11.740.
Ἀγαπήνωρ (κρείων). Son of Ancaeus-1 and leader of the Arcadians Il. 2.609.
Ἀγασθένης (ἄναξ). Patronymic Αὐγηϊάδης. Son of Augeias and father of Polyxeinus Il. 2.624 .
Ἀγάστροφος Trojan. (δουρικλυτὁς, ἴφθιμος ). Patronymic Παιονίδης. Wounded and slain by Diomedes Il. 11.338, 368, 373.
Ἀγαύη A Nereid Il. 18.42 .
Ἀγέλαος-1 Trojan. Patronymic Φραδμονίδης . Killed by Diomedes Il. 8.257.
Ἀγέλαος-2 Greek. Killed by Hector Il. 11.302.

Ἀγέλαος-3 Ἀγέλεως, Od. 22.131, 247 (διοτρεφής). Patronymic Δαμαστορίδης-2 A suitor. Counsels the suitors to abstain from violence Od. 13.321, 339; in the fight advises communication with the people outside Od. 22.131, 136; Od. 22.212 , 241, 247. Killed by Odysseus Od. 22.293, 327.

Ἀγήνωρ Trojan. (ἀμύμων τε κρατερός τε, ἀντίθεος, δῖος, μεγάθυμος). Patronymic Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor and father of Echeclus-1 slays Elephenor Il. 4.467 ; Il. 11.59, Il. 12.93, Il. 13.490, 598, Il. 14.425; slays Clonius Il. 15.340; Il. 16.535, Il. 20.474; stands up to Achilles Il. 21.545, 579, is snatched away by Apollo 595, 600.
Ἀγκαῖος-1. Father of Agapenor Il. 2.609.
Ἀγκαῖος-2 (Πλευρώνιος). Nestor beat him at wrestling Il. 23.635.
Ἀγλαΐη Mother of Nireus by Charopus Il. 2.672.
Ἄγριος Son of Portheus Il. 14.117.
Ἀγχίαλος-1 Greek. (εἰδὼς χάρμης). With his brother Menesthes killed by Hector Il. 5.609.
Ἀγχίαλος-2 (δαΐφρων). Father of Mentes-2 Od. 1.180, 418.
Ἀγχίαλος-3. A Phaeacian Od. 8.112 .

Ἀγχίσης (ἀμύμων, ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν , μεγαλήτωρ). Son of Capys and father of Aeneas by Aphrodite; father also of Hippodameia-2 Il. 2.819, 820, Il. 5.247, 268, 313, 468, Il. 12.98, Il. 13.428, Il. 17.491, Il. 20.112, 208, 239, 240.
Ἀγχισιάδης-1 Patronymic from prec. Of Aeneas Il. 17.754 , Il. 20.160.
Ἀγχισιάδης-2. Patronymic of Echepolus-2 Il. 23.296.
Ἀδάμας Trojan. Patronymic Ἀσιάδης. Apparently son of Asius-2 Il. 12.140; wounds Antilochus and is killed by Meriones Il. 13.560 , 759, 771.
Ἄδμητος Husband of Alcestis and father of Eumelus Il. 2.713, 714, Il. 23.289, 391, 532.
Ἀδρήστεια A plain at the mouth of the Grenicus Il. 2.828.
Ἀδρήστη A handmaid of Helen at Sparta Od. 4.123.
Ἀδρηστίνη Patronymic from next. Of Aegialeia Il. 5.412.
Ἄδρηστος-1 King of Sicyon, and father of Aegialeia Il. 2.572 ; father also of the wife of Tydeus (Deipyle) Il. 14.121; his horse Arion Il. 23.347.
Ἄδρηστος-2 Son of Merops and with his brother Amphius-1 the leader of the men of Adresteia, etc. Il. 2.830; both killed by Diomedes Il. 11.328.
Ἄδρηστος-3 Trojan. Taken by Menelaus Il. 7.37, 45. Killed by Agamemnon Il. 7.63.
Ἄδρηστος-4 Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.694.
Ἀζεΐδης Patronymic of Actor-1 Il. 2.513.
Ἀθῆναι also Ἀθήνη-1Od. 7.80 (ἐϋκτίμενον πτολίεθρον, εὐρυάγυια, ἱεραί, δῆμος Ἐρεχθῆος) Athens Il. 2.546, 549: Od. 3.278, 307, Od. 7.80, Od. 11.323.

Ἀθηναίη-2, Ἀθήνη Also Παλλὰς Ἀθηναίη Il. 1.200 , Il. 10.275, Il. 11.438 , Il. 15.614: Od. 3.42, Od. 4.828, Od. 13.190, 252, 300, 371, Od. 16.298, Od. 24.547. And Π. Ἀθήνη Il. 1.400, Il. 4.78, Il. 5.510, Il. 18.217, Il. 21.290, etc. : Od. 1.125, Od. 3.222, Od. 8.7, Od. 15.1, Od. 24.520, etc. (Never Π. alone.) (ἀγελείη, (αἰγιόχοιο) Διὸς τέκος, Ἀλαλκομενηΐς, Ἀτρυτώνη, (θεὰ) γλαυκῶπις , δῖα θεάων, Διὸς ἐκγεγαρυῖα , ἐρυσίπτολις, ἠΰκμομος , θυγάτηρ Διός, κούρη Διὸς (αιγιόχοιο), κυδίστη, λαοσσόος, ληῗτις, μεγάθυμος, πολύβουλος, πότνια, Τριτογένεια.) Daughter of Zeus (her mother not named). Sent by Hera checks the wrath of Achilles in the assembly Il. 1.194; sent by her to stop the flight of the Greeks Il. 2.156; sent by Zeus to induce the Trojans to break the truce Il. 4.78; inspires spirit into Diomedes Il. 5.1, 121, leads Ares from the fight Il. 5.35, arms herself 733, mounts the chariot of Diomedes 835, they put Ares to flight 855; the prayer to her of the aged Trojan women Il. 6.297; again arms herself Od. 8.384, Hera and she start for the field to aid the Greeks 392, they are stopped by Iris sent by Zeus 413; she checks Ares in his wrath at the death of Ascalaphus Il. 15.121 ; kindles fire from the head of Achilles Il. 18.203; introduces nectar and ambrosia into his body Il. 19.349; in the Battle of the Gods Ares attacks her Il. 21.391, she fells him with a stone 403, she knocks down Aphrodite 423; comes to the aid of Achilles against Hector Il. 22.214, in the likeness of Deiphobus beguiles Η. 226; in the chariotrace disables Eumelus Il. 23.391; etc. : in the likeness of Mentes-2 appears to Telemachus Od. 1.102 , urges him to go to Pylus and Sparta 284, accompanies him in the likeness of Mentor-2 Od. 2.399, her advice to him at Pylus Od. 3.14, her prayer to Poseidon 55, she returns to the ship 357; meets Odysseus and conducts him to the city of the Phaeacians Od. 7.18 ; marks Odysseus's throw of the δίσκος Od. 8.193; in the likeness of a youth appears to Odysseus on his landing in Ithaca Od. 13.221, reveals herself 296, they consult 372, she transforms him into a beggar 429; she departs for Sparta Od. 13.439, where she urges Telemachus to go home and warns him of the ambush of the suitors Od. 15.10; she appears to Odysseus and retransforms him Od. 16.155; she transforms him back to a beggar Od. 16.454; she suggests to Penelope to appear before the suitors Od. 18.158; she bears the light while the arms are being removed Od. 19.33 ; she appears to Odysseus while he lies in the πρόδομος Od. 13.30; she appears in the crisis of the fight with the suitors Od. 22.205; is advised by Zeus to make peace between the Ithacans and Odysseus and his followers Od. 24.472, stops the fight 531; etc.
Ἀθηναῖος Greek. (μήστωρες ἀϋτῆς). Ἀθηναῖοι, the Athenians Il. 2.551, 558, Il. 4.328, Il. 13.196, 689, Il. 15.337.
Ἄθως The mountain terminating the peninsula Acte running out from Chalcidice Il. 14.229.
Αἰαίη An epithet or name of uncertain meaning (cf. Αἰήτης). Of Circe Od. 9.32, Od. 12.268, 273. Of her island Od. 10.135, Od. 11.70, Od. 12.3.
Αἰακίδης Patronymic from next. Of Peleus Il. 16.15 , Il. 18.433, Il. 21.189 . Of Achilles (grandson) Il. 2.860, Il. 9.184, Il. 10.402, Il. 11.805, Il. 16.134, Il. 17.76, etc. : Od. 11.471, 538.
Αἰακός Son of Zeus and father of Peleus Il. 21.189.

Αἴας-1 Voc. Αἶαν (ἄλκιμος, ἀντίθεος , Ἀρήϊος, βοὴν ἀγαθός , δαΐφρων, διογενής , ἕρκος Ἀχαιῶν, κοίρανος λαῶν, κυδάλιμος, μεγάθυμος, μέγαλήτωρ, μέγας, πελώριος, ταχύς, Τελαμώνιος (υἱός), φαίδιμος). Patronymic Τελαμωνιάδης. (1) Son of Telamon and leader of the men of Salamis Il. 2.557; after Achilles the most soldierly of the Greeks Il. 2.768; described by Helen to Priam Il. 3.225; he and Aias-2 visited by Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.273; chosen by lot to fight Hector Il. 7.181, the fight 206, they exchange gifts 303; his brother the archer Teucrus shoots from behind his shield Il. 8.267, he rescues him when wounded 330; is one of the embassy to Achilles Il. 9.169, makes the final appeal 622; with Menelaus comes to the rescue of Odysseus Il. 11.465 , retires panic-stricken 544; goes with Teucrus to the help of Menestheus Il. 12.364 ; disables Hector Il. 14.409; makes a stand on the platforms of the ships Il. 15.674 , retires to a gangway 727, abandons the ship Il. 16.102; with Menelaus comes to the rescue of the corpse of Patroclus Il. 17.123, his cry for light 645, the corpse is at last rescued Il. 18.231; his drawn wrestling-match with Odysseus Il. 23.708, meets Diomedes in the fight in armour 811, is second in putting the weight 838; etc. : Od. 3.109; in the Shades Od. 11.469, avoids Odysseus 543 , 550; in the second νέκυιαOd. 24.17. In dual Αἴαντε and pl. Αἴαντες (with dat. Αἰάντεσσιν) the two ὁμώνυμοι (P 720) spoken of or acting together (θεράποντες Ἄρηος, θοῦριν ὲπιειμένοι ἀλκήν, μεμαότε θούριδος ἀλκῆς, κορυστά, πολέμου ἀκορήτω ) Il. 2.406, Il. 4.273, Il. 7.164, Il. 12.265, Il. 13.126, Il. 16.555, Il. 18.157, etc.

Αἴας-2 Voc. Αἶαν. (δουρικλυτός, ταχύς , φαίδιμος). Patronymic Ὀϊλιάδης. Son of Oeleus-1 and leader of the Locrians. Described Il. 2.527; recognizes a god in the guise of Calchas Il. 13.66; stands firm with his namesake Il. 13.701; does much execution Il. 14.520; slays Cleoboulus Il. 16.330; watching the chariot-race abuses Idomeneus Il. 23.473, comes in second in the foot-race 754; etc.: his death at the Gyraean Rock Od. 4.499, 509. See also prec. 2.
Αἰγαί A seat of the worship of Poseidon of disputed site Od. 8.203, Il. 13.21: Od. 5.381.
Αἰγαίων A hundred-handed being called by the gods Βριάρεως. Saved Zeus from bonds Il. 1.403, 404.
Αἰγεΐδης Patronymic from Αἰγεύς, king of Athens. Of Theseus Il. 1.265 .
Αἰγιάλεια (περίφρων). Patronymic Ἀδρηστίνη. Daughter of Adrestus-1 and wife of Diomedes Il. 5.412.
Αἰγιαλός-1 A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.575.
Αἰγιαλός-2 A Paphlagonian town Il. 2.855.
Αἰγίλιψ (τρηχεῖα). Apparently a town of Ithaca Il. 2.633.
Αἴγινα The Aegean island. In the realm of Diomedes Il. 2.562.
Αἴγιον Atown in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.574.

Αἴγισθος (ἀμύμων, ἄναλκις, δολόμητις). Patronymic Θυεστιάδης. Son of Thyestes and cousin of Agamemnon and Menelaus. Seduced Clytaemnestra and with her aid killed Agamemnon . (Clytaemnestra killing Cassandra (Od. 11.422)) on Agamemnon's return, all his and Agamemnon's followers also being killed Od. 1.35, 42, 300, Od. 3.194, 198, 235, 250, 256, 263, 303, Od. 4.518, 525, 529, 537, Od. 11.389, 409, Od. 24.22, 97; slain with Clytaemnestra by Orestes-3 Od. 1.29, 300, Od. 3.195, 198, 306, 310.

data.ref: Od. 11.422)) on Agamemnon's return, all his and Agamemnon's followers also being killed

definition: Αἰγύπτιος-1 Father of Antiphus-4 and Eurynomus Od. 2.15.
Αἰγύπτιος-2 (1) Adj. from Αἴγυπτος 1. Of Proteus Od. 4.385 . Adj. from Αἴγυπτος 2, Egyptian Od. 4.229. Of Thebes-2 Od. 4.127. In pl., the Egyptians Od. 4.83. So Αἰγύπτιοι ἄνδρες 263, 286, Od. 17.432.

Αἴγυπτος (1) (διιπετὴς ποταμός, ἐϋρρείτης). In masc., the river Nile Od. 3.300, Od. 4.477, 581, Od. 14.257, 258, Od. 17.427. Αἴγυπτόνδε [-δε], to the Nile, Od. 4.483, Od. 14.246, Od. 17.426. In fem., the land of Egypt Od. 4.351, 355, Od. 14.275, Od. 17.448.

Ἀΐδης -αο, -εω. Also genit. Ἄϊδος (α᷌) and dat. Ἄϊδι (α᷌) (ἀδάμαστος, ἀμείλιχος , ἐνέροισιν ἀνάσσων, ἴφθιμος , κλυτότωλος, κρατερός , πελώριος, πυλάρτης , στυγερός). Hades, son of Cronus and Rhea, brother of Zeus , Poseidon, Hera and Demeter, and husband of Persephoneia. By lot (Il. 15.187, 191) got the underworld as his realm. Wounded by Heracles with an arrow Il. 5.395; πύλαι Ἀΐδαο Il. 5.646, Il. 9.312, Il. 23.71: Od. 14.156; Ἄϊδος κυνέη Il. 5.845; his dog carried off by Heracles Il. 8.367, 368; etc.: Od. 10.534, Od. 11.47, etc. In local sense Il. 23.244. His δόμος or δόμοι , δῶ, δῶμα, see δόμος 2, δῶ 2, δῶμα 2 in Lex. See also εἰς (II) 2, εἴσω 3, ἐκ (II) 1 in Lex. Ἄϊδόσδε [-δε], to Hades. Il. 7.330, Il. 16.856, Il. 20.294, Il. 22.362, Il. 23.137: Od. 3.410, Od. 6.11, Od. 10.560, Od. 11.65, 475.

data.ref: 191) got the underworld as his realm.

definition: Ἀϊδωνεύς =prec. Il. 5.190, Il. 20.61 .
Αἰήτης (ὀλοόφρων). King of Colchis, son of Eelius and Perse and brother of Circe Od. 10.137; the voyage of the Argo from his land Od. 12.70.
Αἴθη (καλλίθριξ). A mare of Agamemnon's. Driven by Menelaus in the chariot-race Il. 23.295, 409, 525.
Αἴθικες A people of Thessaly. The Centaurs driven to their land by Peirithous Il. 2.744 .

Αἰθίοπες Αἰθιοπῆες A 423 (ἀμύμονες, ἔσχατοι ἀνδρῶν ). A people represented as dwelling by Oceanus on the extreme limits of the world. Zeus and the gods go thither for a sacrifice Il. 1.423; so Iris Il. 23.206: and Poseidon Od. 1.22 , Od. 5.287. Divided into two peoples Od. 1.22. Visited by Menelaus Od. 4.84. Returning from them Poseidon desries Odysseus Od. 5.282.
Αἴθρη Daughter of Pittheus. A handmaid of Helen at Troy Il. 3.144.
Αἴθων-1 One of Hector's horses Od. 8.185.
Αἴθων-2 The name assumed by Odysseus in his tale to Penelope Od. 19.183 .
Αἱμονίδης-1 Patronymic of Maeon Il. 4.394.
Αἱμονίδης-2 Patronymic of Laerces-1 Il. 16.467.
Αἵμων Greek. (κρείων) Il. 4.296.

Αἰνείας Αἰνέας N 541 (ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν, ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, βονηφόος, δαΐφρων, ἐΰς, μεγάθυμος, μεγαλήτωρ, πόδας ταχύς, Τρώων ἀγός, βουληφόρος.) Patronymic Ἀγχισιάδης. Son of Anchises and Aphrodite. Leader of the Dardanians Il. 2.820; with Pandarus attacks Diomedes Il. 5.166, is wounded by Δ. 305, but rescued by Aphrodite 311, his horses driven off by Capaneus 319, Il. 8.108 , Il. 23.292, D attacks him again Il. 5.432, but retires before Apollo 443; Aeneas's resentment against Priam Il. 13.459; he meets Achilles in fight Il. 20.160, tells his parentage 199, is rescued by Poseidon 320; etc.
Αἴνιος Trojan. A Paeonian. Killed by Achilles Il. 21.210.
Αἶνος The mod. Enos, a Thracian town at the mouth of the Hebrus. Αἰνόθεν [-θεν], from Aenus Il. 4.520.
Αἰολίδης Patronymic from Αἴολος (no doubt different from the Aeolus below; but the Aeolus legends can hardly be disentangled). Of Sisyphus Il. 6.154 . Of Cretheus Od. 11.237.
Αἰολίη Adj. from next Od. 10.1, 55 .

Αἴολος (μεγαλήτωρ, φίλος ἀθανάτοισι θεοῖσιν). Patronymic Ἱπποτάδης. Dwelt with his sons and daughters on a floating island Od. 10.2 ; made by Zeus controller of the winds Od. 10.21; Od. 10.36, 44, 60, Od. 23.314.
Αἴπεια (καλή). A town of Pylus Il. 9.152 , 294.
Αἰπύ (ἐΰκτιτον). A town of Pylus Il. 2.592 .
Αἰπύτιος Adj. from Αἴπυτος, son of Elatus, an Arcadian Il. 2.604 (Αἰπύτιον παρὰ τύμβον).
Ἄϊρος See Ἶρος.
Ἄϊς See Ἀΐδης.
Αἴσηπος-1 A river of the Troad flowing into the Propontis Il. 2.825 , Il. 4.91 Il. 12.21.
Αἴσηπος-2 Trojan. Son of Boucolion and Abarbaree. With his twin brother Pedasus-3 killed by Euryalus-1 Il. 6.21 .
Αἰσυήτης-1 (γέρων). His tomb Il. 2.793.
Αἰσυήτης-2 (διοτρεφής) Father of Alcathous Il. 13.427.
Αἰσύμη A Paeonian town, or perhaps rather an unknown town of the Troad. The home of Castianeira. ὲξ Αἰσύμηθεν [-θεν], from Aesyme Il. 8.304 .
Αἴσυμνος Greek. Killed by Hector Il. 11.303.
Αἴσων Son of Cretheus and Tyro Od. 11.259.
Αἰτώλιος =next. Of Tydeus Il. 4.399 . Of Trechus Il. 5.706 .

Αἰτωλός Of Aetolia, a district of Greece having the Achelous on the west, and bounded by the Gulf of Corinth on the south. Of Thoas-1 Il. 4.527 . Of Diomedes Il. 23.471. Of one who beguiled Eumaeus Od. 14.379. In pl., the men of Aetolia G (μεγάθυμοι, μενεχάρμαι) Il. 2.638, 643, Il. 5.843; their strife with the Couretes (see Κουρῆτες) Il. 9.529, 531, 549, 575, 597; Il. 13.218, Il. 15.282, Il. 23.633.

Ἀκάμας-1 Trojan. (ἐπιείκελος ἀθανάτοισιν, ἠΐθεος). Patronymic Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor. A leader of the Dardanians Il. 2.823, Il. 11.60, Il. 12.100, Il. 14.476, 478, 488. Killed by Meriones Il. 16.342.
Ἀκάμας-2 Trojan. (ἠΰς τε μἑγας τε, θοός ). Son of Eussorus. A leader of the Thracians Il. 2.844, Il. 5.462. Killed by Aias-1 Il. 6.8 .
Ἄκαστος King of Doulichium Od. 14.336.
Ἀκεσσαμενός Father of Periboea-1 Il. 21.142.
Ἀκρισιώνη Patronymic of Danae, daughter of Acrisius Il. 14.319.
Ἀκρόνεως A Phaeacian Od. 8.111 .
Ἀκταίη A Nereid Il. 18.41 .
Ἀκτορίδης Patronymic of Echeclees Il. 16.189.
Ἀκτορίς A servant given by her father to Penelope on her marriage Od. 23.228.

Ἀκτορίων In form a patronymic ; but the occurrence against analogy of two such words together in Il. 11.750 (Ἀκτορίωνε Μολίονε) makes it doubtful whether it is a patronymic. The words have not been satisfactorily explained. Of Cteatus and Eurytus-2 Il. 11.750 , Il. 23.638. Of Cteatus Il. 13.185 . Of Amphimachus-1 and Thalpius (sons of Cteatus and Eurytus-2) Il. 2.621.
Ἄκτωρ-1 Patronymic Ἀζεΐδης. Apparently father of Astyoche Il. 2.513.
Ἄκτωρ-2 Father of Menoetius Il. 11.785, Il. 16.14.
Ἀλαλκομενηΐς See Lexicon.
Ἀλαστορίδης Patronymic of Tros-2 Il. 20.463.
Ἀλάστωρ-1 Greek. (δῖος) Il. 4.295; assists Mecisteus-2 in carrying off the wounded Teucrus Il. 8.333, and Hypsenor-2 Il. 13.422.
Ἀλάστωρ-2 Trojan. killed by Odysseus Il. 5.677.
Ἀλεγηνορίδης Patronymic of Promachus Il. 14.503.
Ἀλεκτρυών (μεγάθυμος). Father of Leitus Il. 16.602.
Ἀλέκτωρ A Spartan. Megapenthes married his daughter Od. 4.10.
Ἀλέξανδρος See Πάρις.
Ἀλήϊον πεδίον.. A plain not localized. Ἀλήϊον is apparently formed to agree in sound with ἀλᾶτο in the same line Il. 6.201. 'The plain of wandering.'
Ἀλήσιον A hill on the confines of Bouprasion Il. 2.617, Il. 11.757.
Ἀλθαίη Wife of Oeneus and mother of Tydeus and Meleagrus Il. 9.555. A brother of Althaea slain by Meleager and her curses thereupon Il. 9.565.
Ἁλίαρτος (ποιήεις) A Boeotian town Il. 2.503.
Ἁλίζωνες Trojan. Perhaps a people of the killed by shore of the Euxine beyond the Paphlagonians Il. 2.856 , Il. 5.39.
Ἁλίη (βοῶπις). A Nereid Il. 18.40 .
Ἁλιθέρσης Patronymic Μαστορίδης-1 An Ithacan elder. His speech in the assembly Od. 2.157; Od. 2.253, Od. 17.68; advises against attacking Odysseus Od. 24.451.
Ἅλιος-1 Trojan. killed by Odysseus Il. 5.678.
Ἅλιος-2 Son of Alcinous Od. 8.119, 370.
Ἀλκάθοος Son of Aesyetes-2, husband of Hippodameia-2 and son-in-law of Anchises Il. 12.93. Killed by Idomeneus Il. 13.428, 465, 496.
Ἀλκάνδρη Wife of Polybus-3 Od. 4.126.
Ἄλκανδρος Trojan. killed by Odysseus Il. 5.678.
Ἄλκηστις (δῖα γυναικῶν, Πελίαο θυγατρῶν εἶδος ἀρίστη). Daughter of Pelies, wife of Admetus and mother of Eumelus Il. 2.715.
Ἀλκιμέδων (ἀμύμων). Son of Laerces-1 A leader under Achilles Il. 16.197 ; comes to the aid of Automedon Il. 17.467, 475, 481, 500, 501.
Ἀλκιμίδης Patronymic of Mentor-2 Od. 22.235.
Ἄλκιμος (ὄζος Ἄρηος). θεράπων of Achilles Il. 19.392 , Il. 24.474, 574.

Ἀλκίνοος (ἀμύμων, βασιλεύς , δαΐθρων, θεοειδής , θεοείκελος, θεῶν ἄπο μήδεα εἰδώς, ίερὸν μένος, κρείων, μεγαλήτωρ, πάντων ἀριδείκετος λαῶν). King of the Phaeacians. Son of Nausithous, husband of Arete (the daughter of his brother Rhexenor) and father of Laodamas-2 Halius-2, Clytoneus and Nausicaa. His parentage Od. 7.56; his house described Od. 7.84, and his orchard and garden 112; Odysseus approaches him and Arete Od. 7.141, he raises Odysseus from the hearth 167, promises him conduct to his home 317, Od. 8.26; entertains him with games Od. 8.97, and with the singing of Demodocus 254 ; proposes the giving of gifts to him Od. 8.389; asks for his tale Od. 8.572; puts the gifts on board the ship Od. 13.20, dispatches Il. 15.64 ; for fear of Poseidon proposes to give up conducting strangers Od. 13.171; etc.

data.ref: Od. 7.84, and his orchard and garden
Od. 8.97, and with the singing of

definition: Ἀλκίππη A handmaid of Helen at Sparta Od. 4.124.
Ἀλκμάων-1 Greek. Patronymic Θεστορίδης-2. Killed by Sarpedon Il. 12.394.
Ἀλκμάων-2 Son of Amphiaraus Od. 15.248.

Ἀλκμήνη Wife of Amphitryon and mother of Heracles by Zeus Il. 14.323; H 's birth delayed by contrivance of Hera, whereby Heracles became subject to Eurystheus Il. 19.99 , 119: Amphitryon brought into comparison with Penelope Od. 2.120; in the Shades Od. 11.266.
Ἀλκυόνη A name for Cleopatra. The reason given Il. 9.562.
Ἀλόπη A town of Argus-2 on the north shore of the entrance to the Malian Gulf Il. 2.682.
Ἄλος A town of Argus-2 on the west shore of the Pagasaean Gulf Il. 2.682.
Ἄλτης (ὀνομάκλυτος). King of the Leleges and father of Laothoe Il. 21.85, 86, Il. 22.51.
Ἀλύβας Of uncertain site. Odysseus in his tale to Laertes claims to have come thence Od. 24.304.
Ἀλύβη A town of the Halizonians Il. 2.857.

Ἀλφειός (ἱερός). A river of west Peloponnesus flowing through the (apparently northern) extremity of Nestor's realm Il. 2.592 ; father of Orsilochus-3 Il. 5.545: Od. 3.489, Od. 15.187; Il. 11.712, 726, 728.
Ἀλωεύς Husband of Iphimedeia and nominal father of Otus-1 and Ephialtes Il. 5.386: Od. 11.305.
Ἀμαζόνες (ἀντιάνειραι). A race of warlike women. Invaded Phrygia Il. 3.189; Bellerophon's fight with them Il. 6.186.
Ἀμάθεια (ὲϋπλόκαμος). A Nereid Il. 18.48 .
Ἄμαξα See Lexicon.
Ἀμαρυγκεΐδης Patronymic from next. Of Diores-1 Il. 2.622 , Il. 4.517.
Ἀμαρυγκεύς (κρείων). Father of Diores-1. His funeral games Il. 23.630.
Ἀμισώδαρος Father of Atymnius and Maris. Reared the Chimaera Il. 16.328.
Ἀμνισός The port of Cnosus Od. 19.188.
Ἀμοπάων Trojan. Patronymic Πολυαιμονίδης . Killed by Teucrus Il. 8.276.
Ἀμυδών The city of the Paeonians Il. 2.849, Il. 16.288.
Ἀμυθάων (ἱππιοχάρμης). Son of Cretheus and Tyro Od. 11.259. Was father of Melampus.
Ἀμύκλαι A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.584.
Ἀμύντωρ Patronymic Ὀρμενίδης. Ruler of Hellas (but in Il. 10.266 he is spoken of as living in Eleon) and father of Phoenix-1 Il. 9.448 , Il. 10.266.

data.ref: Il. 10.266 he is spoken of as living in

definition: Ἀμφίαλος Son of Polyneus. A Phaeacian Od. 8.114 , 128.
Ἀμφιάραος (λαοσσόος). The seer, son of Oicles, husband of Eriphyle and father of Alcmaon-2 and Amphilochus. Perished by the treachery of his wife Od. 15.244, 253.
Ἀμφιγένεια A town of Pylus Il. 2.593 .
Ἀμφιδάμας-1 A Cytherian Il. 10.268, 269 .
Ἀμφιδάμας-2 His son killed in a quarrel by Patroclus Il. 23.87.
Ἀμφιθέη Wife of Autolycus and mother of Anticleia Od. 19.416 .
Ἀμφιθόη A Nereid Il. 18.42 .
Ἄμφικλος Trojan. killed by Meges Il. 16.313.
Ἀμφίλοχος Son of Amphiaraus Od. 15.248.

Ἀμφίμαχος-1 (μεγαλήτωρ) See Ἀκτορίων. Son of Cteatus and grandson of Poseidon, and a leader of the Epeians Il. 2.620. Killed by Hector Il. 13.185, 189, 195, 203; Poseidon's wrath at his slaying Il. 13.206.
Ἀμφίμαχος-2 (ἀγλαός). Son of Nomion and a leader of the Carians Il. 2.870, 871. Killed by Achilles Il. 2.874.
Ἀμφιμέδων (ἀγακλυτός) A suitor, son of Melaneus Od. 24.103; Od. 22.242; wounds Telemachus Od. 22.277, who slays him 284; in the Shades Od. 24.103, 106 , 120.
Ἀμφινόμη A Nereid Il. 18.44 .

Ἀμφίνομος (Δουλιχιεύς, φαίδιμος ). Son of Nisus, and the leader of the suitors from Doulichium. First sees the ship returning from the ambush laid for Telemachus Od. 16.351 ; pleasing to Penelope Od. 16.394; wishes Odysseus well after the fight with Irus Od. 18.119, his presentiment of evil 153, Ο. takes refuge with him when threatened by Eurymachus 395. Killed by Telemachus Od. 22.89, 96; etc.
Ἄμφιος-1 (λινοθώρηξ). See Ἄδρηστος-2.
Ἄμφιος-2 Trojan. Son of Selagus. Killed by Aias-1 Il. 5.612.
Ἀμφιτρίτη (ἀγάστονος, κλυτός , κυανῶπις). A divine marine being Od. 3.91, Od. 5.422, Od. 12.60, 97 .
Ἀμφιτρύων Husband of Alcmene and putative father of Heracles Il. 5.392: Od. 11.266, 270.
Ἀμφίων-1 A leader of the Epeians Il. 13.692.
Ἀμφίων-2 Son of Zeus and Antiope. With his brother Zethus represented as having founded Thebes-1 Od. 11.262.
Ἀμφίων-3 Patronymic Ἰασίδης-1 King of Orchomenus-1 and father of Chloris Od. 11.283.
Ἀμφοτερός Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.415.
Ἀναβησίνεως A Phaeacian Od. 8.113 .
Ἀνδραιμονίδης Patronymic from next. Of Thoas-1 Il. 7.168 .
Ἀνδραίμων Father of Thoas-1 Il. 2.638, Il. 13.216, Il. 15.281: Od. 14.499.

Ἀνδρομάχη (λευκώλενος, πολύδωρος ). Daughter of Eetion-1, wife of Hector and mother of Astyanax. Absent when Hector visited his house Il. 6.371, 377 , her meeting and conversation with him 395, 405; her care of his horses Il. 8.187; Il. 17.208; sees his corpse being dragged to the ships Il. 22.460, her lament for him and Astyanax 477; her lament over his ransomed corpse Il. 24.723.
Ἀνεμώρεια A town of Phocis Il. 2.521.
Ἄνθεια (βαθύλειμος). A town of Pylus Il. 9.151 , 293.
Ἀνθεμίδης Patronymic from next. Of Simoeisius Il. 4.488.
Ἀνθεμίων Father of Simoeisius Il. 4.473.
Ἀνθηδών (ἐσχατόωσα). A Boeotian town Il. 2.508.
Ἄντεια (δῖα). Daughter (apparently) of a king of Lycia and wife of Proetus (see under Βελλεροφόντης) Il. 6.160.

Ἀντηνορίδης Patronymic from next. Of Helicaon Il. 3.122 , 123. Of Laodocus-1 Il. 4.87. Of Polybus-1 Il. 11.59. Of Agenor Il. 11.59 . Of Acamas-1 Il. 11.59 . Of Iphidamas Il. 11.221. Of Coon Il. 11.249 , Il. 19.53.

Ἀντήνωρ (ἀγαυός, ἱππόδαμος , πεπνυμένος). A Trojan elder. Husband of Theano and father of Acamas-1 Agenor , Archelochus, Coon, Demoleon , Helicaon, Iphidamas, Laodocus-1, Laodamas-1, Pedaeus (bastard), and Polybus-1 Il. 2.822 , Il. 3.148; had entertained Odysseus and Menelaus Il. 3.203; Il. 3.262, 312, Il. 6.299; counsels the restoration of Helen Il. 7.347; Il. 7.357, Il. 11.262, Il. 12.99, Il. 14.463, 473, Il. 15.517, Il. 20.396, Il. 21.546, 579.
Ἀντίκλεια Daughter of Autolycus, wife of Laertes and mother of Odysseus and Ctimene. Her death Od. 15.356; Odysseus sees her in the Shades Od. 11.85.
Ἄντικλος Greek. In the Trojan horse Od. 4.286.

Ἀντίλοχος (ἀγλαός, ἀμύμων, δαΐφρων, διοτρεφής, θείειν ταχύς, θοὸς πολεμιστής , κρατερός, κυδάλιμος , μαχητής, μενεχάρμης , μήστωρ ἀϋτῆς, Νηλήϊος , πεπνυμένος). Patronymic Νεστορίδης. Son of Nestor. slays Echepolus-1 Il. 4.457; comes to the rescue of Menelaus Il. 5.565; slays Mydon-1 Il. 5.580 ; slays Ablerus Il. 6.32 ; slays the chariot-driver of Asius-2 Il. 13.396; slays Thoon-3 Il. 13.545; slays Phalces and Mermerus Il. 14.513 ; slays Melanippus-2 Il. 15.575; slays Atymnius Il. 16.318; hears from Menelaus of the death of Patroclus Il. 17.685 , announces the death to Achilles Il. 18.18; takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.301, Nestor's advice to him 306, addresses his horses 402, gains the advantage of Menelaus and comes in second 417, objects to Achilles' proposal to give Eumelus the second prize 541, Menelaus accuses him of foul driving 566, Achilles pacifies him 586, takes part in the foot-race 756, comes in last 785; etc.: Nestor speaks of his death at Troy Od. 3.112; was slain by Memnon Od. 4.187, 202; in the Shades Od. 11.468, Od. 24.16; Od. 24.78.
Ἀντίμαχος (δαΐφρων). Father of Hippolochus-2, Peisandrus-1 and Hippomachus. Corrupted by Paris opposed the restoration of Helen Il. 11.123, 132, 138; Il. 12.188.

Ἀντίνοος (βασιλεύς, θεοειδής , ἱερὸν μένος Ἀντινόοιο, πεπνυμένος). Son of Eupeithes. With Eurymachus leader of the suitors. Taunts Telemachus among the suitors Od. 1.383; answers Telemachus in the Ithacan assembly Od. 2.84; proposes to waylay Telemachus Od. 4.660, gets a ship ready for this 778, reports ill success Od. 16.363; the disguised Odysseus begs from him Od. 17.414, he strikes him with a stool 458; his gift to Penelope Od. 18.292; refrains from trial of the bow Od. 21.186 (he does not seem to make the trial at all). Killed by Odysseus Od. 22.8, Od. 24.179; etc.

data.ref: Od. 4.660, gets a ship ready for this
Od. 21.186 (he does not seem to make the trial at all).

definition: Ἀντιόπη Daughter of the Asopus and mother by Zeus of Amphion-2 and Zethus Od. 11.260.
Ἀντιφάτης-1 Trojan. killed by Leonteus Il. 12.191.
Ἀντιφάτης-2 (κλυτός), also called Λάμος (Od. 10.81). The king of the Laestrygonians Od. 10.81, 106, 114, 199.
Ἀντιφάτης-3 (κραταιός). Son of Melampus and father of Oicles Od. 15.242, 243.
Ἀντίφονος A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.250.
Ἄντιφος-1 Son of Thessalus and with his brother Pheidippus a leader of the men of Nisurus, Cos, etc., Il. 2.678.
Ἄντιφος-2. Son of Talaemenes and a leader of the Maeonians (Μῄονες) Il. 2.864.

Ἄντιφος-3 (αἰολοθώρηξ). Patronymic Πριαμίδης. A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 4.489; had been taken with his brother Isus on Ida and released on ransom, now both slain by Agamemnon Il. 11.101 , 104, 109.
Ἄντιφος-4 (αἰχμητής). Son of Aegyptius-1. Devoured by the Cyclops Od. 2.19.
Ἄντιφος-5. A comrade in Ithaca of Odysseus Od. 17.68.
Ἀντρών (ἀγχίαλος). A town in the realm of Protesilaus Il. 2.697.
Ἀξιός (εὐρὺ ῥέων, εὐρυρέεθρος ). A river flowing into the Thermaic Gulf Il. 2.849, 850, Il. 16.288; father of Pelegon by Periboea-1 Il. 21.141 , 157, 158.
Ἄξυλος Trojan. Patronymic Τευθρανίδης. Dwelt by the roadside in Arisbe. With his charioteer Calesius killed by Diomedes Il. 6.12.
Ἀπαισός Παισός Il. 5.612. A dist. of the Troad on the western extremity of the Propontis Il. 2.828, Il. 5.612.
Ἀπειραῖος Adj. from next. Of Eurymedousa Od. 7.8.
Ἀπείρη A mythical land. Ἀπείρηθεν [-θεν], from Apeira Od. 7.9.
Ἀπισάων-1 Trojan. (ποιμὴν λαῶν). Patronymic Φαυσιάδης . Killed by Eurypylus-2 Il. 11.578, 582.
Ἀπισάων-2 Trojan. (ποιμὴν λαῶν). Patronymic Ἱππασίδης-3. Killed by Lycomedes Il. 17.348.

Ἀπόλλων Voc. Ἄπολλον (ἄναξ, ἀργυρότοξος, Δῒ φίλος, ἑκάεργος, ἑκατηβελέτης, ἑκατηβόλος, ἕκατος, ἑκηβόλος, κλυτότοξος, λαοσσόος, Λυκηγενής, χρυσάορος). Called also Φοῖβος (ἀκερσεκόμης, ἤϊος ) Il. 1.443, Il. 15.221, 365, Il. 16.667, 788, Il. 20.39, 152, Il. 21.436, 448. Ἀπόλλων Φοῖβος Il. 16.700, Od. 17.68, Il. 21.515, 545. Φοῖβος Ἀπόλλων Il. 1.43, Il. 5.344, Il. 9.560, Il. 12.24, Il. 15.59, Il. 20.118, Il. 23.188, etc.: Od. 3.279, Od. 8.79, Od. 9.201. Son of Zeus and Leto and brother of Artemis. Identified with Smintheus Il. 1.39. Besought by Chryses (Il. 1.37) sends pestilence on the Greeks Il. 1.43, is appeased 457; saves Aeneas from Diomedes Il. 5.440; with Poseidon destroys the Greek wall Il. 12.17; sent by Zeus heartens Hector Il. 15.236; cures Glaucus-2 Il. 16.527; cares for Sarpedon's corpse Il. 16.676; repels Patroclus from the walls Il. 16.698; strikes and unarms Patroclus Il. 16.788, Il. 18.454; his death-dealing shafts (always directed against men, for those of Artemis see Ἄρτεμις ) Il. 21.278, Il. 24.605 , 758 (cf. Od. 3.279, Od. 7.64, Od. 15.410, Od. 17.251, 494); in the Battle of the Gods Poseidon challenges him Il. 21.436, but he declines 461 ; beguiles Achilles while the Trojans flee Il. 21.599 ; Achilles destined to fall before him and Paris Il. 22.359; in the chariot-race disables Diomedes Il. 23.382; cares for Hector's corpse Il. 24.18; etc.: Od. 6.162 Od. 8.79, Od. 9.198, Od. 15.245, etc.

data.ref: Il. 1.37) sends pestilence on the Greeks
494); in the Battle of the Gods

definition: Ἀραιθυρέη (ἐρατεινή). A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.571.
Ἀργεάδης Patronymic of Polymelus Il. 16.417.

Ἀργεῖος 1 Of Argos-1 (apparently in sense (4)), Argive. Of Helen Il. 2.161 , 177, Il. 3.458, Il. 4.19, 174, Il. 6.323, Il. 7.350, Il. 9.140, 282: Od. 4.184, 296, Od. 17.118, Od. 23.218. Of Hera Il. 4.8, Il. 5.908. 2 In pl., the Argives a The people of Argos-1 (1) Il. 19.122, 124: Od. 3.309, Od. 15.240. b The people of Proetus (his seat being Tiryns in Argos-1 (1)) Il. 6.159. c The Greeks on their way to Troy Od. 1.211, Od. 2.173, Od. 18.253, Od. 19.126. d The Greeks in the field at Troy (= Ἀχαιός 2.b.γ, Δαναοί 2) (αἰχμηταί, θωρηκταί , ἰόμωροι, φιλοπτόλεμοι , χαλκοχίτωνες) Il. 1.79 , Il. 3.19, Il. 5.3, Il. 7.18, Il. 8.36, Il. 11.16, Il. 12.3, Il. 15.8, Il. 19.84, Il. 21.429, Il. 24.168, etc.: Od. 1.61, Od. 3.129 , 379, Od. 4.172, 200, 258, 273, 279, Od. 8.513, 578, Od. 10.15, Od. 11.369, 485, 500, 518, 524, 555, Od. 12.190, Od. 17.119, Od. 24.54, 62, 81. e The Greeks preparing for or on their return (Ἀχαιός 2.b (d)) Od. 3.133, Od. 8.502.
Ἀργεϊφόντης See Lexicon.
Ἄργισσα A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.738.

Ἄργος-1 (ἱππόβοτον, κλυτόν , οὖθαρ ἀρούρης, πολυδίψιον , πολύπυρον). The Argolic plain in the Peloponnesus stretching inwards from the Argolic gulf, and, apparently, adjoining lands Il. 1.30, Il. 2.108 (here apparently the whole of the mainland over which Agamemnon's sway extended), 115, 559 (the realm of Diomedes (cf. Il. 6.224 , Il. 14.119: Od. 3.180 )), Il. 4.171, Il. 6.224 , Il. 9.22, 141, 283, Il. 13.379, Il. 14.119, Il. 15.30, Il. 19.115: Od. 3.180, 251, 263, Od. 15.224, 239, 274. The city Argos still known by the same name Il. 4.52: Od. 21.108. Of southern Greece, esp. the Pelopnnesus, in contrast to northern Greece Il. 6.152: Od. 4.174, 562. Apparently also Od. 4.246. Esp. in phrase καθʼ (ἀνʼ) Ἑλλάδα καὶ μέσον Ἄργος 344, Od. 4.726, 816, Od. 15.80. Of Greece in general Il. 2.287, Il. 6.456, Il. 7.363, Il. 9.246, Il. 12.70, Il. 13.227, Il. 14.70, Il. 15.372, Il. 19.329, Il. 24.437: Od. 4.99, Od. 24.37. Apparently also Il. 3.75, 258 (Argos and Achaeis being apparently to be regarded as the same). Ἄργοσδε [-δε], to Greece Il. 2.348.

data.ref: Il. 2.108 (here apparently the whole of the mainland over which
258 (Argos and Achaeis being apparently to be regarded as the same).

definition: Ἄργος-2 Πελασγικόν. Apparently a general name for the realm of Peleus, including Phthia and Hellas Il. 2.681.
Ἄργος-3. The dog of Odysseus. The only creature to recognize Odysseus in his disguise Od. 17.292, 300 ; dies 326.
Ἀργώ (πασιμέλουσα). The ship of the Argonauts Od. 12.70.
Ἀρέθουσα A spring in Ithaca near the dwelling of Eumaeus and the Κόρακος πέτρη 408.
Ἀρετάων Trojan. (δῖος). Killed by Teucrus Il. 6.31.
Ἀρηΐθοος-1 (ἄναξ, δῖος). Named the clubbearer. Father by Phylomedousa of Menesthius-1 Il. 7.8 , 10; was slain by Lycourgus-2 Il. 7.137, 138.
Ἀρηΐθοος-2. Chariot-driver to Rhigmus. Killed by Achilles Il. 20.487.
Ἀρηΐλυκος-1. Father of Prothoenor-2 Il. 14.451.
Ἀρηΐλυκος-2 Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.308.
Ἀρήνη (ᾱ) (ἐρατεινή). A town of Pylus Il. 2.591 , Il. 11.723.

Ἄρης (α᷌). Genit. Ἄρεος (α᷌), Ἄρηος (α᷌)). Dat. Ἄρεϊ (α᷌), Ἄρει (ᾱ) , Ἄρηϊ (α᷌), Ἄρῃ (ᾰ) . Acc. Ἄρηα (α᷌). Voc. Ἆρες, Ἄρες. (ἀΐδηλος, ἀλλοπρόσαλλος , ἀνδροφόνος, ἆτος πολέμοιο , βριήπυος, βροτολοιγός , ἐγχέσπαλος, θοός , θοῦρος, κορυθαίολος , κρατερός, λαοσσόος , μιαιφόνος, ὄβριμος , ὀξύς, οὖλος, πελώριος, πτολίπορθος, ῥινοτόρος, ταλαύρινος πολεμιστής , τειχεσιπλήτης, χάλκεος , χρυσήνιος). See also Ἐνυάλιος. Son of Zeus and Her and father by Astyoche of Ascalaphus and Ialmenus. Athene leads him from the fray Il. 5.30; Aphrodite begs the use of his horses Il. 5.355; had been put in bonds by Otus-1 and Ephialtes Il. 5.385 ; Athene and Diomedes go against him Il. 5.840, Diomedes wounds him and puts him to flight 855, his complaint to Zeus 872 , he is cured 899; his rage on hearing of the death of Ascalaphus Il. 15.113, restrained by Athene 125; in the Battle of the Gods attacks Athene Il. 21.391, who lays him low 403 , Aphrodite leads him off 416, Athene lays them both low 423; etc: Od. 8.115; Demodocus's tale of Ares and Aphrodite Od. 8.266, 276 , 285, 309, 330, 345, 353, 355; Od. 8.518, Od. 11.537, Od. 14.216, Od. 16.269, Od. 20.50. See also Ἄρης in Lexicon.

Ἀρήτη (ᾱ) (λευκώλενος). Daughter of Rhexenor and niece and wife of Alcinous. Her parentage Od. 7.54, how she was honoured by Alcinous and the people 67; Odysseus supplicates her Od. 7.142; she recognizes the robe given to Odysseus by Nausicaa Od. 7.233; packs up Odysseus's gifts Od. 8.438; etc.
Ἀρητιάδης Patronymic of Nisus Od. 16.395, Od. 18.413.
Ἄρητος-1 (ᾱ) T (θεοειδής) Il. 17.494 . Killed by Automedon Il. 17.517, 535.
Ἄρητος-2 (ᾱ). Son of Nestor Od. 3.414 , 440.
Ἀριάδνη (καλή, καλλιπλόκαμος ). Daughter of Minos. Her dancing-floor at Cnosus Il. 18.592: carried off by Theseus but slain by Artemis in Dia Od. 11.321.
Ἄριμοι A mythical people in whose country Typhoeus was put in bonds by Zeus Il. 2.783.
Ἀρίσβας Father of Leiocritus-1 Il. 17.345.
Ἀρίσβη (δῖα). A town of the Troad between A bydus and Percote Il. 2.836, Il. 6.13, Il. 21.43. Ἀρίσβηθεν [-θεν], from Arisbe Il. 2.838, Il. 12.96.
Ἀρίων (δῖος). The swift horse of Adrestus-1 of divine origin Il. 23.346.
Ἀρκάδες Greek. (ἐγχεσίμωροι). The Arcadians, an inland people of central Peloponnesus, to whom Agamemnon furnished ships Il. 2.611; Il. 7.134 .
Ἀρκαδίη The country of the Arcadians Il. 2.603.
Ἀρκεισιάδης Patronymic from next. Of Laertes Od. 4.755 , Od. 24.270, 517.
Ἀρκείσιος (ἀντίθεος). Father of Laertes Od. 14.182, Od. 16.118.
Ἀρκεσίλαος A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.495. Killed by Hector Il. 15.329.
Ἄρκτος See ἄρκτος 2 in Lexicon.
Ἅρμα A Boeotian town Il. 2.499.
Ἁρμονίδης Patronymic of Tecton Il. 5.60.
Ἀρναῖος The real name of Irus Od. 18.5.
Ἄρνη (πολυστάφυλος). A Boeotian town Il. 2.507; the home of Menesthius-1 Il. 7.9.
Ἁρπαλίων Trojan. Son of Pylaemenes. Killed by Meriones Il. 13.644.
Ἅρπυια See Lexicon.
Ἀρσίνοος (μεγαλήτωρ). Father of Hecamede Il. 11.626.
Ἀρτακίη (καλλιρέεθρος). The fountain of the Laestrygonians Od. 10.108.

Ἄρτεμις (ἁγνή, ἀγροτέρη, ἐϋπλόκαμος, ἰοχέαιρα, κελαδεινή, πότνα θεά, χρυσηλάκατος, χρυσήνιος, χρυσόθρονος). Daughter of Zeus and Leto and sister of Apollo Il. 5.51, 53, 447, Il. 6.205; her death-dealing shafts, always (except Od. 5.123) directed against women (those of Apollo against men) Il. 6.428, Il. 19.59, Il. 24.606 (cf. Od. 11.172, 324, Od. 15.410, 478, Od. 18.202, Od. 20.60, 61, 80); Il. 9.533, Il. 16.183, Il. 20.39, 71; in the Battle of the Gods reproaches Apollo Il. 21.471, Hera assaults her 489 : Od. 4.122, Od. 6.102, 151, Od. 17.37, Od. 19.54, Od. 20.71.
Ἀρύβας (ῥυδὸν ἀφνειός). A Sidonian, father of the Phoenician woman who stole Eumaeus away Od. 15.426 .
Ἀρχέλοχος Trojan. Son of Antenor. A leader of the Dardanians Il. 2.823, Il. 12.100. Killed by Aias-1 Il. 14.464.
Ἀρχεπτόλεμος Trojan. (θρασύς). Patronymic Ἰφιτίδης. Hector takes him as his chariot-driver Il. 8.128. Killed by Teucrus Il. 8.312.
Ἀσαῖος (ῡ) Greek. Killed by Hector Il. 11.301.
Ἀσιάδης (ᾱ). Patronymic from Ἄσιος-2. Of Phaenops-3 Il. 17.583. And apparently of Adamas Il. 12.140, Il. 13.561, 759, 771.
Ἀσίνη A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.560.
Ἄσιος-1 (ᾱ) (αἰζηός τε κρατερός τε). Son of Dymas-1 full brother of Hecabe and uncle of Hector. Apollo takes his form Il. 16.717.

Ἄσιος-2 (ᾱ) (ἄναξ, μέγας, ὄρχαμος ἀνδρῶν). Patronymic Ὑρτακίδης. Son of Hyrtacus and father of Phaenops-3. Leader of the men of Percote, Abydus, etc. Il. 2.837 , 838, Il. 12.95, 96; eagerly attacks the Greeks at the ships Il. 12.110, 136, 139, 163. Killed by Idomeneus Il. 13.384, 403, 414, 759, 771.
Ἄσιος-3 Ἀσίω (ᾱ). Adj. from, the second form genit. of, Ἀσίας, said to have been a king of Lydia Il. 2.461.
Ἀσκάλαφος Son of Ares and Astyoche. A leader of the men of Orchomenus-1, etc. Il. 2.512, Il. 9.82, Il. 13.478. Killed by Deiphobus Il. 13.518, 526, 527, Il. 15.112.
Ἀσκανίη (ἐριβῶλαξ). A lake (and its district) connected with the Propontis, on which lake lay the later town of Nicaea Il. 2.863, Il. 13.793 .
Ἀσκάνιος (θεοειδής). Came from Ascania, son of Hippotion. A leader of the Phrygians Il. 2.862, Il. 13.792.
Ἀσκληπιάδης Patronymic from next. Of Machaon Il. 4.204 , Il. 11.614, Il. 14.2.
Ἀσκληπιός (ἀμύμων ἰητήρ). Father of Podaleirius and Machaon Il. 2.731, Il. 4.194, Il. 11.518.
Ἀσπληδών A Boeotian town near Orchomenus-1 Il. 2.511 .
Ἀσσάρακος Son of Trus-1, father of Capys and grandfather of Anchises Il. 20.232 , 239.
Ἀστέριον A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.735.
Ἀστερίς (πετρήεσσα). An island represented as lying between Ithaca and Same Od. 4.846.
Ἀστεροπαῖος (ἀρήϊος, περιδέξιος , φαίδιμος). Son of Pelegon and a leader of the Paeonians Il. 12.102 , Il. 17.217, 351, 352. Killed by Achilles Il. 21.140, 163, 170; Il. 23.560, 808.
Ἀστύαλος Trojan. killed by Polypoetes Il. 6.29.
Ἀστυάναξ (ἀγαπητός, ἀλίγκιος ἀστέρι καλῷ). Infant son of Hector and Andromache (called Scamandrius by his father). The name explained Il. 6.403; Il. 22.500, 506.
Ἀστύνοος-1 Trojan. killed by Diomedes Il. 5.144.
Ἀστύνοος-2 Trojan. Son of Protiaon Il. 15.455.
Ἀστυόχεια Captured by Heracles at Ephyra-1 and bore him Tlepolemus-1 Il. 2.658 .
Ἀστυόχη Daughter (apparently) of Actor-1 and mother by Ares of Ascalaphus and Ialmenus Il. 2.513.
Ἀστύπυλος Trojan. A Paeonian. Killed by Achilles Il. 21.209.
Ἀσφαλίων θεράπων of Menelaus at Sparta Od. 4.216.
Ἀσωπός (ᾱ) (βαθύσχοινος λεχεποίης). A river of killed by Boeotia Il. 4.383, Il. 10.287: father of Antiope Od. 11.260.
Ἄτη (ᾱ). πρέσβα Διὸς θυγάτηρ 91 . See further in Lexicon.
Ἄτλας (ὀλοόφρων). Father of Calypso Od. 1.52, Od. 7.245.
Ἀτρεΐων Patronymic from next, = prec. Of Agamemnon Il. 1.387, Il. 2.192, 445 , Il. 23.233, Il. 24.395 .

Ἀτρεύς (δαΐφρων, ἱππόδαμος , ποιμὴν λαῶν). Son of Pelops, brother of Thyestes and father of Agamemnon and Menelaus Il. 2.23; the sceptre given to him by Pelops and by him to Thyestes Il. 2.105, 106; Il. 3.37, Il. 6.46, Il. 17.1; etc.: Od. 4.462, 543, Od. 11.436.
Ἀτρυτώνη See Lexicon.
Ἀτυμνιάδης Patronymic of Mydon-1 Il. 5.581.
Ἀτύμνιος Trojan. (ἀκοντιστης). Son of Amisodarus and brother of Maris. Killed by Antilochus Il. 16.317.
Αὐγειαί-1 (ἐρατειναί). A Locrian town Il. 2.532.
Αὐγειαί-2 (ἐρατειναί). A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.583.
Αὐγείας (ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν). Ruler of Elis and father of Agasthenes and Agamede. Detained Neleus's race-horses Il. 11.701, 739.
Αὐγηϊάδης Patronymic from prec. Of Agasthenes Il. 2.624.
Αὐλίς -ίδος (πετρήεσσα). A Boeotian town on the Euripus by which the Greek ships assembled Il. 2.303, 496.

Αὐτόλυκος (μεγαλήτωρ). Husband of Amphithee and father of Anticleia Od. 11.85 ; dwelt by Parnassus Od. 19.394; gives a name to the babe Odysseus, his grandson Od. 19.399; Odysseus goes to visit him and is wounded by a boar Od. 19.413, Od. 21.220 , Od. 24.334. His skill in thieving and false swearing Il. 10.267: Od. 19.394.

Αὐτομέδων (ἄλκιμος, δουρικλυτός ). Son of Diores-2. θεράπων of Achilles Il. 9.209, Il. 16.864; acts as chariot-driver to Patroclus Il. 16.145, 148, 219, 472, 684; after Patroclus 's death drives alone Il. 17.429, 452, 459; takes up Alcimedon Il. 17.468, 469, 474; stands up to Hector and Aeneas Il. 17.483, 498; kills Aretus-1 Il. 17.516, 536; escapes Hector Il. 17.525; retires Il. 17.540; acts as chariot-driver to Achilles Il. 19.392, 397; Il. 23.563, Il. 24.474, 574, 625.
Αὐτονόη A handmaid of Penelope Od. 18.182.
Αὐτόνοος-1 Greek. Killed by Hector Il. 11.301.
Αὐτόνοος-2 Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.694.
Αὐτόφονος Father of Polyphontes Il. 4.395.
Ἀφαρεύς Greek. Patronymic Καλητορίδης 83 , Il. 13.478. Killed by Aeneas Il. 13.541.
Ἀφείδας (ἄναξ). Patronymic Πολυπημονίδης. Alleged father of the alleged Eperitus Od. 24.305.

Ἀφροδίτη (ᾰ, ῑ) (δῖα, Διὸς θυγάτηρ (κούρη), ἐϋστέφανος, φιλομμειδής, χρυσέη, χρυσείη). Called also Κύπρις Il. 5.330 , 422, 458, 760, 883; and Κυθέρεια Od. 8.288 , Od. 18.193. Daughter of Zeus and Dione and by Anchises mother of Aeneas (Il. 2.820). In Od. (Od. 8.266) the wife of Hephaestus. Her seat Paphos Od. 8.363. Saves Paris from Menelaus Il. 3.374; summons Helen to Paris Il. 3.389; carries off Aeneas from Diomedes Il. 5.311, Diomedes attacks and wounds her 330, her complaint to Dione 370; gives Hera her κεστὸς ιμάς 188; in the Battle of the Gods leads off the wounded Ares Il. 21.416, is smitten by Athene 423; etc.: Od. 4.14, 261; Demodocus's tale of Ares and Aphrodite Od. 8.266, 308 , 337, 342, 362; Od. 17.37, Od. 19.54, Od. 20.68, 73. See also Ἀφροδίτη in Lexicon.
Ἀχαιϊάδες (ἐΰπεπλοι). Achaean women (Ἀχαιός 2.b (a)) Il. 5.422, 424: Od. 3.261 . The women of the realm of Odysseus (Ἀχαιός 2.b) Od. 2.101, Od. 19.146, Od. 21.160, Od. 24.136.
Ἀχαιϊκός Achaean. (1) λαὸς Ἀχαιϊκός Ἀχαιός 2.b (γ) Il. 9.521, Il. 13.349, Il. 15.218. Applied to Argos-1 (1) Il. 9.141, 283, Il. 19.115: Od. 3.251.

Ἀχαιΐς Fem. adj. (1) Achaean. Ἀχαιῒς γαῖα (αἶα) (Ἀχαιός 2.b (a)) Il. 1.254, Il. 7.124: Od. 13.249, Od. 21.107. Absol. (καλλιγύναιξ) Il. 3.75 , 258 (for these cf. under Ἄργος-1 (4)): Od. 11.166, 481, Od. 23.68. Apparently in particular of the realm of Peleus (πουλοβότειρα) Il. 11.770 . In pl., (the) Achaean women Il. 2.235, Il. 7.96. Apparently in particular of the maidens of the realm of Peleus Il. 9.395: of the realm of Odysseus Od. 21.251.

Ἀχαιός 1 In sing., of the Achaeans (see 2.b.γ below) Il. 3.167, 226. 2 Absol. in pl. a Applied with Μυρμιδόνες and Ἕλληνες to the followers of Achilles Il. 2.684 . Distinguished from Μυρμιδόνες 564. b (ἀρήϊοι, ἀρηΐφιλοι , δῖοι, ἑλίκωπες , ἐϋκνήμιδες, κάρη κομόωντες, μεγάθυμοι, μένεα πνείοντες, μένος ἄσχετοι , ὑπερκύδαντες, φιλοπτόλεμοι, χαλκοχίτωνες, χαλκοκνήμιδες). The Greeks. 2.b.α The race in gen. (= Δαναοί 1) Il. 4.384, Il. 5.803, Il. 6.223, Il. 9.673, Il. 10.286, Il. 11.21, 511, Il. 13.669, Il. 14.124, etc.: Od. 3.79, 202, 203, 217, 411, Od. 4.344, Od. 5.311, Od. 8.78, Od. 11.478, 556, Od. 12.184, Od. 17.135, Od. 18.205. In fem. (ἐϋπλοκαμῖδες) Od. 2.119 . b> The followers of Odysseus on his way to Troy (in Odysseus's tale to Penelope) Od. 19.199. c The Greeks in the field at Troy (Ἀργεῖος 2.d, Δαναοί 2) Il. 1.2, Il. 2.4 , Il. 3.8, Il. 7.35, Il. 13.14, Il. 15.11. Il. 16.21, Il. 21.4, Il. 23.1, Il. 24.118, etc.: Od. 3.100, 116 , 220, Od. 4.106, 145, 243, 248, 256, 288, 330, Od. 8.220, 489, 490, Od. 11.509, 513, Od. 14.493, Od. 18.259, Od. 19.240 , Od. 24.27, 49, 57, 68, 86. Ἀχαιοί contrasted with Ἀχαιΐδες 235, Il. 7.96. υἷες Ἀχαιῶν 162, Il. 4.114, Il. 6.255, Il. 9.247, Il. 13.172, Il. 16.698, Il. 17.645 , Il. 24.495, etc.: Od. 3.104, Od. 4.285, Od. 8.514, Od. 13.315, Od. 14.229, 240, Od. 15.153, Od. 23.220, Od. 24.38. κοῦροι Ἀχαιῶν 473 , Il. 3.82, Il. 14.505 , Il. 17.758, Il. 22.391, etc.: Od. 24.54. κούρητες Ἀχαιῶν 248 . d The Greeks preparing for and on their return (= Ἀργεῖος 2.e) Od. 1.286, 326 , Od. 3.131, 137, 141, 149, 185, Od. 4.487, 496, Od. 9.59, 259, Od. 10.15, Od. 13.317, Od. 14.242 . υἷες Ἀχαιῶν 139. e The people of Odysseus at home or the ruling race among them Od. 1.90, 272, 394, 401, Od. 2.7, 72, 87, 112, 211, 265, Od. 16.133, 250, 376, Od. 20.146, 182, 277, Od. 21.324, 344, Od. 23.357, Od. 24.426, 438. In fem. (ἐϋπλοκαμῖδες) 542 . f Applied particularly to the suitors Od. 2.90, 106, 128, 204, 306, Od. 4.847, Od. 11.179, Od. 16.76, Od. 17.413, 415, 513, 596, Od. 18.62, 94, 191, 286, 289, 301, Od. 19.151, 528, 534, Od. 20.3, 166, 271, Od. 21.418, 428, Od. 22.46, 96, Od. 24.141. υἷες Ἀχαιῶν 115, 198. g The people of Neleus or Nestor at Pylus Il. 11.759: Od. 3.372. h The ruling race in Argos-1 (1) (3) Od. 15.274 , Od. 18.246. i Said by Odysseus in his tale to Penelope to be one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.175.
Ἀχελώϊος-1 (κρείων). The largest Greek river flowing south from the Pindus range to the Ionian Sea Il. 21.194.
Ἀχελώϊος-2. An unknown river of Lydia Il. 24.616.
Ἀχέρων A river of the underworld Od. 10.513. See Κώκυτος.

Ἀχιλλεύς (ἀγαυός, ἀμύμων, ἄναξ, Ἀρήϊος, δαΐφρων, διίφιλος, δῖος, θεῖος, θεοείκελος, θεοῖς ἐπιείκελος , θυμολέων, κλυτός , καρτερός, κυδάλιμος , μεγάθυμος, μέγα φέρτατος Ἀχαιῶν, ἄβριμος, ὀλοός, ὄρχαμος ἀνδρῶν, πελώριος, ποδάρκης, πόδας ταχύς (ὠκύς), ποδώκης , ποιμὴν λαῶν, πτολίπορθος , ῥηξήνωρ, ταχύς, ὑπέρθυμος, φαίδιμος, ὠκύς). Patronymic Πηλεΐδης, Πηλεΐων, Πηληϊάδης, Αἰακίδης. Son of Peleus and Thetis and father of Neoptolemus. Leader of the Myrmidons and the great bulwark of the Greeks. Calls an assembly Il. 1.54, addresses Agamemnon 59 , and Calchas 85, Achilles again 122 , abuses Agammemnon 149, questions with himself whether to slay Agammemnon 188, Athene appears 194 , and restrains him 207, he abuses Agammemnon again 225, his final speech to Agammemnon 293, retires to his ships from the fight 306; yields Briseis to the heralds of Agamemnon Il. 1.337 , calls to his mother 352, she promises her intercession with Zeus 414; he receives the embassy Il. 9.193, his speech 308, he rejects finally the proposals 644; Patroclus approaches him Il. 16.2, and asks to be sent to the fight 21, Achilles accedes 49 , and marshals the Myrmidons 155, his prayer to Zeus 233 ; he hears from Antilochus of the death of Patroclus Il. 18.18 , his mother comes to him 70, and promises armour from Hephaestus 136; Iris urges him to come to the rescue of the corpse of Patroclus Il. 18.170, Athene kindles fire from his head 203, he shouts from the ditch 215, and accompanies the rescued corpse 234, his lament 316; his mother brings the divine armour Il. 19.8, he rouses the host 40, he renounces his wrath 146; his further lament Il. 19.315; he assumes the armour Il. 19.367, and addresses his horses 400; he and Aeneas meet in fight Il. 20.158, Poseidon withdraws Aeneas 325; Achilles and Hector meet Il. 20.422 , Apollo withdraws H. Il. 20.443, Achilles does much execution Il. 20.455; he drives a part of the foe into the Xanthus-1 Il. 21.7, he encounters Lycaon-2 34, and slays him 116, after doing much execution is addressed by the river 214 , the river rises upon him 240, he is saved by the fire of Hephaestus 342; Agenor stands up to him 550, is withdrawn by Apollo 596, Apollo in his guise beguiles Achilles to a vain pursuit 599; he approaches the city Il. 22.21, Hector awaits him 35 , but flees before him and is chased thrice round the walls 136 , they fight 273, Achilles slays Η. 326, and drags the corpse to the ships 395; the shade of Patroclus appears to him Il. 23.65, he places his lock dedicated to the Spercheius in the hands of Patroclus's corpse 140, he summons the winds to fan the pyre 192; he sets the prizes for the funeral games Il. 23.262; Thetis sent by Zeus persuades him to accept ransom for Hector's corpse from Priam Il. 24.128, he hearkens to P.'s appeal 483, he gives directions for releasing the corpse 572; etc.: Od. 3.106, 109, 189, Od. 4.5; his strife with Odysseus Od. 8.75; Odysseus encounters him in the Shades Od. 11.467, 478, 482, 486, his lament to Odysseus 488; Od. 11.546, 557; in the second νέκυια 15, 36, 72, 76, 94.

data.ref: Il. 20.455; he drives a part of the foe into the

definition: Ἀψευδής A Nereid Il. 18.46 .
Βαθυκλέης (μεγάθυμος). A Myrmidon, son of Chalcon. Killed by Glaucus-2 Il. 16.594.
Βαλίος One of the horses of Achilles, by Zephyrus out of Podarge Il. 16.149 , Il. 19.400.
Βατίεια (αἰπεῖα). A hill in the Trojan plain Il. 2.813. So called by mortals; called by the gods (Il. 2.814) the grave-mound of Myrine.

Βελλεροφόντης (ἀμύμων, δαΐφρων ). Son of Glaucus-1 and father of Isandrus, Hippolochus-1 and Laodameia. His beauty and valour Il. 6.155; repulsed the love of Anteia, wife of Proetus Il. 6.160, by her contrivance sent by Proetus to Proetus's father-in-law the king of Lycia with a secret message importing his death 163, the dangerous tasks set him 178, and the ambush laid for him 187, received the king's daughter to wife and half of the kingdom 191 , his children 196, his fate 200; had been entertained by Oeneus Il. 6.216, 220.
Βῆσσα A Locrian town Il. 2.532.
Βίας-1 Greek. (ποιμὴν λαῶν). Il. 4.296.
Βίας-2 Greek. (ἐΰς). Il. 13.691.
Βίας-3 Trojan. Father of Laogonus-2 and Dardanus-2 Il. 20.460 .
Βιήνωρ Trojan. (ποιμὴν λαῶν). With his comrade Oeleus-2 killed by Agamemnon Il. 11.92 .
Βοάγριος A Locrian river Il. 2.533.
Βοηθοΐδης Patronymic of Eteoneus Od. 4.31, Od. 15.95, 140 .
Βοίβη A town of the realm of Eumelus lying on the Boebean Lake (see next) Il. 2.712.
Βοιβηΐς (λίμνη). A lake lying west of and under the range of Pelion and Ossa Il. 2.711.
Βοιώτιος Boeotian Il. 14.476 , Il. 17.597.
Βοιωτός Greek. Βοιωτοί, the Boeotians. Their leaders Il. 2.494, Il. 15.330; Il. 2.510, 526 , Il. 5.710, Il. 13.685, 700.
Βούδειον (εὖ ναιόμενον). A town of uncertain site. The original home of Epeigeus Il. 16.572.
Βουκολίδης Patronymic of Sphelus Il. 15.338.
Βουκολίων (ἀμύμων). Bastard son of Laomedon and father by Abarbaree of Aesepus-2 and Pedasus-3 (twins) Il. 6.22, 23.
Βουπράσιον (πολύπυρον). A region of Elis Il. 2.615 , Il. 11.756, 760; the scene of the funeral of Amarynceus Il. 23.631.
Βοώτης (ὀψὲ δύων). See Lexicon.
Βριάρεως See Αἰγαίων.
Βρισεύς Father of next Il. 1.392, Il. 9.132, 274.

Βρισηΐς (ἠΰκομος, ἰκέλη Ἀφροδίτῃ , καλλιπάρῃος). Patronymic from prec. Captured by Achilles at Lyrnessus Il. 2.689 ; Il. 1.184; taken from Achilles by Agamemnon's heralds Il. 1.323, 336, 346, Il. 9.106; restored Il. 19.246, 261 ; her lament over Patroclus Il. 19.282; Il. 24.676.
Βρυσειαί A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.583.
Βῶρος-1. A Maeonian (Μῄων), father of Phaestus-2 Il. 5.44 .
Βῶρος-2. Son of Perieres, husband of Polydora and nominal father of Menesthius-2 Il. 16.177.
Γαῖα ΓαιήϊοςΓῆ. See Lexicon.
Γαλάτεια (ἀγακλειτή). A Nereid Il. 18.45 .
Γανυμήδης (αντίθεος). Son of Trus-1. Carried off by the gods to be their cup-bearer Il. 5.266, Il. 20.232.
Γάργαρον A peak of Mt. Ida Il. 8.48, Il. 14.292, 352, Il. 15.152.
Γεραιστός The south west point of Euboea Od. 3.177.

Γερήνιος Adj. from (apparently) the name of an unknown place, said to have been in Elis and to have sheltered Nestor when an exile from Pylus. Of Nestor Il. 2.336 , Il. 4.317, Il. 7.170, Il. 11.516, Il. 14.52, Il. 15.370, etc. : Od. 3.68, 102, 210, Od. 4.161, etc.
Γίγαντες (ἄγρια φῦλα, ὑπέρθυμοι ). A gigantic and savage race, represented (Od. 7.206) as being with the Cyclopes near the gods. Destroyed under Eurymedon-3 Od. 7.59; Od. 10.120.
Γλαύκη A Nereid Il. 18.39 .
Γλαῦκος-1 Son of Sisyphus, father of Bellerophon and grandfather of Hippolochus-1 Il. 6.154, 155.

Γλαῦκος-2 (ἀμύμων, κρατερός , ποιμήν λαῶν, φαίδιμος ). Son of Hippolochus-1. Comrade of Sarpedon and a leader of the Lycians Il. 2.876; fights Diomedes Il. 6.119, they exchange arms 234; Il. 7.13 , Il. 12.102, 309, 310, 329; wounded by Teucrus Il. 12.387; 392; Il. 14.426 ; the wounded Sarpedon appeals to him Il. 16.492, 508, he cries to Apollo 514, and is cured 527, 530; slays Bathyclees Il. 16.593, 597; reproves Hector Il. 17.140, 170; Il. 17.216 .
Γλαφύραι A town of the realm of Eumelus, probably lying by the Boebean Lake Il. 2.712.
Γλισᾶς A Boeotian town Il. 2.504.
Γονόεσσα (αἰπεινή). A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.573.
Γόργειος Adj. fr. Γοργώ Il. 5.741 : Od. 11.634.
Γοργυθίων (ἀμύμων, ἐΰς). Son of Priam by Castianeira. Killed by Teucrus Il. 8.302.
Γοργώ (βλοσυρῶπις). A frightful phantom Il. 8.349, Il. 11.36.
Γόρτυς (τειχιόεσσα). A city of Crete Il. 2.646 : part of the fleet of Menelaus wrecked near it Od. 3.294.

data.ref: Il. 2.646 : part of the fleet of

definition: Γουνεύς Greek. Leader of the Enienes and Peraebians Il. 2.748 .
Γραῖα A Boeotian town Il. 2.498.
Γρήνικος A river of the Troad west of the Aesepus-1 Il. 12.21.
Γυγαίη λίμνη. A lake to the north of Sardis. To Talaemenes bore Mesthles and Antiphus-2 Il. 2.865 , Il. 20.391.
Γυραί A rock of unknown site on which Aias-2 was destroyed by Poseidon Od. 4.500.
Γυραίη Adj. from prec. Od. 4.507.
Γυρτιάδης Patronymic of Hyrtius Il. 14.512.
Γυρτώνη A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.738.
Δαίδαλος Made Ariadne's dancing - place Il. 18.592.
Δαίτωρ Trojan. killed by Teucrus Il. 8.275.
Δάμασος Trojan. killed by Polypoetes Il. 12.183.
Δαμαστορίδης-1. Patronymic of Tlepolemus-2 Il. 16.416.
Δαμαστορίδης-2. Patronymic of Agelaus-3 Od. 20.321, Od. 22.212, 241, 293.
Δανάη (καλλίσφυρος.) Patronymic Ἀκρισιώνη. Mother of Perseus-1 by Zeus Il. 14.319.

Δαναοί (αἰχμηταί, θεράποντες Ἄρηος , ἴφθιμοι, ταχύπωλοι , φιλοπτόλεμοι.) The Greek race in gen. (= Ἀχαιός 2.b.α) Od. 4.725, 815 . The Greeks in the field at Troy (Ἀργεῖος 2.d, Ἀχαιός 2.b.γ Il. 1.42, Il. 2.40, Il. 4.232, Il. 5.37, Il. 8.33, Il. 9.34, Il. 12.4, Il. 13.9, Il. 15.2, Il. 16.39, Il. 17.26, Il. 19.78, Il. 20.351, Il. 21.517, Il. 24.295, etc. : Od. 1.350, Od. 4.278 , Od. 5.306, Od. 8.82, 578, Od. 11.470, 526, 551, 559, Od. 24.18, 46.

Δαρδανίδης Patronymic from Δάρδανος-1. Of Priam (descendant of Dardanus) Il. 3.303, Il. 5.159, Il. 7.366, Il. 13.376, Il. 21.34, Il. 22.352, Il. 24.171, 354, 629, 631. Similarly of Ilus-1 (descendant) Il. 11.166, 372.
Δαρδανίη A district occupying the middle valley of the Scamander. Peopled by Dardanus-1 Il. 20.216.
Δαρδάνιος Adj. from prec. πύλαι Δαρδάνιαι, one of the gates of Troy, not identified Il. 5.789, Il. 22.194, 413 . In pl. = Δάρδανοι (see Δάρδανος-3 (2)). Aeneas their leader Il. 2.819.
Δαρδανίς Fem. adj. In pl., the Dardanian women (βαθύκολποι) Il. 18.122 , 339.
Δαρδανίων Patronymic from next. In pl., Dardanians Il. 7.414, Il. 8.154.
Δάρδανος-1. Son of Zeus, father of Erichthonius, grandfather of Trus-1 and great-grandfather of Ilus-1 Il. 20.215, 219; the favourite child of Zeus Il. 20.304.
Δάρδανος-2 Τ. Son of Bias-3. Killed by Achilles Il. 20.460.

Δάρδανος-3 Δαρδάνιος. Dardanian Il. 2.701 , Il. 16.807. In pl., Δάρδανοι Τ (ἀγχιμαχηταί), the men of Dardania Il. 3.456 , Il. 7.348, 368, Il. 8.173, 497, Il. 11.286, Il. 13.150, Il. 15.425, 486, Il. 17.184.
Δάρης (ἀφνειὸς ἀμύμων). Priest of Hephaestus, apparently at Troy. Father of Phegeus and Idaeus-2 Il. 5.9, 27.
Δαυλίς A town of Phocis Il. 2.520.
Δεισήνωρ Trojan. Il. 17.217.
Δεξαμένη A Nereid Il. 18.44 .
Δεξιάδης Patronymic of Iphinous Il. 7.15.
Δευκαλίδης Patronymic from next. Of Idomeneus Il. 12.117, Il. 13.307, Il. 17.608.
Δευκαλίων-1 (ἁμύμων, μεγάθυμος ). Son of Minos and father of Idomeneus Il. 13.451 , 452 : in Odysseus's tale to Penelope he says that he was Deucalion's son Od. 19.180, 181 .
Δευκαλίων-2 Trojan. killed by Achilles Il. 20.478.
Δηϊκόων Trojan. Patronymic Περγασίδης.. A comrade of Aeneas. Killed by Agamemnon Il. 5.534.
Δηϊοπίτης Trojan. (ἀμύμων). Killed by Odysseus Il. 11.420.
Δηΐοχος Greek. Killed by Paris Il. 15.341.
Δηΐπυλος Companion of Sthenelus-1 Il. 5.325.
Δηΐπυρος Greek. Il. 9.83, Il. 13.92, 478. Killed by Helenus-1 Il. 13.576.

Δηΐφοβος (θεοειδής, θεοείκελος ). Patronymic Πριαμίδης. Son of Priam and Hecabe Il. 12.94, Il. 13.156, 162, 258, 402, 413, 446, 455, 490, 517, 527, 758, 770, 781; Athene takes his form in approaching Hector in his last fight Il. 22.277; Il. 22.233, 294, 298, Il. 24.251: accompanied Helen when she visited the Trojan horse Od. 4.276; when the city was taken Odysseus and Menelaus proceeded to his house Od. 8.517.
Δῆλος The Aegean island, sacred to Apollo Od. 6.162.

Δημήτηρ (ἄνασσα, ἐϋπλόκαμος , καλλιπλόκαμος, ξανθή ). Daughter of Cronus and Rhea, sister of Zeus , Hades, Poseidon and Hera, and mother by Zeus of Persephoneia. The corn-goddess (Il. 5.500, Il. 13.322, Il. 21.76). Her τέμενος at Pyrasus-1 Il. 2.696; the love of Zeus for her Il. 14.326; her love for Iasion Od. 5.125.
Δημόδοκος (θεῖος (έρος) ἀοιδός). The Phaeacian bard Od. 8.44, 106, 254, 262; his tale of Ares and Aphrodite Od. 8.266 ; Od. 8.472, 478, 483, 486, 487, 537, Od. 13.28.
Δημοκόων Bastard son of Priam. Killed by Odysseus Il. 4.499.
Δημολέων Trojan. (ἐσθλὸς ἀλεξητὴρ μάχης). Son of Antenor. Killed by Achilles Il. 20.395.
Δημοπτόλεμος A suitor Od. 22.242. Killed by Odysseus Od. 22.266.
Δημοῦχος Trojan. (ἠΰς τε μέγας τε). Patronymic Φιλητορίδης . Killed by Achilles Il. 20.457.
Δία (ἀμφιρύτη). A small island (now Standia) off the north coast of Crete Od. 11.325. Also identified with Naxos.
Διόθεν See Ζεύς.
Διοκλῆς (μεγάθυμος). Son of Orsilochus-3 and father of Crethon and Orsilochus-4; dwelt at Pherae-2 Il. 5.542, 547, 548: Telemachus and Peisistratus pass the night in his house Od. 3.488, Od. 15.186.
Διομήδη (καλλιπάρἡος). Daughter of Phorbas-1. Captured by Achilles at Lesbos Il. 9.665.

Διομήδης (ἀγαθός, Αἰτωλός (see Οἰνεύς), ἄλκιμος , Ἀρήϊος, ἄριστος Ἀχαιῶν , βοήν ἀγαθός, δαΐφρων , δῖος, δουρικλειτός , δουρικλυτός, ἱππόδαμος , καρτερόθυμος, κρατερός , μεγάθυμος, μενοπτόλεμος , ποιμὴν λαῶν, ὑπέρθυμος ). Patronymic Τυδεΐδης. Son of Tydeus and husband of Aegialeia (who was his aunt, her sister (Deipyle) being the wife of Tydeus. See Adrestus-1). Leader of the men owning his sway in Argos-1 (1) Il. 2.563, 567; visited by Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.365, reproves Sthenelus-1 411; his feats under Athene's protection Il. 5.1, wounded by Pandarus 95 , Pandarus aims at him again 280, he slays Ρ. 290, attacks and wounds Aphrodite 330, 335, attacks Aeneas 432, but retires before Apollo 443, Ares attacks him 849, he wounds Ares and drives him off 855; fights Glaucus-2 Il. 6.119, they exchange arms 235; accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 7.163; speaks against accepting the offer of the Trojan herald Il. 7.399; comes to the rescue of Nestor Il. 8.91, he and Nestor are put to flight by a thunderbolt from Zeus 130; declares in the Assembly that he will fight to the end Il. 9.31 ; his speech on the announcement by Odysseus of the result of the embassy Il. 9.697; wakened by Agamemnon Il. 10.150, offers to penetrate the hostile lines 219, sets out with Odysseus 272, they encounter and capture and slay Dolon 339, they do execution and slay Rhesus-1 482, and return safely 540; strikes Hector Il. 11.349, is wounded by Paris 369 ; relates his family history Il. 14.110; takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.290, is disabled by Apollo 383, but comes in first 499, meets Aias-1 in the fight in armour 812; etc.: his return from Troy Od. 3.167, 181; in ambush in the Trojan horse Od. 4.280.
Δῖον (αἰπὺ πτολίεθρον). A town of Euboea Il. 2.538.
Διόνυσος Διώνυσος (χάρμα βροτοῖσιν). Son of Zeus and Semele (Il. 14.325). He and his attendants scattered by Lycourgus-1 Il. 6.132, 135: his part in the death of Ariadne Od. 11.325; Od. 24.74.

data.ref: 135: his part in the death of

definition: Δῖος (ἀγαυός). A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.251.
Διός etc. Genit., etc., of Ζεύς.
Διώνη (δῖα θεάων). Mother by Zeus of Aphrodite Il. 5.370 , 381.
Διώρης-1 (κρατερός). Patronymic Ἀμαρυγκεΐδης. Son of Amarynceus and a leader of the Epeians Il. 2.622. Killed by Peiroos Il. 4.517.
Διώρης.-2. Father of Automedon Il. 17.429, 474.
Δμήτωρ Patronymic Ἰασίδης-2. Odysseus's name for an alleged king of Cyprus Od. 17.443.

Δολίος-1 (γέρων). A bondman of Penelope given to her by her father and in charge of the garden and orchard Od. 4.735, Od. 24.222; his six sons Od. 24.387, 497 ; he and his sons welcome Odysseus Od. 24.397, 409, 411; a son reports the approach of the Ithacans Od. 24.492, Dolius arms 498.
Δολίος-2. Father of Melanthius-1 Od. 17.212, Od. 22.159, and Melantho Od. 18.322.
Δόλοπες A people on the west borders of the realm of Peleus Il. 9.484.
Δολοπίων (ὑπέρθυμος). Priest of the Scamander and father of Hypsenor-1 Il. 5.77 .
Δόλοψ-1 Greek. Patronymic Κλυτίδης-1. Killed by Hector Il. 11.302.
Δόλοψ-2 Trojan. (αἰχμῆς ἐΰ εἰδώς). Patronymic Λαμπετίδης . Killed by Menelaus Il. 15.525, 540, 555.
Δόλων (πολύχρυσος πολύχαλκος). Son of Eumedes. Described Il. 10.314; undertakes to Hector to penetrate the Greek lines Il. 10.319, captured by Diomedes 369, gives information 412, killed 454; etc.
Δόρυκλος Patronymic Πριαμίδης. Bastard son of Priam. Killed by Aias-1 Il. 11.489.
Δουλιχιεύς Adj. from next. Of Nisus Od. 18.127 . Of Amphinomus Od. 18.395. Of Moulius-4 Od. 18.424.

Δουλίχιον (ποιῆεν, πολύπυρον ). An island not identified the men from which were led by Meges Il. 2.625. Δουλίχιόνδε [-δε], to Doulichium Il. 2.629 : Od. 14.397. In Od. associated with Same, Zacynthus and Ithaca Od. 1.246, Od. 9.24 , Od. 16.123, 247, Od. 19.131. Its king Acastus Od. 14.335. The home of Amphinomus Od. 16.396. In Odysseus's tale to Eumaeus Od. 14.335, In Odysseus's tale to Penelope Od. 19.292 .
Δρακίος A leader of the Epeians Il. 13.692.
Δρῆσος Trojan. Killed by Euryalus-1 Il. 6.20.
Δρύας-1 (ποιμὴν λαῶν). A warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.263.
Δρύας-2. Father of Lycourgus-1 Il. 6.130.
Δρύοψ Trojan. killed by Achilles Il. 20.455.
Δύμας-1. Father of Asius-1 and Hecabe Il. 16.718.
Δύμας-2 (ναυσικλειτός). Athene takes the form of his daughter in Nausicaa's dream Od. 6.22 .
Δυναμένη A Nereid Il. 18.43 .
Δύσπαρις See Lexicon.
Δωδωναῖος Adj. from next. Of Zeus Il. 16.233 .

Δωδώνη (δυσχείμερος). In Epeirus with an oracle of Zeus (but (Il. 2.750) the Thessalian Enienes and Peraebians are said to have dwelt about it). The prayer of Achilles to Zeus of Dodona Il. 16.234: its oak and Odysseus's consultation Od. 14.327, Od. 19.296.
Δωριεύς (Δωριέες τριχάϊκες). In Odysseus's tale to Penelope one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.177.
Δώριον A town of Pylus where the Muses took from Thamyris his power of song Il. 2.594.
Δωρίς A Nereid Il. 18.45 .
Δωτώ A Nereid Il. 18.43 .
Εἰδοθέη Daughter of Proteus. Encounters Menelaus in Pharos Od. 4.366, her advice to him 371, how he carried it out 431.
Εἰλείθυια See Lexicon.
Εἰλέσιον A Boeotian town Il. 2.499.
Εἰρέτρια A town of Euboea Il. 2.537.

Ἑκάβη (ἠπιόδωρος). Daughter of Dymas-1, full sister of Asius-1 and wife of Priam (for her children see under Πρίαμος) Il. 6.251; collects the aged women to pray to Athene Il. 6.286, her gift to Α. 288, 293; Il. 6.451, Il. 16.718; vainly beseeches Hector to take refuge from Achilles Il. 22.79; Il. 22.234; she sees Hector's corpse being dragged away Il. 22.405, her lament 430; summoned by Priam Il. 24.193, she tries to dissuade him from going to the ships 200, she speeds him on his way 283; her lament over Hector's ransomed, corpse Il. 24.747.
Ἑκαμήδη (ἐϋπλόκαμος). Daughter of Arsinous. Given to Nestor when Tenedos was sacked. Doing service in Nestor's hut Il. 11.624, Il. 14.6.
Ἑκτόρεος Adj. from Ἕκτωρ. Of or pertaining to Hector Il. 2.416, Il. 10.46, Il. 24.276, 579.
Ἑκτορίδης Patronymic from next. Of Astyanax Il. 6.401 .

Ἕκτωρ (ἀνδροφόνος, βοὴν ἀγαθός , βροτολοιγῷ ἶσος Ἄρηϊ, Διὶ μῆτιν ἀτάλαντος, διίφιλος, δῖος, θοῷ ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, θρασύς, ἱππόδαμος, κλυτός, (μέγας) κορυθαίολος, κρατερὸς μήστωρ φόβοιο, μεγάθυμος, μέγας, ὄβριμος, πελώριος, ποιμὴν λαῶν, φαίδιμος, φλογὶ εἴκελος ἀλκήν , χαλκοκορυστής). Patronymic Πριαμίδης. Son of Priam and Hecabe and father of Astyanax. The leader of the Trojans Il. 2.816; reproaches Paris for shrinking from Menelaus Il. 3.38, proposes a duel between Patroclus and Il. 12.86; Sarpedon reproaches him for neglecting the allies Il. 5.471, he leads the fight 590, the wounded Sarpedon appeals to him in vain 684, he does much execution 703; Helenus-1 advises him to retire to the city and collect the aged women to pray to Athene Il. 6.77, he goes 116, he encounters the Trojan wives 237, and his mother, whom he charges to collect the aged women 251 , he proceeds to the house of Paris and reproaches him 313, his conversation with Helen 343, he proceeds to his own house but does not find Andromache there 370, he encounters her with Astyanax on his way back 392, their conversation 405, he leaves her 494, and encounters Paris returning also to the field 514, they join in the fight Il. 7.1; he proposes a duel between himself and a Greek champion Il. 7.67 , Aias-1 meets him 206 , the fight broken off by the heralds 279, Hector and Aias-1 exchange arms 303; Hector comes to attack Nestor Il. 8.87, who is rescued by Diomedes 99; Hector urges the Trojans on Il. 8.173, and addresses his horses 185, he hems in the Greeks 213, disables Teucrus 320 , drives the Greeks to the ships 337; after sunset summons an assembly Il. 8.485, advises his people to bivouac on the field 497; he induces Dolon to go as a scout to the ships Il. 10.303, 314; in the morning leads his people to the fight Il. 11.56, Zeus withdraws him 163 , and sends Iris to advise him to refrain while Agamemnon is in the field 186, when Agamemnon is disabled leads his people on 284, is struck by Diomedes and retires 349, but with Cebriones renews the fight 521, Il. 12.40; his horses refuse the ditch Il. 12.50, on the advice of Poulydamas advances on foot 80, an unfavourable omen 200 does not deter him 231, 251, he leads an attack on the wall 438, and breaks down the gate with a stone 445; he leads the fight within the wall Il. 13.136, Il. 14.388, Aias-1 disables him with a stone Il. 14.409; Apollo sent by Zeus restores his strength and he renews the fight Il. 15.244, 262, lays hold of the ship of Protesilaus 704, and calls for fire 718; the ship set on fire Il. 16.122; after he has retreated to the Scaean gate Apollo in the guise of Asius-1 urges him back to the fight Il. 16.721, he gives the final blow to Patroclus 818, urged by Apollo in the guise of Mentes-1 he joins the fight round the corpse of Patroclus Il. 17.75 , he strips the corpse 122, 125 , and assumes the armour 188, Apollo in the guise of Phaenops-3 urges him on 582; the corpse is rescued by the Greeks Il. 18.231; he spurns the advice of Poulydamas to retire to the city Il. 18.285; on the advice of Apollo shrinks from Achilles Il. 20.379 , but advances to meet him on seeing the wounded Polydorus-1 419, Apollo snatches Hector away 443; he awaits Achilles under the walls in spite of the entreaty of his father Il. 22.35, and of his mother 79, he flees before Α. 136, Athene in the guise of Deiphobus beguiles him 226, Achilles wounds him fatally 326, his dying speech 356; Achilles drags his corpse to the ships Il. 22.395; he drags the corpse thrice daily round the grave-mound of Patroclus Il. 24.14 ; Priam bears the ransomed corpse to the city Il. 24.689, the lament of Andromache 725, the lament of Hecabe 748, the lament of Helen 762 , the funeral of Hector 785; etc.
Ἔλασος Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.696.
Ἔλατος-1 Trojan. killed by Agamemnon Il. 6.33.
Ἔλατος-2. A suitor. Killed by Eumaeus Od. 22.267.
Ἐλατρεύς A Phaeacian Od. 8.111 , 129.

Ἑλένη (Ἀργείη, δῖα γυναικῶν , Διὸς ἐκγεγαυῖ, εὐπατέρεια , ἠΰκομος, καλλίκομος , καλλιπάρῃος, κούρη Διός , λευκώλενος, ῥιγεδανή , τανύπεπλος). Daughter of Leda by Zeus (nominally by Tyndareus), wife of Menelaus (but carried off by Paris) and mother by Menelaus of Hermione-1. Summoned by Iris to the walls to view the duel between Paris and Menelaus Il. 3.121, the Trojan elders see her and what they said 146, she names the Greek leaders to Priam 161, cannot see her brothers Castor-1 and Polydeuces 234; summoned by Aphrodite to Paris Il. 3.383; Hector finds her with Paris Il. 6.323, her conversation with Η. 343; her lament over Hector Il. 24.761; etc.: Hermione-1 her only child Od. 4.12; her conversation at Sparta with Menelaus and Peisistratus Od. 4.121 , her soothing drug 219, she tells how Odysseus came disguised to Troy 235; her gift to Telemachus on his departure Od. 15.100, her speech to him 123; Penelope on her infatuation Od. 23.218; etc.
Ἕλενος-1 (ἄναξ). Patronymic Πριαμίδης. Son of Priam and Hecabe. Skilled in auguries Il. 6.76; Il. 7.44 Il. 12.94, Il. 13.576 , 582, 758, 770, 781, Il. 24.249.
Ἕλενος-2 Greek. Patronymic Οἰνοπίδης . Killed by Hector Il. 5.707.
Ἐλεφήνωρ (κρείων, ὄζος Ἄρηος ). Patronymic Χαλκωδοντιάδης. Leader of the Abantes Il. 2.540. Killed by Agenor Il. 4.463.
Ἐλεών A Boeotian town Il. 2.500, Il. 10.266.
Ἑλικάων Trojan. (κρείων). Patronymic Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor and husband of Laodice-1 Il. 3.123 .
Ἑλίκη (εὐρεῖα). A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.575; a seat of the worship of Poseidon Il. 8.203.
Ἑλικώνιος Adj. from prec. Il. 20.404.

Ἑλλάς (εὐρύχορος, καλλιγύναιξ ). Part of the realm of Peleus, the valley of the Spercheius Il. 2.683, Il. 9.395, 447 , 478, Il. 16.595: Od. 11.496. Of northern in contrast to southern Greece, in phrase καθʼ (ἀνʼ) Ἑλλάδα καὶ μέσον Ἄργος. See Argos-1 (3).
Ἕλληνες The men of prec. (1). Applied with Μυρμιδόνες and Ἀχαιοί to the followers of Achilles Il. 2.684.
Ἑλλήσποντος (ἀγάρροος, ἀπείρων , ἰχθυόεις, πλατύς ). The Hellespont Il. 2.845, Il. 7.86, Il. 9.360 , Il. 12.30, Il. 15.233, Il. 17.432, Il. 18.150, Il. 23.2, Il. 24.346, 545 : Od. 24.82.
Ἑλλοί See Σελλοί.
Ἕλος-1 (ἔφαλον πτολίεθρον). A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.584.
Ἕλος-2. A town of Pylus Il. 2.594 .
Ἐλπήνωρ A comrade of Odysseus in his ship. Killed by mishap at Circe's house Od. 10.552; his shade begs for funeral rites Od. 11.51, 57; the funeral Od. 12.10.
Ἐνεταί Probably a Paphlagonian port Il. 2.852.
Ἐνιῆνες Greek. A people of northern Thessaly led by Gouneus Il. 2.749.
Ἐνιπεύς (θεῖος). A river of Thessaly rising in Mt. Othrys and flowing into the Peneius Od. 11.238, 240.
Ἐνίσπη (ἠνεμόεσσα). A town of Arcadia Il. 2.606.
Ἔννομος-1 (οἰωνιστής). A leader of the Mysians Il. 2.858, Il. 17.218. Killed by Achilles Il. 2.860.
Ἔννομος-2 Trojan. killed by Odysseus Il. 11.422.
Ἐνόπη A town of Pylus Il. 9.150 , 292.

Ἐνυάλιος (ἀνδρειφόντης, κορυθάϊξ πτολεμιστής). A name of Ares Il. 2.651 , Il. 7.166, Il. 8.264, Il. 13.519, Il. 17.259, Il. 20.69, Il. 22.132. An epithet of Ares Il. 17.211. War or battle personified Il. 18.309.
Ἐνυεύς King of Scyrus-2 Il. 9.668.
Ἐνυώ (πότνια, πτολίπορθος ). A female counterpart of Ares (Euyalius) Il. 5.333, 592.
Ἐξάδιος A warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.264.
Ἐπάλτης Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.415.
Ἐπειγεύς (δῖος). A Myrmidon, son of Agaclees Il. 16.571 . Came as a suppliant to Peleus and Thetis Il. 16.573. Killed by Hector Il. 16.577.

Ἐπειοί Greek. (μεγάθυμοι, φαιδιμόεντες , χαλκοχίτωνες). The people of Elis Il. 2.619, Il. 4.537, Il. 11.688, 694, 732, 737, 744, Il. 13.686, 691, Il. 15.519, Il. 23.630, 632: Od. 13.275, Od. 15.298, Od. 24.431.
Ἐπειός (δῖος, ἠύς τε μέγας τε , μεγάθυμος). Son of Panopeus-2. Wins the boxing-match Il. 23.665, 689, 694; is last in putting the weight Il. 23.838, 839: made the Trojan horse Od. 8.493, Od. 11.523 .
Ἐπήριτος The name assumed by Odysseus in his tale to Laertes Od. 24.306.
Ἐπίδαυρος (ἀμπελόεις). A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.561.
Ἐπικάστη The later Iocaste (καλή). Mother and wife of Oedipodes (Oedipus). Her incestuous marriage and suicide Od. 11.271.
Ἐπικλέης Trojan. (μεγάθυμος). Killed by Aias-1 Il. 12.379.
Ἐπίστροφος-1 Son of Iphitus-1. With his brother Schedius-1 leader of the men of Phocis Il. 2.517.
Ἐπίστροφος-2 (ἐγχεσίμωρος). Son of Euenus and brother of Mynes Il. 2.692.
Ἐπίστροφος-3. A leader of the Halizonians Il. 2.856.
Ἐπίστωρ Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.695.
Ἑπτάπορος An unknown river Il. 12.20.

Ἔρεβος Genit. Ἐρέβευς Il. 8.368 : Od. 11.37. Abl. Ἐρέβεσφιν Il. 9.572. The underworld, the realm of Hades Il. 8.368, Il. 9.572, Il. 16.327: Od. 10.528, Od. 11.37, 564, Od. 12.81. Ἔρεβόσδε [-δε], to Erebos, Od. 20.356.
Ἐρεμβοί A people, otherwise unknown, visited by Menelaus Od. 4.84.
Ἐρετμεύς A Phaeacian Od. 8.112 .
Ἐρευθαλίων (δῖος, ἰσόθεος). An Arcadian slain in the armour of Areithous-1 (given to him by Lycourgus-2 (Il. 7.137 , 149)) by Nestor in his youth Il. 4.319, Il. 7.136 , 154.
Ἐρεχθεύς (μεγαλήτωρ). An autochthonous hero of Athens Il. 2.547: Od. 7.81.
Ἐρινύς See Lexicon.
Ἔρις See ἔρις 4 in Lexicon.
Ἐριφύλη (στυγερή). Wife of Amphiaraus. Bribed by a golden necklace persuaded Amphiaraus to take part in the expedition of the Seven against Thebes-1 Od. 11.326, Od. 15.247.
Ἐριχθόνιος Son of Dardanus-1, father of Trus-1, and grandfather of Ilus-1, Assaracus and Ganymedes Il. 20.219, 230.
Ἐριῶπις Wife of Oeleus-1, mother of Aias-2 and stepmother of Medon-1 Il. 13.697, Il. 15.336.
Ἕρμαιος λόφος. An eminence above the city of Ithaca Il. 16.471.

Ἑρμείας Ἑρμῆς Il. 20.72 : Od. 5.54, Od. 8.334, Od. 14.435, Od. 24.1. Dat. Ἑρμέᾳ Il. 5.390 (ἀκάκητα, ἄναξ, ἀργεϊφόντης, διάκτορος (ἀ.) , ἐΰσκοπος ἀ., κρατὺς ἀ. , δώτωρ ἑάων, ἐριούνης , ἐριούνιος, Κυλλήνιος , σῶκος, χρυσόρραπις ). Son of Zeus and Maia, and father of Eudorus by Polymele. The sceptre given by him to Pelops Il. 2.104; rescues Ares from bonds Il. 5.390; sent by Zeus to conduct Priam to the ships Il. 24.334, rouses Priam and urges him to return 679; etc. : sent by Zeus to bid Calypso let Odysseus go Od. 5.28, his conversation with Il. 14.85; meets Ο. on his way to Circe's house Od. 10.277 ; conducts the souls of the suitors to the Shades Od. 24.1; etc.
Ἑρμιόνη-1 (ἐρατεινή). Only child of Menelaus and Helen Od. 4.14. Her marriage to Neoptolemus Od. 4.5.
Ἑρμιόνη-2. A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.560.
Ἕρμος (δινήεις). A river flowing near Sardis and into the Aegean Il. 20.392 .
Ἐρυθῖνοι (ὑψηλοί). Probably cliffs bordering Cape Carambis in Paphlagonia Il. 2.855 .
Ἐρυθραί A Boeotian town Il. 2.499.
Ἐρύλαος Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.411.
Ἐρύμανθος A mountain range in northwest Peloponnesus Od. 6.103.
Ἐρύμας-1 Trojan. killed by Idomeneus Il. 16.345.
Ἐρύμας-2 Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.415.
Ἐτεοκληείη βίη Ἐτεοκλῆς. King of Thebes-1, son of Oedipodes and Epicaste Il. 4.386.
Ἐτεόκρητες (μεγαλήτορες). Etymologically, 'the true Cretans.' In Odysseus's tale to Penelope applied to one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.176.
Ἐτεωνεύς (κρείων). Patronymic Βοηθοΐδης. θεράπων of Menelaus at Sparta Od. 4.22, 31, Od. 15.95.:
Ἐτεωνός (πολύκνημος). A Boeotian town Il. 2.497.
Εὐαιμονίδης Patronymic from next. Of Eurypylus-2 Il. 5.76, Il. 11.810.
Εὐαίμων Father of Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.736, Il. 5.79, Il. 7.167, Il. 8.265, Il. 11.575.
Εὐάνθης Father of Maron Od. 9.197 .
Εὔβοια (ἱερή). The island Euboea Il. 2.535; the home of the Abantes Il. 2.536: Od. 3.174; Od. 7.321 (see Ῥαδάμανθυς, Τιτυός).
Εὔδωρος (ἀρήϊος, θείειν ταχὺς ἠδὲ μαχητής, παρθένιος). Son of Hermes and Polymele. A leader under Achilles Il. 16.179, 186.
Εὐηνίνη Patronymic of Marpessa Il. 9.557.
Εὐηνορίδης Patronymic of Leocritus Od. 2.242, Od. 22.294.
Εὐηνός (ἄναξ). Patronymic Σεληπιάδης. Father of Mynes and Epistrophus-2 Il. 2.693.
Εὔιππος Trojan. Killed by Patroclus Il. 16.417.

Εὔμαιος (δῖος, ὄρχαμος ἀνδρῶν ). Odysseus's swineherd (συβώτης, συφορβός , ὑφορβός). Son of Ctesius.
