Athene directs Odysseus to go to his dwelling Od. 13.404; the dwelling described Od. 14.5, receives Ο. 29; Odysseus tells him his tale Od. 14.192; he tells Odysseus his tale Od. 15.403; receives Telemachus Od. 16.11; is dispatched to tell Penelope of Telemachus's safe arrival 130, returns 452; accompanies Odysseus to the town Od. 17.200, they encounter Melantheus 212, they reach the city 260; he enters Odysseus's house first Od. 17.324; summons Odysseus to Penelope Od. 17.551 ; leaves the house to return to his own Od. 17.604; returns to Odysseus 's house Od. 20.162; sets down the bow etc. before the suitors for the contest Od. 21.80, Odysseus tests him 188, he pledges himself to support Il. 15.203, Odysseus reveals himself 207; he carries the bow to Odysseus that Odysseus may take part in the contest Od. 21.359; during the fight he and Philoetius seize Melantheus in the θάλαμος Od. 22.178, ranges himself by Odysseus for the final fight 201, slays Elatus-2 267 , is wounded by Ctesippus 279, slays Polybus-5 284 ; takes part in the slaying of the unfaithful maids Od. 22.454 ; accompanies Odysseus to the country Od. 23.366; at Laertes) house when Odysseus comes to it Od. 24.363, prepares to fight the oncoming suitors 497, but Athene stops the fight 528; etc.
Εὐμήδης (κῆρυξ θεῖος). Father of Dolon Il. 10.314, 412, 426.

Εὔμηλος (ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν, κρείων ). Patronymic Φηρητιάδης. Son of Admetus and Alcestis and husband of Iphthime. Leader of the men of Pherae, etc. Il. 2.714; his fine horses reared by Apollo Il. 2.764; takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.289, his chariot disabled by Athene 391, comes in last 532, but is awarded an extra prize 558; etc.: married Iphthime Od. 4.798.
Εὔνηος Patronymic Ἰησονίδης Son of Ieson and Hypsipyle. Sent wine to the Greeks from Lemnos Il. 7.468; purchased Lycaon-2 Il. 21.41, Il. 23.747.
Εὐπείθης Father of Antinous Od. 1.383; leads a section of the Ithacans to attack Odysseus Od. 24.422 , 465, 469, killed by Laertes 523; etc.
Εὐρυάδης A suitor. Killed by Telemachus Od. 22.267.

Εὐρύαλος-1 (ἰσόθεος φώς). Patronymic Μηκιστηϊάδης. Son of Mecisteus-1 and companion of Diomedes Il. 2.565; slays Dresus, Opheltius-1, Aesepus-2 and Pedasus-3 Il. 6.20; beaten in boxing by Epeius Il. 23.677.
Εὐρύαλος-2 (βροτολοιγῷ ἶσος Ἄρηϊ). Patronymic Ναυβολίδης-2. A Phaeacian. The fairest after Laodamas-2 Od. 8.115; Od. 8.127, 140; taunts Odysseus Od. 8.158, they are reconciled 396, 400 .
Εὐρυβάτης-1 (ὀτρηρός). A herald of Agamemnon. Sent with Talthybius to bring away Briseis Il. 1.320.
Εὐρυβάτης-2 (Ἰθακήσιος). A herald who accompanied Odysseus to Troy Il. 2.184, Il. 9.170: Od. 19.247.
Εὐρυδάμας-1 (ὀνειροπόλος γέρων). Father of A bas and Polyidus-1 Il. 5.149.
Εὐρυδάμας-2. A suitor. His gift to Penelope Od. 18.297. Killed by Odysseus Od. 22.283.
Εὐρυδίκη Daughter of Clymenus and wife of Nestor Od. 3.452.

Εὐρύκλεια (περίφρων, φίλη τροφός ). Odysseus's nurse, daughter of Ops. Puts Telemachus to bed Od. 1.429; in charge of the stora-room Od. 2.347, Telemachus bids her prepare provisions for his voyage 348; she encloses the maids while Odysseus and Telemachus remove the arms Od. 19.15; washes Odysseus Od. 19.357, recognizes his scar 392, 467 ; encloses the maids before the fight Od. 21.380; enumerates the unfaithful maids Od. 22.419; brings sulphur Od. 22.480; tells Penelope of Odysseus's return and the slaughter of the suitors Od. 23.1; etc.

Εὐρύλοχος (θεοειδής, μεγαλήτωρ ). A comrade of Odysseus in his ship. Leads one half of the ship's company to Circe's house Od. 10.205, remains when the others enter 232, tells their fate 244, follows Odysseus to the house 447; at the sacrifice on the borders of Oceanus Od. 11.23; with Perimedes-2 binds Odysseus more firmly at the Sirens' island Od. 12.195 ; insists on landing at the island of the oxen of the Sun Od. 12.278; etc.

Εὐρύμαχος (θεοειδής, πεπνυμένος ). Son of Polybus-2. With Antinous leader of the suitors. In the Ithacan assembly threatens Halitherses Od. 2.177 ; Penelope urged to marry him Od. 15.17; falsely comforts Penelope Od. 16.434; his gift to Penelope Od. 18.295; abuses the disguised Odysseus Od. 18.349, throws a stool at him 387; cannot string the bow Od. 21.245; addresses Odysseus on the slaying of Antinous Od. 22.44; heads the suitors Od. 22.69, slain by Odysseus Ο. Od. 22.81; etc.
Εὐρυμέδουσα Chamber-maid of Alcinous Od. 7.8.
Εὐρυμέδων-1 Son of Ptolemaeus and chariot-driver of Agamemnon Il. 4.228 .
Εὐρυμέδων-2 (ἀγαπήνωρ). Chariot-driver of Nestor Il. 8.114, Il. 11.620.
Εὐρυμέδων-3 (υεγαλήτωρ). King of the Gigantes and father of Periboea-2 Od. 7.58 .
Εὐρυμίδης Patronymic of Telemus Od. 9.509.
Εὐρυνόμη-1. Daughter of Oceanus. She and Thetis kept Hephaestus secretly when he was rejected by Hera Il. 18.398, 399, 405.
Εὐρυνόμη-2 (θαλαμηπόλος, ταμίη ). Odysseus's house-keeper Od. 17.495, Od. 18.164, 169, 178, Od. 19.96, 97, Od. 20.4, Od. 23.154, 289, 293.
Εὐρύνομος A suitor, son of Aegyptius-1 Od. 2.22, Od. 22.242.
Εὐρύπυλος-1. His city, i.e. Cos Il. 2.677.

Εὐρύπυλος-2 (ἀγαπήνωρ, ἀγλαός , διογενής). Patronymic Εὐαιμονίδης. Son of Euaemon and leader of the men of Ormenium, etc. Il. 2.736 ; slays Hypsenor-1 Il. 5.76, 79, and Melanthius-2 Il. 6.36; accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 7.167; Il. 8.265; comes to the rescue of Aias-1 and slays Apisaon-1 Il. 11.576 , 580; wounded by Paris Il. 11.583, 592, 662, 809, 819, 822, Il. 16.27; is tended by Patroclus Il. 11.838, Il. 12.2, Il. 15.392, 399.

Εὐρύπυλος-3. Patronymic Τηλεφίδης. Son of Telephus by Astyoche, daughter of Priam. Killed by Neoptolemus, his mother having been bribed by Priam with a golden vine to induce him to go to Troy Od. 11.520.
Εὐρυσθεύς Son of Sthenelus-2. By contrivance of Hera born before Heracles, who thus became subject to him Il. 8.363, Il. 15.639, Il. 19.123, 133.
Εὐρυτίδης Patronymic from Εὔρυτος-1. Of Iphitus-2 Od. 21.14, 37.
Εὐρυτίων (ἀγακλυτός). A centaur. Punished in the house of Peirithous by the Lapiths Od. 21.295.

Εὔρυτος-1 (μέγας). Father of Iphitus-2. The ruler of Oechalia Il. 2.596, 730: skilled with the bow Od. 8.224; challenged Apollo to a contest with the bow and was slain by him Od. 8.226; left his bow to his son Od. 21.32.
Εὔρυτος-2. See Ἀκτορίων, Μολίων-2 . Son (with Cteatus) of Poseidon (Il. 11.751 ). Father of Thalpius Il. 2.621. See also Il. 11.709, 750 , Il. 23.638 under Κτέατος .
Ἐΰσσωρος Father of Acamas-2 Il. 6.8.
Εὔτρησις A Boeotian town Il. 2.502.
Εὔφημος Son of Troezenus and leader of the Cicones Il. 2.846.
Εὐφήτης (ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν). Gave Phyleus a breastplate Il. 15.532.

Εὔφορβος (ἐϋμμελίης). Patronymic Πανθοΐδης. Son of Panthous. Wounds Patroclus Il. 16.808, 850; bids Menelaus. quit Patroclus's body Il. 17.12; will avenge the slaying by Menelaus of his brother Hyperenor Il. 17.34. Killed by Menelaus Il. 17.45, 59, 81.
Εὐχήνωρ Greek. Son of Polyidus-2. Killed by Paris Il. 13.663.
Ἐφιάλτης (κρατερός, τηλεκλειτός ). Son of Poseidon (nominally of Aloeus) and Iphimedeia. See Ὦτος-1.
Ἐφύρη-1 A town on the Selleis-2, the home of Astyocheia Il. 2.659 , Il. 15.531.
Ἐφύρη-2. A town of Argos-1 (3), the home of Sisyphus Il. 6.152, 210.
Ἐφύρη-3 (πίειρα ἄρουρα). A city or district, perhaps in Thesprotia, the seat of Ilus-2 Od. 1.259, Od. 2.328 .
Ἔφυροι A people represented as warred on by Ares Il. 13.301.
Ἐχεκλέης (κρατερός). Patr Ἀκτορίδης. Husband of Polymele Il. 16.189.
Ἔχεκλος-1 Trojan. Son of Agenor. Killed by Achilles Il. 20.474.
Ἔχεκλος-2 Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.694.
Ἐχέμμων Son of Priam (his mother not named). With his brother Chromius-2 killed by Diomedes Il. 5.160.
Ἐχένηος A Phaeacian elder Od. 7.155, Od. 11.342.
Ἐχέπωλος-1 Trojan. Patronymic Θαλυσιάδης . Killed by Antilochus Il. 4.458.
Ἐχέπωλος-2. Patronymic Ἀγχισιάδης-2. Gave Agamemnon the mare Aethe to escape service Il. 23.296.
Ἔχετος (βροτῶν δηλήμων πάντων). A mythical destructive king Od. 18.85, 116, Od. 21.308.
Ἐχέφρων (δῖος). Son of Nestor Od. 3.413 , 439.
Ἐχῖναι νῆσοι (ἱεραί). The Echinean Islands, represented as lying off Elis Il. 2.625.
Ἐχίος-1. Father of Mecisteus-2 Il. 8.333, Il. 13.422.
Ἐχίος-2 Greek. Killed by Polites-1 Il. 15.339.
Ἐχίος-3 Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.416.

Ζάκυνθος (ὑλήεις, ὑλήεσσα ). The mod. Zante. An island forming part of the realm of Odysseus Il. 2.634. In Od. associated with Doulichium, Same and Ithaca Od. 1.246, Od. 9.24, Od. 16.123, 250, Od. 19.131.
Ζέλεια (ἱερή). A town of the Troad on the Aesepus-1 Il. 2.824, Il. 4.103, 121.

Ζεύς Genit. Ζηνός 408, Il. 11.795, Il. 12.235, Il. 13.449, etc. : Od. 1.27, Od. 2.68, Od. 4.74, etc. Dat. Ζηνί 49, Il. 4.1, Il. 7.443, etc.: Od. 4.78, Od. 9.552. Acc. Ζῆνα 756, Il. 8.22, Il. 14.157, etc.: Od. 20.339, Od. 24.472. Ζῆν 206, Il. 14.265, Il. 24.331. Voc. Ζεῦ 503, Il. 2.371, Il. 3.298, Il. 5.421, etc.: Od. 1.62, Od. 4.341, Od. 5.7, Od. 7.331, etc. Genit. Διός 5, Il. 2.26, Il. 3.107, Il. 4.128, etc.: Od. 1.10, Od. 2.296, Od. 3.42, Od. 4.27, etc. Dat. Διί 419, Il. 2.102, Il. 3.104, Il. 4.23, etc.: Od. 4.472, Od. 7.164, Od. 8.432, etc. Acc. Δία 394, Il. 2.2, Il. 5.419, etc. : Od. 14.389, 406, Od. 20.75. Διόθεν [>-θεν], from Zeus Il. 24.194, 561. By his power or will Il. 15.489. (ἀθάνατος, αἰγίοχος , ἄναξ, ἀργικέραυνος , ἄριστος, ἀστεροπητής , ἐριβρεμέτης, ἐρίγδουπος , ἐρισθενής, εὐρύοπα , Ἰδαῖος, ἱκετήσιος , καταχθόνιος, κελαινεφής , κρείων, κύδιστος , μέγας, μέγιστος, Ἴδηθεν (Δωδώνης) μεδέων, μητίετα, αἰθέρι ( τηλόθι) ναίων, νεφεληγερέτα, ξείνιος, ξένιος, Ὀλύμπιος, πανομφαῖος, πατήρ, π. ἀνδρῶν τε θεῶν τε , στεροπηγερέτα, τελεσφόρος , τερπικέραυνος, ὕπατος , ὕ. κρειόντων, ὑπερμενής , ὑψιβρεμέτης, ὑψίζυγος , ὑψόθ' ἐών.) Patronymic Κρονίδης, Κρονίων. The supreme god, son of Cronus and Rhea, brother of Poseidon, Hades, Hera and Demeter, and husband (and brother) of Hera. Father (1) by Hera of Ares, Hebe and Hephaestus; (2) by Leto of Apollo and Artemis; (3) by Dione of Aphrodite; (4) by Semele of Dionysus; (5) by Maia of Hermes; (6) by Demeter of Persephoneia; (7) by Europa (daughter of Phoenix-2) of Minos and Rhadamanthys; (8) by Leda of Helen; (9) by Alcmene of Heracles; (10) by Laodameia of Sarpedon; (11) by Danae of Perseus-1; (12) by Antiope of Amphion-2 and Zethus; (13) by Dia of Peirithous; and (14) by unnamed mothers of Athene , Dardanus-1, Aeacus and Tantalus. Father also of Ate Il. 19.91; of the river Xanthus-1 Il. 14.434; of the Muses Il. 2.491 , 598: Od. 8.488; of nymphs Il. 6.420: Od. 6.105 , Od. 9.154, Od. 13.356, Od. 17.240; of Λιταί 502. Protector of heralds. See under κῆρυξ in Lex. And of strangers, beggars and suppliants Od. 6.207, Od. 9.270, etc. See also ξείνιος 1, ξένιος 2 in Lex. His scales. See τάλαντον 1 in Lex. His thunderbolts Il. 8.133, Il. 21.198, etc.: Od. 5.128, Od. 12.415, etc. Sender of rain Il. 12.25, etc.: Od. 9.111, etc. Of snow Il. 10.5, Il. 12.279 , Il. 19.357. Of winds Il. 12.252, Il. 13.795, etc. : Od. 9.67, Od. 15.297, etc. And of the rainbow Il. 11.27, Il. 17.547. By lot (Il. 15.187, 192) got the heavens and the upper air as his realm (but he is called καταχθόνιος 457). The attempt of Hera, Athene and Poseidon to put him in bonds Il. 1.399; Thetis goes to him on behalf of Achilles Il. 1.493, his promise to her 518; sends Oneirus to beguile Agamemnon Il. 2.8; sends Athene to induce the Trojans to break the truce Il. 4.70; with threats forbids the assembled gods to help either side Il. 8.1; sends a thunderbolt which falls before the chariot of Diomedes Il. 8.133; sends an omen to comfort Agamemnon Il. 8.247; sends Iris to turn back Hera and Athene Il. 8.399; sends Eris to encourage the Greeks Il. 11.3; sends Iris to Hector with advice Il. 11.185; beguiled and lulled to sleep by Hera Il. 14.292, his rage when he awakes Il. 15.4; summons Iris and Apollo Il. 15.54, sends her to bid Poseidon retire from the fight 158, and him to aid Hector 221; debates with himself as to Sarpedon's fate Il. 16.433, resolves on his death 458, charges Apollo with his funeral rites 667; Hera tricked him in the matter of the birth of Heracles Il. 19.95, his rage thereat 125; sends Athene to comfort Achilles Il. 19.342 ; summons an assembly of the gods Il. 20.4, allows the gods to take sides in the fight 20; pities Hector's plight Il. 22.168, but allows Athene to go to the assistance of Achilles 183; sends Thetis to Achilles to induce him to give up Hector's corpse Il. 24.104 , and Iris to Priam to bid him go to the ships and ransom the corpse 144 , sends Hermes to aid Il. 17.334, etc. : speaks of Aegisthus to the assembled gods Od. 1.31; sends an eagle as a good omen to Telemachus Od. 2.146; sends Hermes to bid Calypso let Odysseus go Od. 5.29, Od. 7.261; thunders as a good sign to Odysseus Od. 20.103; gives his voice for peace between Odysseus and his people Od. 24.478, and sends a thunderbolt to stop the fighting 539; etc.

data.ref: 192) got the heavens and the upper air as his realm (but he is called
Od. 24.478, and sends a thunderbolt to stop the fighting

definition: Ζῆθος (ἄναξ). Son of Zeus and Antiope. With his brother Amphion-2 represented as having founded Thebes-1 Od. 11.262; Od. 19.523 (see also Πανδάρεος).

Ἥβη (καλλίσφυρος, πότνια ). Daughter of Zeus and Hera. Acts as cup-bearer to the gods Il. 4.2; helps Hera to prepare a chariot Il. 5.722; tends Ares when cured of his wound Il. 5.905: Heracles her husband Od. 11.603.

Ἠέλιος Ἥλιος Od. 8.271 (ἀκάμας, παμφανάων , τερψίμβροτος, Ὑπερίων, Ὑπεριονίδης, φαέθων, φαεσίμβροτος). The Sun, father by Perse of Aeetes and Circe Od. 10.138, and by Neaera of Phaethousa and Lampetie Od. 12.132 . Brings to Hephaestus news of his dishonour by Ares Od. 8.271; his oxen Od. 1.8, Od. 12.128 , they are killed by the companions of Odysseus 353. See further in Lexicon.
Ἠερίβοια (περικαλλής). Stepmother of (apparently) Otus-1 and Ephialtes. Her rescue of Ares Il. 5.389.

Ἠετίων-1 (μεγαλήτωρ). King of Thebe-2 and father of Andromache. His city taken by Achilles and himself slain Il. 1.366, Il. 6.416, Il. 9.188, Il. 16.153; Il. 6.395, 396, Il. 8.187, Il. 22.472, 480, Il. 23.827.
Ἠετίων-2. A Trojan, father of Podes Il. 17.575, 590.
Ἠετίων-3. An Imbrian. Ransomed Lycaon-2 Il. 21.43.
Ἠϊόνες A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.561.
Ἠϊονεύς-1 Greek. Killed by Hector Il. 7.11 .
Ἠϊονεύς-2. Father of Rhesus-1 Il. 10.435.
Ἠλεῖοι The people of Elis Il. 11.671.
Ἥλιος See Ἠέλιος.
Ἦλις (δῖα, εὐρύχορος, ἱππόβοτος). A town and country in the north west extremity of the Peloponnesus Il. 2.615, 626, Il. 11.673, 686, 698: Od. 4.635, Od. 13.275, Od. 15.298, Od. 21.347, Od. 24.431.
Ἠλύσιον πεδίον. See Lexicon.
Ἠλώνη A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.739.
Ἠμαθίη (ἐρατεινή). A district adjoining Pieria Il. 14.226.
Ἠνιοπεύς Son of Thebaeus-1. Chariot-driver to Hector. Killed by Diomedes Il. 8.120.
Ἠνοπίδης Patronymic from next. Of Satnius Il. 14.444 .
Ἦνοψ-1. Father of Satnius by a naiad Il. 14.445; and father also of Thestor Il. 16.401.
Ἦνοψ-2. Father of Clytomedes Il. 23.634.
Ἠπυτίδης Patronymic of Periphas-2 Il. 17.324.

Ἡρακλέης Ἡρακλῆς (θεῖος, θρασυμέμνων θυμολέων, κρατερός, κρατερόφρων, μεγάλων ἐπιίστωρ ἔργων , μένος αἰὲν ἀτειρής). Son of Alcmene by Zeus (nominally by Amphitryon) Il. 14.324 : Od. 11.267. Father of Tlepolemus-1 by Astyocheia Il. 2.658 , 666; father also of Thessalus Il. 2.679: husband of Hebe Od. 11.603. His birth delayed by contrivance of Hera, whereby he became subject to Eurystheus Il. 19.95, Il. 15.640; wounded Hera with an arrow Il. 5.392; being wronged by Laomedon sacked Troy Il. 5.638, his return thence hindered by Hera Il. 14.249, 266, Il. 15.25; carried off the dog of Hades Il. 8.366: Od. 11.623; vexed Pylus Il. 11.690 ; the wall built for him against the sea monster Il. 20.145 ; his fate Il. 18.117: Od. 8.224 ; his phantom in the Shades Od. 11.601; killed Iphitus-2 Od. 21.26.
Ἡρακλεΐδης Patronymic from prec. Of Tlepolemus-1 Il. 2.653, Il. 5.628. Of Thessalus Il. 2.679.
Ἡρακλήειος Adj. from Ἡρακλέης. βίη Ἡρακλείη, Ἡρακλέης 658, 666, Il. 5.638, Il. 11.690, Il. 15.640, Il. 19.98: Od. 11.601. So βίη Ἡρακλῆος 117.
Ἡρακλῆς See Ἡρακλέης.

Ἥρη (Ἀργείη, βοῶπις, Διὸς κυδρὴ παράκοιτις, ἠΰκομος , θεά, λευκώλενος, πότνια, πρέσβα θεά, χρυσόθρονος, χρυσοπέδιλος ). Daughter of Cronus and Rhea, sister of Zeus , Hades, Poseidon and Demeter, and wife (and sister) of Zeus. For her children see under Ζεύς. Reared by Oceanus and Tethys Il. 14.200, 302. She suspects the promise of Zeus to Thetis Il. 1.536; reproaches Zeus for favouring the Trojans Il. 4.20, they come to terms 31; she urges Athene to the fray Il. 5.711, prepares a chariot 720, consults Zeus 753, conveys Athene to the field 767; urges Athene again to the field Il. 8.350, they are stopped by Iris sent by Zeus 413; arrays herself to beguile Zeus Il. 14.166, gets the aid of Aphrodite 188, and of Sleep 231, the beguilement 292, Zeus wakens Il. 15.4 , and sends her to summon Iris and Apollo 54; how she tricked Zeus in the matter of the birth of Heracles Il. 19.95; summons Hephaestus to quell Xanthus-1 Il. 21.328 ; in the Battle of the Gods assaults Artemis Il. 21.489; etc. : Od. 4.513, Od. 8.465 , Od. 11.604, Od. 12.72, Od. 15.112, 180, Od. 20.70.

Ἥφαιστος (ἀμφιγυήεις, ἄναξ , κλυτοεργός, κλυτοτέχνης , κυλλοποδίων, περικλυτός , πολύμητις, πολύφρων , χαλκεύς). Son of Zeus and Hera. Husband in Il. (Il. 18.382) of Charis, in Od. (Od. 8.267) of Aphrodite . His lameness Il. 18.394, Il. 20.36, etc. : Od. 8.308, etc. His craftsmanship Il. 1.607, Il. 14.166, Il. 18.417, 468, etc.: Od. 8.272, etc. Persuades his mother to conciliate Zeus Il. 1.571; his fall from Olympus Il. 1.590; made Agamemnon's sceptre Il. 2.101, and the breastplate of Diomedes Il. 8.195, and the aegis Il. 15.310; Thetis goes to beg him for armour for her son Il. 18.369, which he makes 468 ; he tells how Eurynome-1 and Thetis tended him when rejected by Hera Il. 18.394; Hera summons him to quell Xanthus-1 Il. 21.330 ; etc. : Od. 4.617, Od. 6.233 , Od. 7.92; Demodocus tells how Ares and Aphrodite deceived him and how he punished them Od. 8.266 , 270, 286, 287, 293, 297, 327, 330, 345, 355, 359; Od. 15.117, Od. 23.160, Od. 24.71, 75. See also in Lex.

Ἠώς (δῖα, ἐΰθρονος, ἐϋπλόκαμος, ἠριγένεια, κροκόπεπλος, ῥοδοδάκτυλος , χρυσόθρονος). The Dawn. Wife of Tithonus and mother of Memnon. Carried off Orion Od. 5.121, and Cleitus-2 Od. 15.250. See also ἠώς 5 in Lexicon.
Θάλεια A Nereid Il. 18.39 .
Θάλπιος See Ἀκτορίων. Son of Eurytus-2 and grandson of Poseidon. A leader of the Epeians Il. 2.620.
Θαλυσιάδης Patronymic of Echepolus-1 Il. 4.458.
Θάμυρις A Thracian bard deprived by the Muses at Dorium of his power of song Il. 2.595.
Θάνατος See Lexicon.
Θαυμακίη A town of uncertain site in the realm of Philoctetes Il. 2.716.

Θεανώ (δῖα, καλλιπάρῃος ). Patronymic Κισσηΐς. Daughter of Cisses (Il. 11.224), wife of Antenor, mother of Iphidamas and priestess at Troy of Athene . Brought up Pedaeus Il. 5.70; opens Athene's temple for the aged women Il. 6.298, 302.
Θέμις See θέμις 7 in Lexicon.

Θεοκλύμενος (θεοειδής, μάντις ). Son of Polypheides and great-grandson of Melampus. In flight from Argos-1 (1) encounters Telemachus embarking for home at Pylus Od. 15.223, 256, 271, is taken on board 286, asks as to his disposal 508, announces a good omen 529, is committed to the care of Peiraeus 540; his prediction to Penelope Od. 17.151; his vision among the suitors Od. 20.350, he leaves the suitors 363.

data.ref: 529, is committed to the care of

definition: Θερσίλοχος Trojan. A Paeonian Il. 17.216 . Killed by Achilles Il. 21.209.
Θερσίτης A deformed Greek described Il. 2.212. Abuses Agamemnon Il. 2.225, Odysseus deals with him 244, 246.
Θέσπεια A Boeotian town Il. 2.498.
Θεσπρωτοί The inhabitants of Thesprotia, a part of Epeirus extending southeast from the Thyamis Od. 14.315, 316, 335, Od. 16.65, 427, Od. 17.526, Od. 19.271, 287, 292.
Θεσσαλός Patronymic Ἡρακλεΐδης. Son of Heracles and father of Pheidippus and Antiphus-1 Il. 2.679 .
Θεστορίδης-1. Patronymic of Calchas Il. 1.69.
Θεστορίδης-2. Patronymic of Alcmaon-1 Il. 12.394.
Θέστωρ Trojan. Son of Enops-1. Killed by Patroclus Il. 16.401.

Θέτις (ἁλοσύδνη, ἀργυρόπεζα , ἠΰκομος, θεά, καλλιπλόκαμος, τανύπεπλος ). Daughter of the ἅλιος γέρων (Nereus) Il. 1.556. Wife of Peleus and mother of Achilles. Comes when called upon by Achilles on his loss of Briseis Il. 1.357 , Achilles reminds her how she saved Zeus from bonds 396, she promises to induce Zeus to favour the Trojans 413, goes to him and gets his promise 495; received Dionysus when terrified by Lycourgus-1 Il. 6.136 ; the chest given by her to Achilles Il. 16.222; comes to Achilles on the death of Patroclus Il. 18.35 , promises him armour from Hephaestus 127, goes to Η. 369, how Eurynome-1 and she preserved Η. 398, she brings away the armour 616, and gives it to Achilles Il. 19.3; summoned by Zeus Il. 24.74 , and sent to bid Achilles release Hector's corpse 104, etc. : appears and takes part in the funeral rites of Achilles Od. 24.47, the jar given by her to receive Achilles's bones 73, the prizes given by her for his funeral games 85, 92.

data.ref: 104, etc. : appears and takes part in the funeral rites of Achilles

definition: Θῆβαι-1 Θήβη-1 Il. 4.378, 406, Il. 14.323, Il. 19.99: Od. 11.263, 265, 275 (ἑπτάπυλος, εὐρύχορος , ἐϋστέφανος, ἱερὰ τείχεα , πολυήρατος). The Boeotian city, traditionally said to have been founded by Cadmus (represented as having been founded by Amphion-2 and Zethus Od. 11.262) Il. 4.378, 406, Il. 5.804, Il. 6.223, Il. 10.286, Il. 14.114, 323, Il. 19.99: Od. 11.263, 265, 275, Od. 15.247. Θήβασδε [-δε], to Thebes-1 Il. 23.679 .
Θῆβαι-2 (ἑκατόμπυλοι). The city of Upper Egypt Il. 9.381: Od. 4.126.
Θηβαῖος-1 (ὑπέρθυμος). Father of Eniopeus Il. 8.120.
Θηβαῖος-2. Adj. from Θῆβαι-1. Of Teiresias Od. 10.492, 565, Od. 11.90 , 165, Od. 12.267, Od. 23.323.
Θήβη-1. See Θῆβαι-1.

Θήβη-2 Θῆβαι-3 Il. 22.479 (ἱερή, ὑποπλακίη, ὑψίπυλος). A town (inhabited by the Cilices), of which Eetion-1 was king, in the plain of Thebe-2 in which Adramyttium afterwards stood. Taken by Achilles and Eetion-1 slain and Chryseis captured Il. 1.366, Il. 2.691, Il. 6.397, 416; Il. 22.479 .

Θησεύς (ἐπιείκελος ἀθανάτοισιν, ἐρικυδής). Patronymic Αἰγεΐδης. Son of Aegeus, king of Athens, and husband of Phaedra. The great legendary hero of Athens. Named as a warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.265: carried off Ariadne from Crete Od. 11.322; Od. 11.631.
Θίσβη (πολυτρήρων). A Boeotian town Il. 2.502.

Θόας-1 (Αἰτωλός). Patronymic Ἀνδραιμονίδης. Son of Andraemon and leader of the Aetolians Il. 2.638 ; slays Peiroos Il. 4.527 , 529; accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 7.168; Il. 13.92; Poseidon takes his guise Il. 13.216, 222, 228; Thoas advises the chiefs to stand up to Hector, sending the general body back Il. 15.281; Il. 19.239: in Odysseus's tale to Eumaeus and his companions Od. 14.499.
Θόας-2 (θεῖος). King of Lemnos Il. 14.230, Il. 23.745.
Θόας-3 Trojan. killed by Menelaus Il. 16.311.
Θόη A Nereid Il. 18.40 .
Θόων-1 Trojan. Son of Phaenops-1. With his brother Xanthus-3 killed by Diomedes Il. 5.152.
Θόων-2 Trojan. killed by Odysseus Il. 11.422.
Θόων-3 Trojan. Il. 12.140. Killed by Antilochus Il. 13.545.
Θόων-4. A Phaeacian Od. 8.113 .
Θόωσα (νύμφη). A nymph, daughter of Phorcys-2 and by Poseidon mother of Polyphemus-1 Od. 1.71 .
Θοώτης (δῖος). A Greek herald Il. 12.342, 343 .
Θρασίος Trojan. A Paeonian. Killed by Achilles Il. 21.210.

Θρασυμήδης (ἀντίθεος, δῖος, ἱππόδαμος, κυδάλιμος, μενεπτόλεμος, ποιμὴν λαῶν , ὑπέρθυμος). Patronymic Νεστορίδης. Son of Nestor Il. 9.81 , Il. 10.255, Il. 14.10; slays Maris Il. 16.321 ; Il. 17.378, 705: Od. 3.39, 414, 442, 448.
Θρασύμηλος Trojan. (ἀγακλειτός). Killed by Patroclus Il. 16.463.
Θρηΐκιος Thracian Il. 10.559 , Il. 13.13, 577, Il. 23.230, 808.

Θρῆϊξ Θρῇξ. Thracian Il. 2.595 . Θρήϊκες, Θρῇκες Τ (ἀκρόκομοι, ἱπποπόλοι ). The Thracians Il. 2.844 , Il. 4.519, 533, 537, Il. 5.462, Il. 6.7, Il. 10.434, 464, 470, 487, 506, 518, Il. 13.4, Il. 14.227, Il. 24.234.
Θρῄκη (ἐριβῶλαξ, μήτηρ μήλων ). Thrace Il. 11.222, Il. 13.301, Il. 20.485. Θρῄκηθεν [-θεν], from Thrace Il. 9.5, 72. Θρῄκηνδε [-δε], to Thrace Od. 8.361.
Θρινακίη Epithet or the name of the island containing the oxen of the Sun Od. 11.107, Od. 12.127, 135, Od. 19.275.
Θρόνιον A Locrian town Il. 2.533.
Θρύον (Ἀλφειοῖο πόρος). A town of Pylus Il. 2.592 , apparently identical with Θρυόεσσα (αἰπεῖα κολώνη) Il. 11.711 .
Θυέστης Θυέστα Il. 2.107 (πολύαρνι). Son of Pelops, brother of Atreus and father of Aegisthus. The sceptre left to him by Atreus and by him to Agamemnon Il. 2.106 , 107: his dwelling Od. 4.517 .
Θυεστιάδης Patronymic from prec. Of Aegisthus Od. 4.518.
Θυμβραῖος Trojan. killed by Diomedes Il. 11.320.
Θύμβρη A town on the Scamander Il. 10.430.
Θυμοίτης A Trojan elder Il. 3.146 .
Θῶν An Egyptian, husband of Polydamna Od. 4.228 .
Ἴαιρα A Nereid Il. 18.42 .
Ἰάλμενος Son of Ares and Astyoche. A leader of the men of Orchomenus-1, etc. Il. 2.512, Il. 9.82.
Ἰαμενός (ι) Trojan. Il. 12.139 . Killed by Leonteus Il. 12.193.
Ἰάνασσα A Nereid Il. 18.47 .
Ἰάνειρα A Nereid Il. 18.47 .
Ἰάονες Greek. (ἑλκεχίτωνες). The Ionians Il. 13.685 (apparently identified with the Athenians 689).
Ἰάπετος (ῑ). A Titan. In Tartarus Il. 8.479 .
Ἰάρδανος-1. An unknown river, apparently on the borders of Pylus and Arcadia Il. 7.135 .
Ἰάρδανος-2. A river of northern Crete Od. 3.292.
Ἰασίδης-1 (ῑ). See Δμήτωρ.
Ἰασίων (ῑ). Demeter's love for him and his death by lightning Od. 5.125.
Ἴασος-1 (ῑ). Son of Sphelus and a leader of the Athenians. Killed by Aeneas Il. 15.332, 337.
Ἴασος-2 (ῑ). Ἴασον Ἄργος, of doubtful origin, apparently denoting all southern Greece (Argos-1 (3)) Od. 18.246.
Ἰαωλκός (ἐϋκτιμένη, εὐρύχορος ). A town of the realm of Eumelus at the head of the Pagasaean Gulf Il. 2.712: was the home of Pelies Od. 11.256.

Ἰδαῖος-1 (ῑ) (δαΐφρων, πεπνυμένος ). A Trojan herald. Summons Priam to take the oath to the Greeks Il. 3.248; with Talthybius stops the fight between Aias-1 and Hector Il. 7.276, 278, 284; sent to carry Paris's proposal to the Greeks Il. 7.372, 381, 405, 406, 413, 416; accompanies Priam to the ships Il. 24.281, 325, 470.
Ἰδαῖος-2 (ῑ) (μάχης εὖ εἰδὼς πάσης). Son of Dares. With his brother Phegeus attacks Diomedes Il. 5.11, is saved by Hephaestus 20.
Ἰδαῖος-3 (ῑ). Adj. from next. Il. 8.170, Il. 11.196, Il. 12.19, Il. 15.79, Od. 3.189, etc. Of Zeus Il. 16.605 , Il. 24.291.

Ἴδη (ῑ) (μήτηρ θηρῶν, πιδήεσσα , πολυπῖδαξ, πολύπτυχος , ὑλήεσσα, ὑψηλή). A mountain of the Troad with many branches Il. 2.821, 824, Il. 8.47, 75, 207, Il. 11.105, 112, 183, 337, Il. 13.13, Il. 14.157, 162, 283, 287, 293, 307, 332, Il. 15.5, 146, 151, 255, Il. 17.594, Od. 3.59, 91, 218, Il. 21.449, 559, Il. 22.171, Il. 23.117. Ἴδηθεν [-θεν], from Ida Il. 4.475, Il. 8.397 , 438. Apparently as genit. : Ἱ. μεδέων 276=320=Il. 7.202=Il. 24.308.
Ἴδης (ι). Husband of Marpessa and father of Cleopatra Il. 9.558 . Fought with Apollo for Marpessa Il. 9.559.

Ἰδομενεύς (ι) (ἀγαπήνωρ, ἀγαυός , ἀγὸς ἀνδρῶν, ἀγακλυτός , ἄναξ, ἀρήϊος, ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, δαΐφρων, δουρικλυτός, μεσαιπόλιος ). Son of Deucalion-1 and leader of the Cretans Il. 2.645; described by Helen to Priam Il. 3.230; visited by Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.252; accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 7.165; Poseidon reproaches him Il. 13.219, he urges Meriones to the fight 249, slays Othryoneus 363, slays Asius-2 384 , slays Alcathous 424 , fights Aeneas 500 ; slays Erymas-1 Il. 16.345; strikes Hector Il. 17.605, retreats to the ships 624; while watching the chariot-race is abused by Aias-2 Il. 23.474; etc.: brought his surviving comrades safe home Od. 3.191; in Odysseus's tale to Athene Od. 13.259, in Odysseus's tale to Eumaeus Od. 14.237, in Eumaeus's comment 382, and in Odysseus 's tale to Penelope Od. 19.181 , 190.
Ἰηλυσός A town of Rhodes Il. 2.656.
Ἰησονίδης Patronymic from next. Of Euneus Il. 7.468 , 471, Il. 23.747.
Ἰήσων (ποιμὴν λαῶν). The Argonaut, father by Hypsipyle of Euneus Il. 7.469, Il. 21.41: Od. 12.72.
Ἰθαιμένης Father of Sthenelaus Il. 16.586.

Ἰθάκη mod. Ithaki (ἀμφίαλος, εὐδείελος , ἐϋκτιμένη, κραναή , παιπαλόεσσα, πίων δῆμος , τρηχεῖα, ὑπονήϊος ). The island home of Odysseus, containing the mountain Neritum (Neium) Il. 2.632, Il. 3.201: Od. 1.18, Od. 2.167, Od. 3.81; its condition described Od. 4.605; its position Od. 9.22; Od. 11.111, Od. 13.97; its features pointed out by Athene to Odysseus Od. 13.344 ; Od. 14.98, Od. 15.36, Od. 16.419, Od. 17.250, Od. 19.399, Od. 20.340, Od. 21.18, Od. 22.30, Od. 23.176, Od. 24.104, etc. Ἰθάκης πόλις (ἄστυ) Od. 10.416, Od. 18.2, Od. 22.223. πόλις alone Od. 1.185 , Od. 15.37, Od. 24.205, etc. ἄστυ alone Od. 2.77, Od. 17.25, Od. 22.77, etc. Associated with Doulichium, Same and Zacynthus Od. 1.247, Od. 9.21 , Od. 16.124, 251, Od. 19.132. Ἰθάκηνδε [-δε], to Ithaca Od. 1.163, Od. 11.361, Od. 15.157, Od. 16.322. See also Ἀρέθουσα, Κόρακος πέτρη.
Ἰθακήσιος Adj. from Ἰθάκη, Ithacan Il. 2.184 : Od. 2.246, Od. 22.45. In pl., the Ithacans Od. 2.25, 161, 229, Od. 15.520, Od. 24.354, 443, 454, 531.
Ἴθακος With Neritus and Polyctor-2 constructed a fountain above the city of Ithaca Od. 17.207 .
Ἰθώμη (κλωμακόεσσα). A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Podaleirius and Machaon Il. 2.729.
Ἰκάριος-1 πόντος) [ι]. A part of the Aegean south of Icaria and Samos, said to be named from Icarus, son of Daedalus, who fell into it from the air Il. 2.145.
Ἰκάριος-2 (μεγαλήτωρ). Father of Penelope and Iphthime Od. 1.329, Od. 2.53, 133, Od. 4.797, etc.
Ἱκεταονίδης Patronymic from next. Of Melanippus-2 Il. 15.546.
Ἱκετάων (ὄζος Ἄρηος). Son of Laomedon and father of Melanippus-2 Il. 3.147 , Il. 15.576, Od. 3.238.
Ἰκμάλιος Made Penelope's κλισίη 57.
Ἰλήϊος (ι). Adj. from an unknown Ἰλεύς. The Ileian plain cannot be identifed Od. 21.558.
Ἴλιον See Ἴλιος.
Ἰλιονεύς (ῑ) (ἀγαυός). Only son of Phorbas-2. Killed by Peneleos Il. 14.489, 492, 501.

Ἴλιος (ι), Ἴλιον (ι) Il. 15.71 (αἰπεινή, αἰπύ, ἐρατεινή, ἐϋκτίμενον (εὖ ναιόμενον) πτολίεθρον, εὔπωλος, εὐτείχεος, ἠνεμόεσσα, ἱρή, ὀφρυόεσσα). Another name for Τροίη 1 Il. 1.71, Il. 2.113, Il. 4.33, Il. 7.20, Il. 11.196, Il. 14.46, Il. 18.58, Il. 23.64, etc. : Od. 2.18, Od. 8.495, Od. 11.86, Od. 14.71, Od. 17.104, Od. 24.117, etc. For Ἰλιόθεν and for Ἰλιόθι as locative and Ἰλιόφι as genit. see Lexicon.
Ἶλος-1 (ι). Patronymic Δαρδανίδης. Son of Trus-1 and father of Laomedon. His tomb Il. 10.415, Il. 11.166, 372, Il. 24.349 ; Od. 3.232, 236 .
Ἶλος-2. Patronymic Μερμερίδης. A ruler of Ephyra-3 represented as having command of poisons Od. 1.259.
Ἰμβρασίδης Patronymic of Peiroos Il. 4.520.
Ἴμβριος-1 (αἰχμητής). Son of Mentor-1. From Pedaeum. Husband of Medesicaste. Killed by Teucrus Il. 13.171, 197.
Ἴμβριος-2. Adj. from next. Il. 21.43.
Ἴμβρος (παιπαλόεσσα). An island lower in height than Samothrace between Samothrace and Troy and northwest of Tenedos Il. 13.33, Il. 14.281, Il. 24.78, 753.
Ἰνώ (ι), called also Λευκοθέη (καλλίσφυρος). Daughter of Cadmus. Made immortal Od. 5.334; comes to the aid of Odysseus when his raft is shattered Od. 5.333, 461.
Ἰξιόνιος Adj. from Ἰξίων. (Wife) of Ixion. Of Dia (see Πειρίθοος ) Il. 14.317.
Ἱππασίδης-1. Patronymic from Ἵππασος. Of Charops and Socus Il. 11.426, 431.
Ἱππασίδης-2. Patronymic of Hypsenor-2 Il. 13.411.
Ἱππασίδης-3. Patronymic of Apisaon-2 Il. 17.348.
Ἵππασος (δαΐφρων ἱππόδαμος). Father of Charops and Socus Il. 11.450.
Ἱππημολγοί (ἀγαυοί). An unknown race described as living on (mare's) milk Il. 13.5 .
Ἱπποδάμας Trojan. killed by Achilles γ> 401.
Ἱπποδάμεια-1 (κλυτός). Wife of Peirithous and mother of Polypoetes Il. 2.742 .
Ἱπποδάμεια-2. The eldest and the fairest and most skilful of the daughters of Anchises. Wife of Alcathous Il. 13.429.
Ἱπποδάμεια-3 A handmaid of Penelope Od. 18.182.
Ἱππόδαμος Trojan. Killed by Odysseus Il. 11.335.

Ἱππόθοος-1 Trojan. (φαίδιμος). Son of Lethus. A leader of the Pelasgians (1) Il. 2.840, 842; Il. 17.217; tries to drag off the body of Patroclus Il. 17.289. Killed by Aias-1 Il. 17.293; Il. 17.313, 318 .
Ἱππόθοος-2 A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.251.
Ἱπποκόων (ἐσθλός). Cousin of Rhesus-1 Il. 10.518.
Ἱππόλοχος-1 Son of Bellerophon, grandson of Glaucus-1 and father of Glaucus-2 Il. 6.119 , 144, 197, 206, Il. 7.13, Il. 12.309, 387, Il. 17.140.
Ἱππόλοχος-2 Trojan. (μενεχάρμης). Son of Antimachus. With his brother Peisandrus-1 killed by Agamemnon Il. 11.122 , 145.
Ἱππόμαχος Trojan. Son of Antimachus. Killed by Leonteus Il. 12.189.
Ἱππόνοος Greek. (μενεχάρμης). Killed by Hector Il. 11.303.
Ἱπποτάδης Patronymic of Aeolus Od. 10.2, 36.
Ἱπποτίων Trojan. Father of Ascanius and Morys Il. 13.792. Killed by Meriones Il. 14.514.
Ἱρή (ποιήεσσα). A town of Pylus Il. 9.150 , 292.

Ἶρις (ἀελλόπος, θεά, (πόδας) ὠκέα, ποδήνεμος, ταχεῖα, χρυσόπτερος). The messenger of the gods. Comes to the Trojans from Zeus Il. 2.786; calls Helen to the walls Il. 3.121; leads Aphrodite from the fray Il. 5.353; sent by Zeus to stop Hera and Athene Il. 8.398; sent by him to encourage Hector Il. 11.185; summoned by him Il. 15.55, and sent to cause Poseidon to retire 157; sent by Hera to Achilles Il. 18.166 ; summons the winds to the pyre of Patroclus Il. 23.198; summons Thetis to Zeus Il. 24.77; sent by Zeus to Priam Il. 24.143; etc.

Ἶρος Apparently masc. form of prec.; the nickname of Arnaeus. A beggar employed as a messenger by the young men in Ithaca. His fight with Odysseus Od. 18.6, 25, 38, 56, 73 (Ἶρος Ἄϊρος, that will soon be Irus no more), 75, 96, 233, 239, 333, 334, 393.
Ἴσανδρος (ι.) Son of Bellerophon Il. 6.197; killed fighting with the Solymi Il. 6.203.
Ἴσμαρος The town of the Cicones Od. 9.40, 198.
Ἶσος Bastard son of Priam Il. 11.101. See Ἄντιφος-3
Ἱστίαια (πολυστάφυλος). A town of Euboea Il. 2.537.
Ἴτυλος Od. 19.522. See Πανδάρεος.
Ἰτυμονεύς (ι) (ἐσθλός). Patronymic Ὑπειροχίδης. An Eleian slain by Nestor in his youth Il. 11.672.
Ἴτων (μήτηρ μήλων). A town in the realm of Protesilaus Il. 2.696.
Ἰφεύς (ι) Trojan. Killed by Patroclus Il. 16.417.
Ἰφθίμη Daughter of Icarius-2, sister of Penelope and wife of Eumelus. Appears to Penelope in a dream Od. 4.797.
Ἰφιάνασσα (ι). Daughter of Agamemnon Il. 9.145, 287.

Ἰφιδάμας (ι) T (ἠΰς τε μέγας τε). Patronymic Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor and Theano ; brought up in Thrace by his maternal grandfather Cisses and married a sister of Theano Il. 11.221. Killed by Agamemnon Il. 11.234; Il. 11.257, 261 .
Ἰφικλήειος (ι). Adj. from next. βίη Ἰφικληείῆ next. His oxen and Melampus Od. 11.290, 296.
Ἴφικλος-1 (ι) (πολύμηλος). Patronymic Φυλακίδης. Son of Phylacus-2 and father of Protesilaus and Podarces Il. 2.705, Il. 13.698. See also prec.
Ἴφικλος-2 (ι) Nestor beat him in a foot-race Il. 23.636.
Ἰφιμέδεια (ι). Wife of Aloeus and by Poseidon mother of Otus-1 and Ephialtes Od. 11.305.
Ἰφίνοος (ι) Greek. Patronymic Δεξιάδης . Killed by Glaucus-2 Il. 7.14.
Ἶφις (ὲΰζωνος). When Achilles took Scyrus-2 given by him to Patroclus Il. 9.667 .
Ἰφιτίδης (ι). Patronymic of Archeptolemus Il. 8.128.
Ἰφιτίων (ι) Trojan. Patronymic Ὀτρυντεΐδης. Son of Otrynteus and a naiad. Killed by Achilles Od. 3.382.
Ἴφιτος-1 (ι) (μεγάθυμος). Patronymic Ναυβολίδης-1 Father of Schedius-1 and Epistrophus-1 Il. 2.518, Il. 17.306.

Ἴφιτος-2 (ι) (ἐπιείκελος ἀθανάτοισιν). Patronymic Εὐρυτίδης. Son of Eurytus-1. Inherited his father's bow Od. 21.32; met Odysseus in the house of Orsilochus-3 in Messene Od. 21.14, when he was seeking for lost horses 22 (though his and his father's home is stated to have been in Oechalia, far from Messene (see Εὔρυτος-1)); gave Odysseus his father's bow Od. 21.31. Killed by Heracles Od. 21.24, 37.

data.ref: Od. 21.14, when he was seeking for lost horses
22 (though his and his father's home is stated to have been in

definition: Καβησός The home of Othryoneus of unknown site Καβησόθεν [-θεν], from Cabesus Il. 13.363.
Καδμεῖοι (κέντορες ἵππων). The Thebans (see Κάδμος) Il. 4.388, 391 , Il. 5.807, Il. 10.288: Od. 11.276.
Καδμεΐωνες =prec. Il. 4.385, Il. 5.804 , Il. 23.680.
Κάδμος Traditional founder of Thebes-1 (but see under Θῆβαι-1). Father of Ino and Semele Od. 5.333.
Κάειρα A Carian woman Il. 4.142 .
Καινεΐδης Patronymic from next. Of Coronus Il. 2.746 .
Καινεύς Father of Coronus. A warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.264.
Κακοΐλιος 'Evil Ilius.' Apparently formed by Penelope Od. 19.260 , 597, Od. 23.19.
Καλήσιος Charioteer of Axylus. Killed by Diomedes Il. 6.18.
Καλητορίδης Patronymic of Aphareus Il. 13.541.
Καλήτωρ Trojan. Son of Clytius-1. Killed by Aias-1 Il. 15.419.
Καλλιάνασσα A Nereid Il. 18.46 .
Καλλιάνειρα A Nereid Il. 18.44 .
Καλλίαρος A Locrian town Il. 2.531.
Καλλικολώνη A hill or mound on the Trojan plain of uncertain site Od. 3.53, 151.
Καλύδναι A group of Aegean islands, part of the Sporades Il. 2.677 .
Καλυδών (αἰπεινή, ἐραννή, πετρήεσσα). A town of Aetolia Il. 2.640; the scene of the strife of the Couretes and the Aetolians Il. 9.530 , 531, 577; Il. 13.217, Il. 14.116.

Καλυψώ (δεινὴ θεὰ (αὐδήεσσα), δῖα (θεάων), δολόεσσα, ἠΰκομος, ἐϋπλόκαμος, νύμφη, πότνια). Daughter of Atlas; dwelt in the Ogygian island. Odysseus reaches her island and is detained by her there Od. 12.448; Od. 1.14 , Od. 4.557, Od. 5.14, Od. 7.245, 254, Od. 21.452, Od. 9.29, Od. 12.389, Od. 17.143, Od. 23.333; at the bidding of Hermes sent by Zeus she dispatches him to Phaeacia Od. 5.78, 85, 116, 180, 202, 242, 246, 258, 263, 276, 321, 372, Od. 7.260.

Κάλχας (οἰωνοπόλων ὄχʼ ἄριστος). Patronymic Θεστορίδης-1. The chief Greek seer. Having invoked the protection of Achilles against Agamemnon Il. 1.69, 86, declares Apollo's purpose Il. 1.92, Agamemnon's reply Il. 1.105105; Calchas's prophecy at Aulis Il. 2.300, 322; Il. 13.45, 70.
Κάμειρος (ἀργινόεις). A town of Rhodes Il. 2.656.
Καπανεύς (ἀγακλειτός, κυδάλιμος ). Father of Sthenelus-1 Il. 2.564, Il. 4.403, Il. 5.319.
Καπανηϊάδης Patronymic from prec. Of Sthenelus-1 Il. 5.109.
Καπανήϊος Adj. from Καπανεύς. Of Sthenelus-1 Il. 4.367, Il. 5.108, 241 .
Κάπυς Son of Assaracus and father of Anchises Od. 3.239.
Καρδαμύλη A town of Pylus Il. 9.150 , 292.
Κᾶρες Trojan. (βαρβαρόφωνοι). The Carians, a people of southwest Asia Minor about the Maeander Il. 2.867, Il. 10.428.
Κάρησος An unknown river Il. 12.20.
Κάρυστος A town of Euboea Il. 2.539.
Κάσος An Aegean island, one of the Sporades Il. 2.676.

Κασσάνδρη (Πριάμοιο θυγατρῶν εἶδος ἀρίστη, ἰκέλη χρυσέῃ Ἀφροδίτη). Daughter of Priam and Hecabe. Sought in marriage by Othryoneus Il. 13.366; was the first to see her father approaching with Hector's corpse Il. 24.699: her murder Od. 11.422.
Καστιάνειρα (καλή, δέμας ἐϊκυῖα θεῇσιν ). Married from Aesyme. Mother by Priam of Gorgythion Il. 21.305 .

Κάστωρ-1 (ἰππόδαμος, κρατερόφρων ). Son of Tyndareus and Leda, brother of Polydeuces and Clytaemnestra and half-brother of Helen. Helen misses him and his brother Polydeuces from the Greek host Il. 3.237. The alternate immortality of Castor and Polydeuces Od. 11.300.
Κάστωρ-2. Patronymic Ὑλακίδης. An alleged noble of Crete said by Odysseus in his tale to Eumaeus to be his father Od. 14.204.
Καύκωνες An unknown people on the Trojan side Il. 10.429, Od. 3.329.
Καύκωνες (μεγάθυμοι) A people said to be in debt to Mentor-2 Od. 3.366.
Καΰστριος A river flowing by Ephesus and into the Aegean Il. 2.461.
Κεάδης Patronymic of Troezenus Il. 2.847.

Κεβριόνης (δαΐφρων). Bastard son of Priam. Acts as chariot-driver to Hector Il. 8.318, Il. 11.521, Il. 12.91, 92, Il. 16.727; Il. 13.790. Killed by Patroclus Il. 16.738, the fight over his body 751, 754, 756, 759, 772, 781.
Κελάδων (ὠκύροος). An unknown river, apparently on the borders of Pylus and Arcadia Il. 7.133 .

Κένταυροι called also Φῆρες Il. 1.268 , Il. 2.743 (λαχνήεντες, ὀρεσκῷοι ). A savage race (but see Χείρων) apparently inhabiting the regions about Pelion (Il. 2.744, Il. 16.143, Il. 19.390). Contrasted with ἄνδρες Od. 21.303. Fought with by Nestor in his youth Il. 1.268; through the evil acts of Eurytion punished by Peirithous Il. 2.743 : Od. 21.295, 303. In sing., of Eurytion Od. 21.295.
Κεφαλλῆνες Greek. (μεγάθυμοι). Etymologically the people of Cephallenia (Same). The general name of the peoples over whom Odysseus ruled Il. 2.631, Il. 4.330 ; Od. 20.210, Od. 24.355 , 378, 429.
Κήρινθος (ἔφαλος). A town of Euboea Il. 2.538.
Κήτειοι A Mysian people Od. 11.521.
Κηφισίς λίμνη= Lake Copais Il. 5.709 .
Κηφισός (δῖος). A river of Phocis Il. 2.522, 523 .
Κίκονες Trojan. (αἰχμηταί). A Thracian people dwelling under Mt. Ismarus Il. 2.846, Il. 17.73: their town Ismarus raided by Odysseus Od. 9.39, 47, 59, 66, 165, Od. 23.310.

data.ref: Il. 17.73: their town Ismarus raided by

definition: Κίλικες The inhabitants of Thebe-2 Il. 6.397, 415.
Κίλλα (ζαφέη). Probably at the head of the Gulf of Adramyttium Il. 1.38, 452.
Κιμμέριοι A people dwelling in darkness on the borders of Oceanus. Visited by Odysseus Od. 11.14.
Κινύρης Of Cyprus. His gift of a breastplate to Agamemnon Il. 11.20.

Κίρκη (ἀθανάτη, Αἰαίη, δεινὴ θεὸς αὐδήεσσα, ἐϋπλόκαμος , πολυφάρμακος, πότνια ). Daughter of Eelius and Perse and sister of Aeetes. Her island reached by Odysseus and his surviving comrades Od. 10.135, half the force led by Eurylochus to her house 203, all but Eurylochus turned by her into swine 233, Odysseus proceeds to the house 261, Hermes meets and instructs him 275, he is not affected by Circe's enchantments 314, his transformed comrades restored 388, he brings his other comrades from the ship 406; after a year Circe dispatches him and his comrades to the Shades 488; she receives them on their return Od. 12.16, gives directions for their further voyage 37, they leave the island 144; etc.
Κισσηΐς Patronymic from next. Of Theano Il. 6.299 .
Κισσῆς Κισσεύς. Father of Theano and maternal grandfather of Iphidamas. Brought up Iphidamas in Thrace Il. 11.223.
Κλεῖτος-1 (ἀγλαός). Son of Peisenor-1 and comrade of Poulydamas. Killed by Teucrus Il. 15.445.
Κλεῖτος-2. Son of Mantius Od. 15.249; carried off by Eos Od. 15.250.
Κλεόβουλος Trojan. Killed by Aias-2 Il. 16.330.
Κλεοπάτρη (ἐΰζωνος, καλή). Called also Alcyone. Daughter of Ides and Marpessa and wife of Meleagrus Il. 9.556 , she prevails on Meleagrus to beat off the Couretes Il. 9.590.
Κλεωναί (ἐϋκτίμεναι). A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.570.
Κλονίος A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.495. Killed by Agenor Il. 15.340.
Κλυμένη-1 (βοῶπις). A handmaid of Helen at Troy Il. 3.144.
Κλυμένη-2. A Nereid Il. 18.47 .
Κλυμένη-3. Wife of Phylacus-2 and mother of Iphiclus-1 Od. 11.326 .
Κλύμενος Father of Eurydice Od. 3.452.

Κλυταιμνήστρη (δῖα, δολόμητις). Daughter of Tyndareus and Leda, sister of Castor-1 and Polydeuces, half-sister of Helen, and wife of Agamemnon , Agamemnon prefers Chryseis to her Il. 1.113: her treachery to Agamemnon and his murder and the murder of Cassandra Od. 3.266, Od. 11.409, 422 , 439, Od. 24.199.

data.ref: Il. 1.113: her treachery to Agamemnon and his murder and the murder of

definition: Κλυτίδης-1. Patronymic of Dolops-1 Il. 11.302.
Κλυτίδης-2. Patronymic from Κλυτίος-2. Of Peiraeus Od. 15.540.
Κλυτίος-1. Son of Laomedon and father of Caletor Il. 3.147, Il. 15.419, 427, Od. 3.238.
Κλυτίος-2. Father of Peiraeus Od. 16.327.
Κλυτομήδης Son of Enops-2. Nestor beat him at boxing Il. 23.634.
Κλυτόνηος (ἀμύμων, ἀντίθεος ). Son of Alcinous Od. 8.119, 123.
Κλῶθες See Lexicon.
Κνωσός (εὐρεῖα, μεγάλη πόλις ). The chief town of Crete Il. 2.646; Ariadne's dancing-floor there Il. 18.591: the seat of Minos Od. 19.178.
Κοίρανος-1 Trojan. killed by Odysseus Il. 5.677.
Κοίρανος-2. Chariot-driver to Meriones. Saves Meriones's life but loses his own Il. 17.611, 614.
Κοπρεύς Father of Periphetes-2. Carried orders to Heracles from Eurystheus Il. 15.639 .
Κόρακος πέτρη. A rock in Ithaca near the dwelling of Eumaeus and the spring Arethousa Od. 13.408 .
Κόρινθος (ἀφνειός). Corinth. In Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.570. Κορινθόθι [-θι], at Corinth Il. 13.664.
Κορώνεια A Boeotian town Il. 2.503.
Κόρωνος (ὑπέρθυμος). Patronymic Καινεΐδης. Son of Caeneus and father of Leonteus Il. 2.746.
Κουρῆτες A people, apparently neighbours of the Aetolians . They joined with them in hunting the Calydonian boar, but strife arose over the division of the spoils Il. 9.529, 532 , 549, 551, 589.
Κόων Trojan. (ἀριδείκετος ἀνδρῶν). Patronymic Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor. Avenging his brother Iphidamas wounds Agamemnon Il. 11.248 , Il. 19.53. Killed by Agamemnon Il. 11.256.
Κρανάη An island not identified Il. 3.445.
Κράπαθος Later Κάρπαθος, an Aegean island, one of the Sporades Il. 2.676.
Κράταιϊς Mother of Scylla Od. 12.124.
Κρειοντιάδης Patronymic from next. Of Lycomedes Il. 19.240.
Κρείων-1. Father of Lycomedes Il. 9.84.
Κρείων-2 (ὑπέρθυμος). King of Thebes-1 (not the same as the kinsman of Oedipus) and father of Megare Od. 11.269.
Κρηθεύς Patronymic Αἰολίδης. Husband of Tyro and father of Aeson, Pheres and Amythaon Od. 11.237, 258.
Κρήθων Son of Diocles. With his brother Orsilochus-4 killed by Aeneas Il. 5.542, 549.

Κρήτη Κρῆται Od. 14.199, Od. 16.62 (ἑκατόμπολις, εὐρεῖα , καλή, περίρρυτος , πίειρα). Crete Il. 2.649; the realm of Minos Il. 13.450, 453: Od. 3.191 , 291, Od. 11.323; in Odysseus's tale to Athene Od. 13.256, 260; in his tale to Eumaeus Od. 14.199, 252, 300, 301, Od. 16.62, Od. 17.523; in his tale to Penelope Od. 19.172, 338. Κρήτηνδε [-δε], to Crete Od. 19.186. Κρήτηθεν [-θεν], from Crete Il. 3.233.
Κρῖσα (ζαθέη). A town of Phocis Il. 2.520.
Κροῖσμος Trojan. killed by Meges Il. 15.523.
Κροκύλεια Apparently a town of Ithaca Il. 2.633.

Κρονίων Genit. Κρονίονος Il. 14.247 : Od. 11.620. Κρονίωνος Il. 21.184, 230: Od. 8.289. Dat. Κρονίωνι Il. 1.397, Il. 2.102, etc. Acc. Κρονίωνα Il. 1.502 , Il. 2.350, etc.: Od. 14.406 , Od. 24.472. Patronymic of next. Of Zeus Il. 1.528, Il. 2.419, Il. 5.753, Il. 6.267, Il. 7.194, Il. 21.175, etc.: Od. 1.386, Od. 3.88, Od. 4.207, Od. 10.21, etc.

Κρόνος (ἀγκυλομήτης, μέγας ). A Titan, son of Uranus and Ge, and by Rhea father of Zeus, Hades, Poseidon, Hera and Demeter Il. 2.205, Il. 4.59; in Tartarus Il. 21.479, Il. 14.203, 274 , Il. 15.225; his sons enumerated Il. 15.187; etc.: Od. 21.415.
Κρουνοί Χαλκίς-3. Places passed by Telemachus on his return from Pylus Od. 15.295 .
Κρῶμνα A Paphlagonian town Il. 2.855.

Κτέατος See Ἀκτορίων, Μολίων-2 . Son (with Eurytus-2) of Poseidon (Il. 11.751 ). Father of Amphimachus-1 Il. 2.621, Il. 13.185; in Nestor's tale of the fighting between the Pylians and the Epeians Il. 11.709, 750 ; at the funeral games of Amarynceus Il. 23.638.
Κτήσιος (ἐπιείκελος ἀθανάτοισιν). Patronymic Ὀρμενίδης. Named as ruler of the island Syria and father of Eumaeus Od. 15.414.

Κτήσιππος (ἀθεμίστια εἰδώς, φιλοκέρτομος). Patronymic Πολυθερσεΐδης. A suitor. Dwelt in Same Od. 20.288 ; throws an ox's foot at the disguised Odysseus Od. 20.292, 303, 304; wounds Eumaeus Od. 22.279, killed by Philoetius 285.
Κτιμένη (ἰφθίμη, τανύπεπλος ). Daughter of Laertes and Anticleia and sister of Odysseus Od. 15.363 .
Κύδωνες A people represented by Menelaus as dwelling by the Iardanus-2 Od. 3.292; in Odysseus's tale to Penelope one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.176.
Κυθέρεια See Ἀφροδίτη.
Κύθηρα τά (ζάθεα). An island off the southeast extremity of the Peloponnesus Il. 15.432: Od. 9.81. Κυθηρόθεν [-θεν], from Cythera Il. 15.438.
Κυθήριος Adj. from prec. Il. 10.268, Il. 15.431.

Κύκλωπες (ἀθέμιστοι, ὑπερηνορέοντες , ὑπερφίαλοι). A gigantic and savage race, represented (Od. 7.206) as being with the giants near the gods. Their manners described Od. 9.106; an island off their land described Od. 9.116; Odysseus lands on the island Od. 9.142; goes in his ship to visit the Cyclopes Od. 9.177; etc. See further under Πολύφημος-1.

data.ref: Od. 7.206) as being with the giants near the

definition: Κυλλήνη (ὄρος αἰπύ). A mountain of north Arcadia, sacred to Hermes Il. 2.603.
Κυλλήνιος-1. Adj. from prec. Of Hermes Od. 24.1 .
Κυλλήνιος-2. Adj. from Κυλλήνη, a town of Elis Il. 15.518.
Κυμοδόκη Κυμοθόη. Nereids Il. 18.39, 41.
Κῦνος A Locrian town Il. 2.531.
Κυπαρισσήεις A town of Pylus Il. 2.593 .
Κυπάρισσος A town of Phocis Il. 2.519.
Κύπρις Apparently from next. See Ἀφροδίτη.

Κύπρος Cyprus. Visited by Menelaus Od. 4.83; its town Paphos a seat of Aphrodite Od. 8.362 ; its king Dmetor (according to Odysseus) Od. 17.442 , 443; Od. 17.448. Κύπρονδε [-δε], to (i.e. from as far as) C. Il. 11.21.
Κύτωρος A Paphlagonian town Il. 2.853.
Κύφος A town of the Peraebians Il. 2.748.
Κώκυτος Πυριφλεγέθων. Rivers of the underworld flowing into the Acheron, the A. being a tributary of the Styx Od. 10.513, 514.
Κῶπαι A Boeotian town Il. 2.502.
Κῶς (εὖ ναιομένη). An Aegean island, one of the Sporades Il. 2.677. Κόωνδε [-δε], to C. Il. 14.255 Ο 28.
Λάας A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.585.
Λαέρκης-1. Patronymic Αἱμονίδης-2. Father of Alcimedon Il. 16.197, Il. 17.467.
Λαέρκης-2. A goldsmith at Pylus Od. 3.425.

Λαέρτης (μεγαλήτωρ, πεπνυμένος ). Only son of Arceisius, husband of Anticleia and father of Odysseus and Ctimene Od. 1.189, Od. 2.99 , Od. 4.111, Od. 8.18, Od. 14.9, Od. 15.353; his parentage and offspring Od. 16.118; Od. 22.185; Odysseus tries him Od. 24.226, he slays Eupeithes 520; etc.
Λαερτιάδης Patronymic from prec. Of Odysseus Il. 2.173 , Il. 3.200, Il. 4.358, Il. 19.185, etc.: Od. 5.203, Od. 9.19, Od. 12.378, Od. 16.104, Od. 18.348, Od. 22.339, etc.
Λαιστρυγονίη Fem. adj. = next Od. 10.82, Od. 23.318.

Λαιστρυγών Of or pertaining to the Laestrygonians, a gigantic and savage race visited by Odysseus. Of their king Od. 10.106, 199 . In pl., the Laestrygonians (ἴφθιμοι) Od. 10.119 . All Odysseus's ships but his own destroyed by them Od. 10.121.

Λακεδαίμων (δῖα, ἐρατεινή, εὐρύχορος, κητώεσσα, κοίλη) The realm of Menelaus in general Il. 2.581, Il. 3.239, 244, 443: Od. 4.1, Od. 21.13. The chief city (Sparta) Il. 3.387: Od. 3.326, Od. 4.313, 702, Od. 5.20, Od. 13.414, 440, Od. 15.1, Od. 17.121.
Λάμος See Ἀντιφάτης-2.
Λαμπετίδης Patronymic from Λάμπος-1. Of Dolops-2 Il. 15.526.
Λαμπετίη (νύμφη ἐϋπλόκαμος, τανύπεπλος). Daughter of Eelius and Neaera. With Phaethousa in charge of the oxen of the Sun Od. 12.132, 375.
Λάμπος-1 Trojan. Patronymic Λαομεδοντιάδης. Son of Laomedon and father of Dolops-2 Il. 3.147, Il. 15.526, Od. 3.238.
Λάμπος-2 (δῖος). One of Hector's horses Il. 21.185.
Λάμπος-3. One of the horses of the Dawn Od. 23.246.
Λαόγονος-1 Trojan. (θρασύς). Son of Onetor. Killed by Meriones Il. 16.604.
Λαόγονος-2 Trojan. Son of Bias-3. Killed by Achilles Od. 3.460.
Λαοδάμας-1 (ἀγλαός). Son of Antenor. Killed by Aias-1 Il. 15.516.
Λαοδάμας-2 (ἀγαθός, ἀγαπήνωρ , ἀμύμων). Son of Alcinous Od. 7.170, Od. 8.117, 119 , 130, 132, 141, 153, 207, 370.
Λαοδάμεια Daughter of Bellerophon and by Zeus mother of Sarpedon Il. 6.197, 198 ; slain by Artemis Il. 6.205.
Λαοδίκη-1. The fairest of the daughters of Priam and Hecabe and wife of Helicaon Il. 3.124, Il. 6.252.
Λαοδίκη-2. Daughter of Agamemnon Il. 9.145, 287.
Λαοδόκος-1 Trojan. (κρατερὸς αἰχμητής). Patronymic Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor Il. 4.87 .
Λαόδοκος-2 Greek. Il. 17.699.
Λαοθόη (κρείουσα γυναικῶν). Daughter of Altes and mother by Priam of Lycaon-2 and Polydorus-1 Il. 21.85, Il. 22.48.
Λαομεδοντιάδης Patronymic from next. Of Priam Il. 3.250 . Of Lampus-1 Il. 15.527.

Λαομέδων (ἀγαυός, ἀγήνωρ, ἀμύμων). Son of Ilus-1 and father of Priam, Tithonus , Lampus-1, Clytius-1 and Hicetaon, also of Boucolion (bastard). His horses Il. 5.269, Il. 23.348; wronged Heracles in a matter of horses Il. 5.640, 649; Il. 7.453; wronged Poseidon and Apollo Il. 21.443, 452.
Λαπίθαι (αἰχμηταί). A Thessalian race. Peirithous and Polypoetes of this race Il. 12.128, 181 (cf. Il. 2.743): strife between the Lapiths and the Centaurs Od. 21.297 .
Λάρισα (ἐριβῶλαξ). Probably a maritime town on the west of the southern Troad Il. 2.841, Il. 17.301.
Λειώδης A suitor, son of Oenops. The suitors' seer; abstained from evil. The first to try the bow Od. 21.144, 168; appeals to Odysseus for mercy Od. 22.310, but is slain 320 .
Λειώκριτος-1 Greek. Son of Arisbas and comrade of Lycomedes. Killed by Aeneas Il. 17.344.
Λειώκριτος-2. Patronymic Εὐηνορίδης. A suitor. Answers Mentor-2 in the assembly Od. 2.242. Killed by Telemachus Od. 22.294.
Λεκτόν A promontory (the south west termination of Mt. Ida) forming the south west angle of the Troad Il. 14.284.
Λέλεγες Trojan. (φιλοπτόλεμοι). The inhabitants of Pedasus-2 Il. 10.429, Od. 3.96, Il. 21.86.

Λεοντεύς (ἀντίθεος, βροτολοιγῷ ἶσος Ἄρηϊ, κρατερός, ὄζος Ἄρηος). A Lapith. Son of Coronus and with Polypoetes leader of the men of Argissa, etc. Il. 2.745 ; his defence with Polypoetes of the wall Il. 12.130, 188; is third in putting the weight Il. 23.837, 841.
Λεσβίς -ίδος. Adj. from next. Absol., a Lesbian woman Il. 9.129, 271.

Λέσβος (ἐϋκτιμένη). The Aegean island. The island (or more probably the town thereof) taken by Achilles Il. 9.129, 271; Il. 24.544; Od. 3.169, Od. 4.342, Od. 17.133. Λεσβόθεν [-θεν], from Lesbos Il. 9.664.
Λευκάς πέτρη. The White Rock by which Hermes led the shades of the suitors Od. 24.11.
Λευκοθέη Od. 5.334. See Ἰνώ.
Λεῦκος Greek. Killed by Antiphus-3 Il. 4.491.
Λήδη Wife of Tyndareus and by him mother of Castor-1, Polydeuces and Clytaemnestra Od. 11.298. Also, by Zeus, mother of Helen Il. 3.236.
Λῆθος Patronymic Τευταμίδης. A Pelasgian, father of Hippothous-1 and Pylaeus Il. 2.843, Il. 17.288.
Λήϊτος Son of Alectryon. A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.494; slays Phylacus-1 Il. 6.35; Il. 13.91; wounded by Hector Il. 17.601, 605.

Λῆμνος (ἀμιχθαλόεσσα, ἐϋκτιμένη , ἐϋκτίμενον πτολίεθρον, ἠγαθέη). The Aegean island, inhabited by the Sinties. Hephaestus's fall on to it Il. 1.593; Philoctetes left there Il. 2.722; Euneus sends wine from it to the Greeks Il. 7.467; Il. 21.230; its king Thoas-2 Il. 14.230; Hera encounters Ὕπνος there Il. 14.231, 281; Lycaon-2 sold into slavery there to Euneus Il. 21.40, 46, 58, 79; Il. 24.753: a seat of Hephaestus Od. 8.283 , 294, 301.
Ληόκριτος See Λειώκριτος 2.

Λητώ (Διὸς κυδρὴ παράκοιτις, ἐρικυδής, ἠΰκομος, καλλιπάρῃος). Mother by Zeus of Apollo and Artemis Il. 1.9, 36, Il. 5.447, Il. 14.327, Il. 16.849, Il. 19.413, Od. 3.40, 72; in the Battle of the Gods Hermes declines a fight with her Il. 21.497, 498 , 502; her revenge on Niobe Il. 24.607: Od. 6.106, Od. 11.318; Tityus laid violent hands on her Od. 11.580.
Ληώδης See Λειώδης.
Λιβύη Libya, a country in the north of Africa. Visited by Menelaus, described Od. 4.85; Od. 14.295.
Λικύμνιος (ὄζος Ἄρηος). Maternal uncle of Heracles, slain by Tlepolemus-1 Il. 2.663 .
Λίλαια A town of Phocis Il. 2.523.
Λιμνώρεια A Nereid Il. 18.41 .
Λίνδος A town of Rhodes Il. 2.656.

Λοκροί Greek. The (Epicnemidian and Opuntian) Locrians, inhabiting the coast lands facing the south and southwest shore of the northwest end of Euboea Il. 2.527, 535, Il. 13.686; were archers Il. 13.712.
Λύκαστος (ἀργινόεις). A city of Crete Il. 2.647 .

Λυκάων-2. Patronymic Πριαμίδης. Son of Priam and Laothoe and brother of Polydorus-1 Il. 3.333 ; Apollo takes his form in inciting Aeneas Od. 3.81; sold into slavery at Lemnos to Euneus but ransomed by Eetion-3 Il. 21.40; Achilles comes upon him at the river and slays him Il. 21.35, 116, 127; Il. 22.46, Il. 23.746.
Λυκηγενής See Lexicon.

Λυκίη (ἐριβῶλαξ, εὐρεῖα , πίων). The country of the Lycians Il. 2.877, Il. 5.173, 479, 645, Il. 6.172, 173, 188, 210, 225, Il. 12.312, 318, Il. 16.437, 455, 514, 542, 673, 683, Il. 17.172. Λυκίηνδε [-δε], to Lycia Il. 6.168, 171. Λυκίηθεν [-θεν], from Lycia Il. 5.105.

Λύκιοι Trojan. (ἀντίθεοι, ἀσπισταί , ἴφθιμοι, πύκα θωρηκταί ). The Lycians, a people of southwest Asia Minor (southeast of the Carians) through whose territory the Xanthus-2 ran Il. 2.876, Il. 4.197, Il. 5.482; many slain by Odysseus Il. 5.676; Il. 10.430, Il. 12.315, Il. 16.421; etc.
Λυκομήδης Greek. (ἀρηΐφιλος, δῖος, κρατερός). Patronymic Κρειοντιάδης. Son of Creion-1 Il. 9.84, Il. 12.366; slays Apisaon-2 Il. 17.345, 346; Il. 19.240 .
Λυκόοργος-1 Λύκουργος (ἀνδροφόνος, κρατερός ). Son of Dryas-2. Scattered Dionysus and his attendants Il. 6.130, 134, his consequent fate 138.
Λυκόοργος-2. Slew Areithous-1 Il. 7.142, 144, gave Areithous-1's armour to Ereuthalion 148.
Λυκοφόντης Trojan. (ἀντίθεος). Killed by Teucrus Il. 21.275.
Λυκόφρων Patronymic Μαστορίδης-2. Son of Mastor. From Cythera, a follower of Aias-1. Killed by Hector Il. 15.430.
Λύκτος (ἐϋκτιμένη). A city of Crete Il. 2.647 , Il. 17.611.
Λύκων Trojan. killed by Peneleos Il. 16.335, 337.
Λυρνησσός A town of the southern Troad perhaps to be identified with the later Antandros. Taken by Achilles and its king Munes slain and Briseis captured Il. 2.690 , 691, Il. 19.60, Od. 3.92, 191.
Λύσανδρος Trojan. Killed by Aias-1 Il. 11.491.
Λωτοφάγοι The lotus-eaters. Visited by Odysseus Od. 9.84, 91, 92, 96, Od. 23.311.
Μάγνητες Greek. The men of Magnesia described as dwelling about the Peneius and Pelion, led by Prothous Il. 2.756.
Μαίανδρος A river of Asia Minor falling into the Aegean near Mycale Il. 2.869.
Μαιάς (Μαῖα). Mother by Zeus of Hermes Od. 14.435.
Μαιμαλίδης Patronymic of Peisandrus-3 Il. 16.194.
Μαῖρα-1. A nymph of Artemis, slain by her for an amour with Zeus Od. 11.326 .
Μαίων (ἐπιείκελος ἀθανάτοισιν). Patronymic Αἱμονίδης-1. With Polyphontes leader of the ambush at Thebes-1 against Tydeus Il. 4.394, the only survivor 398.
Μάκαρ King of Lesbos Il. 24.544.
Μάλεια The southeast extremity of the Peloponnesus Od. 9.80. So Μάλειαι Od. 3.287, Od. 4.514, Il. 19.187.
Μαντινέη (ἐρατεινή). A town of Arcadia Il. 2.607.
Μάντιος (κραταιός). Son of Melampus and father of Polypheides and Cleitus-2 Od. 15.242 , 249.
Μαραθών A district northeast of Athens facing Euboea Od. 7.80.
Μάρις Trojan. (ἀκοντιστής). Son of Amisodarus and brother of Atymnius. Killed by Thrasymedes Il. 16.319.
Μαρπήσση (καλλίσφυρος). Patronymic Εὐηνίνη. Wife of Ides and mother of Cleopatra Il. 9.557 .
Μάρων Son of Euanthes and priest of Apollo at Ismarus. His gifts to Odysseus Od. 9.197.
Μάσης A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.562.
Μαστορίδης-1. Patronymic of Halitherses Od. 2.158, Od. 24.452.
Μαστορίδης-2 Patronymic from next. Of Lycophron Il. 15.438.
Μάστωρ Father of Lycophron Il. 15.430.

Μαχάων (ἰητὴρ ἀγαθός, ποιμὴν λαῶν ). Patronymic Ἀσκληπιάδης. Son of Asclepius. With his brother Podaleirius chief surgeon of the Greeks and leader of the men of Tricca, etc. Il. 2.732; summoned to attend the wounded Menelaus Il. 4.193, 200; wounded by Paris Il. 11.506, but rescued by Nestor 512, 517, 598, 613, in Nestor's hut 618 , 651, Il. 14.3; Il. 11.833.
Μεγάδης Patronymic of Perimus Il. 16.695.
Μεγαπένθης (κρατερός). Son of Menelaus by a δούλη. His marriage to a daughter of Alector Od. 4.11; Od. 15.100, 103, 122.
Μεγάρη Daughter of Creion-2 and the first wife of Heracles Od. 11.269 .

Μέγης (ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, δουρικλυτός). Patronymic Φυλεΐδης. Son of Phyleus and leader of the men of Doulichium and the Echinean Islands Il. 2.627; slays Pedaeus Il. 5.69 ; leading the Epeians Il. 13.692; Il. 15.302; slays Croesmus Il. 15.520; Il. 15.535; slays Amphiclus Il. 16.313; Il. 19.239.
Μεδεών (ἐϋκτίμενον πτολίεθρον). A Boeotian town Il. 2.501.

Μέδων-1 Greek. Bastard son of Oeleus-1 by Rhene and brother of Aias-2. Takes the place of Philoctetes as leader of the men of Methone, etc. Il. 2.727, Il. 13.693 (his followers here called Φθῖοι); dwelt in Phylace a fugitive, having slain a kinsman of his stepmother Eriopis Il. 13.695, Il. 15.334. Killed by Aeneas Il. 15.332.
Μέδων-2 Trojan. Il. 17.216.

Μέδων-3 (πεπνυμένα εἰδώς). A herald of Odysseus left by him at home. Tells Penelope of the plot against her son's life Od. 4.677, 696, 711, Od. 16.412; consorted with the suitors Od. 16.252; their favourite herald Od. 17.172; spared by Odysseus Od. 22.357, 361; his advice to the people Od. 24.439, 442.

Μελάμπους (μάντις ἀμύμων). Son of Amythaon and father of Antiphates-3 and Mantius. As the price of the hand of Pero undertook to drive off the oxen of Iphiclus-1 Od. 11.291, but was put in bonds by Ι. 292, his release 294; he drove off the oxen Od. 15.235; while in bonds had been wronged by Neleus Od. 15.230, avenged himself and gave Pero to his brother (who was named Bias) 236, fled to Argos-1 (1) 238, where he married 241.
Μελανεύς Father of Amphimedon Od. 24.103.

Μελάνθιος-1 or Μελανθεύς, Od. 17.212 , Od. 20.255, Od. 21.176 , Od. 22.152, 159. (αἰπόλος αἰγῶν.) Odysseus's goatherd, son of Dolius-2. Maltreats and abuses the disguised Odysseus Od. 17.212, Od. 20.1731; Od. 17.247, 369, Od. 20.255, Od. 21.175, 176, 181, 265, Od. 22.135; brings armour and arms to the suitors Od. 22.142, 152, 159, 161; his punishment Od. 22.182, 195 , 474.
Μελάνθιος-2 Trojan. Killed by Eurypylus-2 Il. 6.36.
Μελανθώ (καλλιπάρῃος). An unfaithful hand maid, daughter of Dolius-2. Abuses the disguised Odysseus Od. 18.321, Od. 19.65; rebuked by Penelope Od. 19.89.
Μελάνιππος-1 Trojan. killed by Teucrus Il. 8.276.
Μελάνιππος-2 Trojan. (ἴφθιμος, ὑπέρθυμος ). Patronymic Ἱκεταονίδης. Son of Hicetaon Il. 15.547, 553. Killed by Antilochus Il. 15.576, 582.
Μελάνιππος-3 Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.695.
Μελάνιππος-4 Greek. T 240.
Μέλας Son of Portheus Il. 14.117.

Μελέαγρος (ἀρηΐφιλος, ξανθός ). Son of Oeneus and Althaea and husband of Cleopatra. Died before the Trojan war Il. 2.642; killed the Calydonian boar Il. 9.543, strife having arisen with the Couretes conceived anger against his mother and would fight no more 550 , 553, persuaded by his wife beats the Couretes off 590.
Μελίβοια A town in the realm of Philoctetes north of the Boebean Lake Il. 2.717.
Μελίτη A Nereid Il. 18.42 .
Μέμνων (ἀγλαός, δῖος). Son of Tithonus and Eos. Slew Antilochus Od. 4.188; his beauty Od. 11.522.

Μενέλαος (ἀγαθός, ἀγακλεής , ἀμύμων, ἄναξ, ἀντίθεος, ἀρήϊος, ἀρηΐφιλος, βοὴν ἀγαθός, διοτρεθής, δουρικλειτός, ἴφθιμος, κοσμήτωρ λαῶν, κυδάλιμος, ξανθός, ὄρχαμος λαῶν). Patronymic Ἀτρεΐδης. King of Lacedaemon. Son of Atreus, brother of Agamemnon, husband of Helen and father by her of Hermione-1; father also of Megapenthes. His followers enumerated Il. 2.581; had often entertained Idomeneus Il. 3.232; fights Paris Il. 3.340 , Paris withdrawn by Aphrodite 380; Menelaus wounded by Pandarus Il. 4.127, tended by Machaon 210 ; takes and spares Adrestus-3 Il. 6.37, but Agamemnon slays him 63; ready to accept Hector's challenge Il. 7.94, but is dissuaded 104; cannot sleep and joins Agamemnon in rousing the chiefs Il. 10.25; with Aias-1 comes to the rescue of Odysseus Il. 11.465 ; wounds Helenus-1 Il. 13.581, kills Peisandrus-2 601; bestrides the corpse of Patroclus Il. 17.1, kills Euphorbus 45 , retires before Hector 108, returns with Aias-1 124 , Hector retires before them 129, he shouts for help 248, Athene in the guise of Phoenix-1 urges him on 556, he kills Podes 575 , dispatches Antilochus to Achilles 685, the corpse is at last rescued Il. 18.231; takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.293, Antilochus gains the advantage of him 417, he comes in third 514, accuses A. of foul driving 566, A. pacifies him 586; etc. : after the taking of Troy advised, opposing Agamemnon, a return home at once Od. 3.141, sailed accordingly 157; the death of his steersman off Sounium Od. 3.278; receives Telemachus hospitably at Sparta Od. 4.1, tells him his adventures 333; speeds him home with gifts Od. 15.68; etc.
Μενεσθεύς (δῖος, μεγάθυμος, πλήξιππος). Son of Peteos and leader of the Athenians Il. 2.552 , Il. 4.327; in charge of part of the wall Il. 12.331, 373; Il. 13.195, 690, Il. 15.331.
Μενέσθης Greek. (εἰδὼς χάρμης). With his brother Anchialus-1 killed by Hector Il. 5.609.
Μενέσθιος-1 Greek. Son of Areithous-1 and Phylomedousa. Dwelt at Arne. Killed by Paris Il. 7.9 .
Μενέσθιος-2 (αἰολοθώρηξ). Son of the Spercheius and Polydora, nominally son of Borus-2. A leader under Achilles Il. 16.173.
Μενοιτιάδης Patronymic from next. Of Patroclus Il. 1.307, Il. 9.211, Il. 16.420, Il. 17.132, Il. 18.93, Il. 21.28, Il. 23.25, Il. 24.16 etc. : Od. 24.77.

Μενοίτιος Son of Actor-2 and father of Patroclus Il. 9.202 , Il. 11.605; his charge to his son Il. 11.765, 771, 785; Il. 11.814, 837, Il. 12.1, Il. 16.14, 278, 307, 626, 665, 827, Il. 18.12; Achilles' promise to him Il. 18.324; Il. 18.455, Il. 19.24; brought his son from his home in Opoeis to the house of Peleus Il. 23.85 .
Μέντης-1. Leader of the Cicones. In his guise Apollo urges Hector to avenge Euphorbus Il. 17.73 .
Μέντης-2. Son of Anchialus-2 and king of the Taphians. In his guise Athene appears to Telemachus Od. 1.105 , 180, 418.
Μέντωρ-1 (πολύϊππος). Father of Imbrius-1 Il. 13.171.

Μέντωρ-2 Patronymic Ἀλκιμίδης. A comrade of Odysseus in Ithaca left in charge of Odysseus's house and property. His speech in the Ithacan assembly Od. 2.225; Athene takes his guise Od. 2.267 (urging Telemachus to go to Pylus and Sparta ), 416 (accompanying T.), Od. 22.206 (in the fight with the suitors), Od. 24.502 (in the fight with the Ithacans); etc.

data.ref: Od. 22.206 (in the fight with the suitors),

definition: Μένων Trojan. killed by Leonteus Il. 12.193.
Μερμερίδης Patronymic of Ilus-2 Od. 1.259.
Μέρμερος Trojan. killed by Antilochus Il. 14.513.
Μέροψ Of Percote. Father of Adrestus-2 and Amphius-1 Il. 2.831 , Il. 11.329.
Μεσαύλιος A servant bought by Eumaeus with his own funds from the Taphians Od. 14.449, 455.
Μέσθλης Son of Talaemenes and a leader of the Maeonians (Μῄονες) Il. 2.864, Il. 17.216.
Μέσση (πολυτρήρων). A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.582.
Μεσσηΐς A fountain in Greece of unknown site Il. 6.457.
Μεσσήνη A town (no doubt maritime) apparently in the later Messenia Od. 21.15.
Μεσσήνιοι The men of prec. Od. 21.18.
Μηδεσικάστη Bastard daughter of Priam. Wife of Imbrius-1 Il. 13.173.
Μηθώνη A town in the realm of Philoctetes on the east shore of the Pagasaean Gulf Il. 2.716.
Μηκιστεύς-1 (ἄναξ). Patronymic Ταλαϊονίδης. Father of Euryalus-1 Il. 2.566; he overcame all in the funeral games of Oedipus Il. 23.678 .
Μηκιστεύς-2 Son of Echius-1. Assists Alastor-1 in carrying off the wounded Teucrus Il. 8.333, and Hypsenor-2 Il. 13.422. Killed by Poulydamas Il. 15.339.
Μηκιστηϊάδης Patronymic from Μηκιστεύς-1. Of Euryalus-1 Il. 6.28.
Μῃονίη (ἐρατεινή). The land of the Maeonians Il. 3.401, Il. 18.291.
Μῃονίς A Maeonian woman Il. 4.142.
Μῄων a Maeonian, one of a people in the basin of the Hermus and the plain of Sardis Il. 5.43. Μῄονες Τ (ἱπποκορυσταί). The Maeonians Il. 2.864, 866 , Il. 10.431.

Μηριόνης (ἀγὸς ἀνδρῶν, ἀτάλαντος Ἐνυαλίῳ ἀνδρειφόντῃ, δαΐφρων, δουρικλυτός, ἐΰς, θοῷ ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, μήστωρ ἀϋτῆς , πεπνυμένος). Son of Molus and traditionally nephew of Idomeneus. ὀπάων of I. and joined with him in the leadership of the Cretans Il. 2.651, Il. 7.165 ; kills Phereclus Il. 5.59; accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 7.166; kills Adamas Il. 13.567 , kills Harpalion 650 , kills Morys and Hippotion Il. 14.514 , kills Acamas-1 Il. 16.342, kills Laogonus-1 Il. 16.603, Aeneas misses him 608 ; superintends the bringing of wood for the pyre of Patroclus Il. 23.113; takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.351, comes in fourth 528, wins the archery contest 860, receives a consolation prize for spear-throwing, the contest not taking place 884; etc.
Μήστωρ (ἀντίθεος). A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.257.
Μίδεια A Boeotian town Il. 2.507.
Μίλητος-1 A city of Crete Il. 2.647 .
Μίλητος-2 The city of the Carians near the mouth of the Maeander Il. 2.868.
Μίμας (ἠνεμόεις). A mountain range forming a promontory off which the north of Chios lies Od. 3.172.
Μινύειος Of the legendary race of the Μινύαι. Of Orchomenus-1 Il. 2.511 : Od. 11.284.
Μινυήϊος A river of Nestor's realm Il. 11.722.

Μίνως (ἀγλαός, Διὸς ὀαριστής , ὀλοόφρων). King of Crete. Son of Zeus and Europa (daughter of Phoenix-2), brother of Rhadamanthys and father of Deucalion-1, Ariadne and Phaedra Il. 13.450, 451 , Il. 14.322: Od. 11.322 ; judging among the Shades Od. 11.568; Od. 17.523; reigned in Cnosus Od. 19.178.
Μνῆσος Trojan. A Paeonian. Killed by Achilles Il. 21.210.
Μοῖρα See Lexicon.
Μολίων-1 (ἀντίθεος). θεράπων to Thymbraeus. Killed by Odysseus Il. 11.322.
Μολίων-2. In form a patronymic; but see under Ἀκτορίων. Of Cteatus and Eurytus-2 Il. 11.709 , 750.
Μόλος Father of Meriones. Traditionally a son of Deucalion-1 and brother of Idomeneus Il. 10.269, Il. 13.249.
Μόρυς Trojan. Came from Ascania, son of Hippotion Il. 13.792 . Killed by Meriones Il. 14.514.
Μούλιος-1 (αἰχμητής). Son-in-law of Augeias and husband of Agamede. Nestor slew him Il. 11.739.
Μούλιος-2 Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.696.
Μούλιος-3 Trojan. killed by Achilles Od. 3.472.
Μούλιος-4 )Δουλιχιεύς(. θεράπων of Amphinomus Od. 18.423 .
Μυγδών (ἀντίθεος). A leader of the Phrygians Il. 3.186.
Μύδων-1 Trojan. (ἐσθλός). Patronymic Ἀτυμνιάδης. Chariot-driver of Pylaemenes. Killed by Antilochus Il. 5.580.
Μύδων-2 Trojan. A Paeonian. Killed by Achilles Il. 21.209.
Μυκάλη (αἰπεινή). A promontory of Asia Minor off which the Icarian Samos lies Il. 2.869.
Μυκαλησσός (εὐρύχορος). A Boeotian town Il. 2.498.
Μυκῆναι See Μυκήνη-1.
Μυκηναῖος Adj. from next Il. 15.638. In pl., the Mycenaeans Il. 15.643.

Μυκήνη-1, also Μυκῆναι Il. 2.569 , Il. 4.376 (ἐϋκτίμενον πτολίεθρον, εὐρυάγυια, πολύχρυσος). Agamemnon's capital Il. 2.569, Il. 4.52, 376 , Il. 7.180, Il. 11.46: Od. 3.304, Od. 21.108. Μυκήνηθεν [-θεν], from M. Il. 9.44.
Μυκήνη-2 (ἐϋστέφανος). Said to have been the eponym of prec. Brought into comparison with Penelope Od. 2.120.
Μύνης (θεῖος, ἐγχεσίμωρος ). King of Lyrnessus. Son of Euenus and brother of Epistrophus-2 Il. 2.692, Il. 19.296.
Μυρίνη (πολύσκαρθμος) Il. 2.814 . Said to have been an Amazon. See Βατίεια.

Μυρμιδόνες The people of Peleus Il. 1.180, Il. 7.126, Il. 16.15, 596, Il. 19.299 , Il. 21.188, Il. 24.397 , 536 : Od. 4.9, Od. 11.495. (ἐγχεσίμωροι, μεγαλήτορες , ταχύπωλοι, φιλοπτόλεμοι .) The followers of Achilles at Troy Il. 1.328, Il. 9.185, Il. 11.797, Il. 16.12, Il. 18.10, Il. 19.14, Il. 23.4, Il. 24.449, etc. Their return Od. 3.188. Applied with Ἕλληνες and Ἀχαιοί to A. 's followers Il. 2.684. Distinguished from Ἀχαιοί 564.
Μύρσινος A town of Elis Il. 2.616 .
Μυσοί-1 Trojan. (ἀγέρωχοι, καρτερόθυμοι ). The Mysians, a people east of the Troad, probably having the Aesepus-1 as their west boundary Il. 2.858, Il. 10.430 , Il. 14.512, Il. 24.278 .
Μυσοί-2 (ἀγχέμαχοι). A people of the far north beyond Thrace Il. 13.5.
Νάστης (ἀγλαός). Son of Nomion and a leader of the Carians Il. 2.867, 870, 871.
Ναυβολίδης-1. Patronymic of Iphitus-1 Il. 2.518.
Ναυβολίδης-2. Patronymic of Euryalus-2 Od. 8.116.

Ναυσίθοος (θεοειδής, μεγάθυμος ). King of the Phaeacians. Son of Poseidon and Periboea-2 and father of Rhexenor and Alcinous. Settled his people in Scheria Od. 6.7; his parentage and progeny Od. 7.56, 62, 63; Od. 8.565.

Ναυσικάα (εὔπεπλος, λευκώλενος , θεῶν ἄπο κάλλος ἔχουσα). Daughter of Alcinous and Arete. Her dream Od. 6.20; she takes the washing to the river Od. 6.81, she and her maidens play 100, when Odysseus wakens she alone does not flee 139, Odysseus's appeal to her 149, her reply 187, she encourages her maidens 199, she bids Odysseus prepare to accompany her and gives him counsel and information 255, she leads him to the city 316, her return home Od. 7.2; her farewell to Odysseus Od. 8.457; etc.
Ναυτεύς A Phaeacian Od. 8.112 .
Νέαιρα (δῖα). Mother by Eelius of Phaethousa and Lampetie Od. 12.133 .

Νεοπτόλεμος (θεοειδής). The youthful son of Achilles. Brought up in Scyrus-1 Il. 19.327 : brought thence by Odysseus Od. 11.506 , his exploits at Troy 510 , slays Eurypylus-3 520; his marriage to Hermione-1 Od. 4.5.
Νεστόρεος Adj. from Νέστωρ 54, Il. 8.113, 192.

Νεστορίδης Patronymic from next. Of Antilochus Il. 6.33, Il. 15.589, Il. 23.353. Of Thrasymedes Il. 9.81. In pl. of both Il. 16.317. Of Peisistratus Od. 3.36, 482, Od. 4.71, 155, Od. 15.6, 44, 46, 48, 166, 195, 202.

Νέστωρ (ἀντίθεος, γέρων, Γερήνιος, δῖος, ἡδυεπής, ίππηλάτα, ἱππόδαμος, ἱππότα, λιγὺς Πυλίων ἀγορητής, μεγάθυμος , μέγα κῦδος Ἀχαιῶν, μέγας , οὖρος Ἀχαιῶν, ποιμὴν λαῶν , Πυλοιγενὴς βασιλεύς, ὑπέρθυμος). Patronymic Νηλεΐδης, Νηληϊάδης. King of Pylus, son of Neleus, husband of Eurydice and father of Antilochus, Peisistratus, Echephron, Stratius, Perseus-2, Aretus-2 and Thrasymedes. Had reigned already over two generations Il. 1.247; intervenes in the quarrel between Achilles and Agamemnon Il. 1.254 ; Oneirus appears to Ag. in his form Il. 2.21; he addresses the βουλή Il. 2.77; visited by Ag. in his inspection Il. 4.293; reproaches the Greeks, no champion coming forward against Hector, and tells the tale of the fighting between the Pylians and the Arcadians Il. 7.123; advises the burning of the dead and the building of the wall Il. 7.325; is cut off in the fight Il. 8.80, but is rescued by Diomedes 99; advises the setting of a guard Il. 9.52; advises the restoration of Briseis with gifts Il. 9.94, advises the sending of the embassy 162; is wakened by Ag. Il. 10.73, visits the guard 180; carries off the wounded Machaon Il. 11.516; his appeal in his hut to Patroclus and his tale of the fighting between the Pylians and the Epeians Il. 11.655; encounters the wounded chiefs Il. 14.27; his advice to Antilochus before the chariot-race Il. 23.306, is presented by Achilles with a remaining prize 615; etc. : hospitably receives Telemachus at Pylus Od. 3.31, tells, him the tale of his return 102, advises him to go to Menelaus 317, dispatches him 474; restrained the flight of the Greeks when Thetis appeared to take part in the funeral rites of Achilles Od. 24.50; etc.
Νήϊον (ὑλήεν). A mountain in Ithaca Od. 1.186. In Od. 9.22 u.l. for Νήριτον. See Νήριτον.
Νηλεΐδης Patronymic from Νηλεύς. Of Nestor Il. 23.652 .

Νηλεύς (ἀγαυότατος ζωόντων, ἀμύμων , ἀντίθεος, θεόφιν μήστωρ ἀτάλαντος, κρατερὸς θεράπων Διός, μεγάθυμος). Son (Od. 11.241) of Poseidon and Tyro, husband of Chloris and (Od. 11.285) father of Nestor, Chromius-1, Periclymenus and Pero (in Il. 11.692 he is said to have had twelve sons) Il. 11.683, 717 : Od. 3.4, 409, Od. 11.254, 281; his requirement of Pero's suitors Od. 11.288; his treatment of Melampus Od. 15.229, 233.

data.ref: Il. 11.692 he is said to have had twelve sons)

definition: Νηληϊάδης Patronymic from prec. Of Nestor Il. 8.100 , Il. 10.87, 555, Il. 11.511, 618, Il. 14.42, Il. 15.378, Il. 23.303 : Od. 3.79, 202, 247, 465.
Νηλήϊος Adj. from Νηλεύς 597, 682 : Od. 4.639. Of Nestor Il. 2.20 , Il. 10.18, Il. 23.349. Of Antilochus Il. 23.514.
Νημερτής A Nereid Il. 18.46 .
Νηρηΐς See Lexicon. Νηρεύς͂ the ἅλιος γέρων of Il. 1.556 : Od. 24.58, and the πατὴρ γέρων and γέρων ἅλιος of Il. 18.36, 141.
Νήρικος (ἀκτὴ ἠπείροιο, ἐϋκτίμενον πτολίεθρον). Perhaps to be identified with the place of the name mentioned in Thuc. iii. 7. 4. How Laertes took the place Od. 24.377.
Νήριτον (εἰνοσίφυλλον, καταειμένον ὕλῃ). A mountain in Ithaca Il. 2.632 : Od. 9.22, Od. 13.351. In Od. 1.186 u.l. for Νήϊον. Νήριτον and Νήϊον seem to be the same.
Νήριτος See Ἴθακος.
Νησαίη A Nereid Il. 18.40 .
Νιόβη (ἠΰκομος). Her children slain by Apollo and Artemis and she herself turned to stone on Mt. Sipylus Il. 24.602, 606 .
Νιρεύς Son of Charopus and Aglaia and leader of the men of Syme. His beauty Il. 2.671-673.
Νῖσα (ζαθέη). A Boeotian town Il. 2.508.
Νῖσος (ἄναξ, ἀφνειός, Δουλιχιεύς, ἐΰς). Patronymic Ἀρητιάδης. Father of Amphinomus Od. 16.395, Od. 18.127, 413.
Νίσυρος An Aegean island, one of the Sporades Il. 2.676.
Νοήμων-1 Trojan. killed by Odysseus Il. 5.678.
Νοήμων-2 A comrade of Antilochus Il. 23.612.
Νοήμων-3 (φαίδιμος). An Ithacan, son of Phronius. Lent Telemachus a ship Od. 2.386, Od. 4.630, 648.
Νομίων Father of Nastes and Amphimachus-2 Il. 2.871.
Νυσήϊον (sc. ὄρος) (ἠγάθεον). Adj. from Νύσα, the mythical mountain sacred to Dionysus Il. 6.133.

Ξάνθος-1. The divine name of the river of the Trojan plain west of Troy called (Il. 20.74) by men Σκάμανδρος. Zeus his father Il. 14.434, Il. 21.2, Il. 24.693. Ξάνθος (βαθυδινήεις , βαθυδίνης, δινήεις , ἐϋρρεῖος) 4, Il. 8.560; the ford Il. 14.434, Il. 21.2 , Il. 24.693; Od. 3.40, Il. 21.15, 146, 332, 337, 383. Σκάμανδρος (βαθυδινήεις, βαθυδίνης, δινήεις, δῖος, διοτρεφής, ἐΰρροος, ἠϊόεις) Il. 5.36; his priest Il. 5.77 : Il. 5.774 , Il. 7.329, Il. 11.499 , Il. 12.21, Il. 21.124 , 223, 305, 603; his springs Il. 22.148.
Ξάνθος-2 (δινήεις, ῥέων). A river of Lycia Il. 2.877, Il. 5.479, Il. 6.172, Il. 12.313.
Ξάνθος-3 Trojan. Son of Phaenops-1. With his brother Thoon-1 killed by Diomedes Il. 5.152.
Ξάνθος-4. One of Hector's horses Il. 8.185.
Ξάνθος-5 (πόδας αἰόλος). One of the horses of Achilles by Zephyrus out of Podarge Il. 16.149 , Il. 19.400, 405, 420.
Ὀγχηστός (ἱερός). A Boeotian town with a grove of Poseidon Il. 2.506.
Ὀδίος-1 (μέγας). A leader of the Halizonians Il. 2.856. Killed by Agamemnon Il. 5.39.
Ὀδίος-2. A Greek herald Il. 9.170.

Ὀδυσσεύς Genit. Ὀδυσεῦς 398 (ἀγακλυτός, ἀμύμων , ἄναξ, ἀντίθεος, δαΐφρων, Διὶ μῆτιν ἀτάλαντος , διίφιλος, διογενής , δῖος, δόλων ἆτος ἠδὲ πόνοιο, δουρικλυτός, ἐσθλός, θεῖος, θεοῖς ἐναλίγκιος, θρασύς, Ἰθακήσιος, κλυτός, κρατερός, κυδάλιμος, Λαερτιάδης, μεγάθυμος, μεγαλήτωρ, ποικιλομήτης, πολύαινος, πολύμητις, πολυμήχανος, πολύτλας δῖος , πολύτροπος, πολύφρων , πτολίπορθος, πτολιπόρθιος , ταλασίφρων, τλήμων , φαίδιμος). (For the significance of the name see Od. 19.406.) Only son of Laertes and Anticleia, brother of Ctimene, husband of Penelope and father of Telemachus. In command of the ship conveying Chryseis to her father Il. 1.311, 430; Athene urges him to stop the flight homeward of the Greeks Il. 2.169, he deals with Thersites 244, exhorts the host 278; his followers enumerated Il. 2.631; described by Helen to Priam Il. 3.191; visited by Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.329; accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 7.168; neglects the disabled Nestor Il. 8.97; is one of the embassy to Achilles Il. 9.169, his speech 225, announces the result 677; wakened by Nestor Il. 10.137, offers to go with Diomedes to penetrate the hostile lines 231 (see further under Diomedes); comes to the help of the wounded Diomedes Il. 11.396 , is cut off 401, after doing much execution is wounded by Socus 434, kills him 447, is rescued by Menelaus and Aias-1 465; reproves Agamemnon Il. 14.83; advises against renewing the fight fasting Il. 19.155, 216, superintends the conveyance of the gifts to Achilles 238; his drawn wrestling-match with Aias-1 Il. 23.708, wins the foot-race 755; etc. : his adventures on his way home; the Cicones Od. 9.39, the Lotus-eaters 82, the Cyclops 105 , the island of Aeolus Od. 10.1, the Laestrygonians (all the ships lost but his) 80, Circe's island 135 , Oceanus, the Cimmerians, the Shades Od. 11.13, return to Circe's island Od. 12.1, the Sirens 146, smoke, breakers, roaring 201, Scylla and Charybdis 223, Thrinacia, the oxen of the Sun 260, the ship wrecked by violence of the wind, himself the only survivor 403, Scylla and Charybdis again 430, reaches Calypso's island 447, Hermes comes from Zeus to bid C. let him go Od. 5.29, he builds his raft 234, sets sail 269, Poseidon raises the sea 291, the raft shattered 313, Ino comes to his aid 333 , lands in the mouth of a Phaeacian river and falls asleep 451, wakened by Nausicaa's maidens Od. 6.117, his appeal to Nausicaa 149, she conducts him to a point near the city 316, he proceeds to the city Od. 7.14, enters the palace of Alcinous 134, who receives him hospitably 167, he views the games and dancing Od. 8.109, is taunted by Euryalus-2 158, answers him 165, they are reconciled 396, 400 , he throws the δίσκος 186 , hears the lay of Demodocus 266, relates his adventures Od. 9.39, is conveyed with gifts in a Phaeacian ship to Ithaca Od. 13.70; Athene comes to him Od. 13.221, his tale to her 256, she transforms him into a beggar 429; he proceeds to the hut of Eumaeus Od. 14.1, who receives him hospitably 48, his tale to Eumaeus 192, his tale of the night ambush 462; Telemachus appears at the hut Od. 16.11; Athene appears and retransforms Odysseus Od. 16.155 , Odysseus reveals himself to his son 187, is transformed back to a beggar 454; with Eumaeus follows Telemachus to the city Od. 17.200, they encounter Melantheus 212, they reach the city 260;
