his dog Argus Od. 17.291; he follows Eumaeus into the house Od. 17.336, goes begging round the suitors 365, his tale to Antinous 415, A. throws a foot-stool at him 462, he is summoned to Penelope 553, declines to go 561; his quarrel with Irus Od. 18.1; abused by Melantho Od. 18.321, Eurymachus throws another foot-stool at him 394; with Telemachus he removes the arms Od. 19.4; Melantho abuses him again Od. 19.66; his tale to Penelope Od. 19.165, Penelope tests him 215, he tells of her husband and prophesies his return 262; Eurycleia ordered to wash him Od. 19.357, she recognizes his scar 392, 467, how he got the scar 393, she is silenced 479; he interprets Penelope's dream Od. 19.535; lies down to sleep in the πρόδομος 1, Athene appears to him 30, Zeus gives him signs 102; Ctesippus throws the foot of an ox at him Od. 20.287; he reveals himself to Philoetius and Eumaeus Od. 21.193; asks to try the bow Od. 21.275, Eumaeus gives it to him on the orders of Telemachus 359, he strings it 404; kills Antinous Od. 22.8 , Eurymachus vainly begs for mercy 45, the fight proceeds 79, Athene appears 205 , slaughter of the suitors 297; he summons the unfaithful maids for death Od. 21.431; Penelope comes to him but doubts Od. 23.85, her doubts resolved by his knowledge of the bed 174, he tells her of the trials that await him 264, the pair retire 289, he tells his adventures 310, he charges her with the care of the house and leaves the city 348; he goes to try his father Od. 24.216, his tale to him 303, reveals himself 321, the fight with the Ithacans 520, stopped by Athene 531 ; etc.

data.ref: 231 (see further under Diomedes); comes to the help of the wounded Diomedes

definition: Ὀδυσήϊος Adj. from prec. Od. 18.353.
Ὀθρυονεύς Trojan. From Cabesus. Sought Cassandra in marriage, promising to expel the Greeks. Killed by Idomeneus Il. 13.363, 374, 772.
Οἰδιπόδης the later Oedipus. King of Thebes-1. His incestuous marriage with Epicaste Od. 11.271. His funeral games referred to Il. 23.679.
Ὀϊκλῆς Ὀϊκλήης (μεγάθυμος). Son of Antiphates-3 and father of Amphiaraus Od. 15.243 , 244.

Ὀϊλεύς-1 (θεῖος, πτολίπορθος ). Husband of Eriopis and father of Aias-2; by Rhene father of Medon-1 Il. 2.527, 727, 728, Il. 13.66, 694, 697, 701, Il. 14.442, 520, Il. 15.333, 336, Il. 17.256, Il. 23.473, 488, 754.
Ὀϊλεύς-2 (πλήξιππος) Trojan. With his comrade Bienor killed by Agamemnon Il. 11.93 .
Ὀϊλιάδης Patronymic from Ὀϊλεύς-1. Of Aias-2 Il. 12.365 , Il. 13.203, 712, Il. 14.446, Il. 16.330, Il. 23.759.
Οἰνεΐδης Patronymic from next. Of Tydeus Il. 5.813 , Il. 10.497.

Οἰνεύς (δῖος, ιππηλάτα, ἱππότα, μεγαλήτωρ). Ruler of Calydon in Aetolia, son of Portheus, husband of Althaea, father of Tydeus and Meleagrus, and grandfather of Diomedes Il. 2.641; entertained Bellerophon Il. 6.216, 219; the Calydonian boar Il. 9.535, 540, 543, 581; Il. 14.117.
Οἰνόμαος-1 Greek. Killed by Hector Il. 5.706.
Οἰνόμαος-2 Trojan. Il. 12.140. Killed by Idomeneus Il. 13.506.
Οἰνοπίδης Patronymic of Helenus-2 Il. 5.707.
Οἶνοψ Father of Leodes Od. 21.144.
Οἴτυλος A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.585.
Οἰχαλιεύς Adj. from next, Oechalian. Of Eurytus-1 Il. 2.596, 730; Od. 8.224 .
Οἰχαλίη In Thessaly, the city of Eurytus-1. Its men led by Podaleirius and Machaon Il. 2.730. Οἰχαλίηθεν [-θεν], from Oechalia, Il. 2.596 .
Ὀλιζών (τρηχεῖα). A town in the realm of Philoctetes at the extremity of the Magnesian Peninsula Il. 2.717.
Ὀλοοσσών (λευκή). A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.739.
Ὀλυμπιάς Fem. adj.=next Il. 2.491.

Ὄλυμπος Οὔλυμπος (ἀγάννιφος, αἰγλήεις , αἰπύς, θεῶν ἕδος , μακρός, μέγας, νιφόεις, πολυδειράς, πολύπτυχος). The Thessalian Mt. Olympus, the seat of the gods Il. 1.44, Il. 3.407, Il. 5.360, Il. 11.77, Il. 13.523, Il. 16.93, Od. 3.5, Il. 24.144, etc. : Od. 1.102, Od. 6.240, Od. 8.331, Od. 11.313, Od. 14.394, Od. 20.55, etc. Οὔλυμπόνδε [-δε], to Odysseus Il. 1.221, Il. 8.12, Il. 15.133, Il. 18.146, Il. 21.438, etc. : Od. 6.42.
Ὄνειρος (θεῖος, οὖλος). See Lexicon.
Ὀνητορίδης Patronymic of Phrontis-2 Od. 3.282.
Ὀνήτωρ Priest of the Idaean Zeus and father of Laogonus-1 Il. 16.604 .
Ὀπίτης Greek. Killed by Hector Il. 11.301.
Ὀπόεις A Locrian town Il. 2.531, Il. 18.326; the home of Menoetius Il. 23.85.
Ὀρέσβιος Greek. (αἰολομίτρης). Killed by Hector Il. 5.707.
Ὀρέστης-1 (πλήξιππος) Greek. Killed by Hector Il. 5.705.
Ὀρέστης-2 Trojan. Il. 12.139. Killed by Leonteus Il. 12.193.

Ὀρέστης-3 (δῖος, τηλεκλυτός ). Patronymic Ἀγαμεμνονίδης, Ἀτρεΐδης. Son of Agamemnon and Clytaemnestra Il. 9.142, 284 : avenged his father's murder on Aegisthus and Clytaemnestra Od. 1.30, 40, 298, Od. 3.306, Od. 4.546; Ag. in the Shades asks Odysseus about his fate Od. 11.461.
Ὀρθαῖος Trojan. Il. 13.791.
Ὄρθη A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.739.
Ὀρμενίδης Patronymic of Amyntor Il. 9.448, Il. 10.266. A sim. patronymic given to Ctesius Od. 15.414.
Ὀρμένιον A town of Thessaly, probably lying under Pelion. Its men led by Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.734.
Ὄρμενος-1 Trojan. killed by Teucrus Il. 8.274.
Ὄρμενος-2 Trojan. killed by Polypoetes Il. 12.187.
Ὀρνειαί A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.571.
Ὀρσίλοχος-1 Trojan. killed by Teucrus Il. 8.274.
Ὀρσίλοχος-2 (πόδας ὠκύς). An alleged son of Idomeneus. Odysseus in his tale to Athene says that he killed him Od. 13.260.
Ὀρτίλοχος-3 (δαΐφρων). Son of the Alpheius and father of Diocles Il. 5.546, 547 : Od. 3.489, Od. 15.187, Od. 21.16.
Ὀρτίλοχος-4. Son of Diocles. With his brother Crethon killed by Aeneas Il. 5.542, 549.
Ὀρτυγίη A mythical island. Orion slain here Od. 5.123; apparently represented as to the south of the island Syria Od. 15.404.
Ὀρχομενός-1 (Μινύειος). A Boeotian town, the capital of the kingdom of the Minyae Il. 2.511, Il. 9.381: Od. 11.284, 459.
Ὀρχομενός-2 (πολύμηλος). A town of Arcadia Il. 2.605.
Ὄσσα A mountain in Magnesia between Olympus and Pelion. See Od. 11.315 under Πήλιον .
Ὀτρεύς A leader of the Phrygians Il. 3.186.
Ὀτρυντεΐδης Patronymic from next. Of Iphition Od. 3.383 , 389.
Ὀτρυντεύς (πτολίπορθος). A Maeonian. Father of Iphition by a naiad Od. 3.384.
Οὐκαλέγων (πεπνυμένος). A Trojan elder Il. 3.148 .
Οὔλυμπος See Ὄλυμπος.
Οὐρανίωνες See Lexicon.
Οὐρανός (εὐρύς). See Lexicon.
Οὖτις = οὔ τις. Odysseus's name assumed for the Cyclops Od. 9.366, 369, 408, 455, 460.
Ὀφελέστης-1 Trojan. killed by Teucrus Il. 8.274.
Ὀφελέστης-2 Trojan. A Paeonian. Killed by Achilles Il. 21.210.
Ὀφέλτιος-1 Trojan. Killed by Euryalus-1 Il. 6.20.
Ὀφέλτιος-2 Greek. Killed by Hector Il. 11.302.
Ὀχήσιος Father of Periphas-1 Il. 5.843.
Παιήων The physician of the gods. Heals Hades Il. 5.401, heals Ares 899, 900: the Egyptians descended from him Od. 4.232.
Παίονες Trojan. (ἀλκυλότοξοι, δολιχεγχέες , ἱπποκορυσταί). The Paeonians, a people whose territory lay on the Axius Il. 2.848 , Il. 10.428, Il. 16.287 , 291, Il. 21.155, 205, 211.
Παιονίδης Patronymic of Agastrophus Il. 11.339, 368.
Παιονίη (ἐριβῶλαξ, ἐρίβωλος ). The land of the Paeonians Il. 17.350, Il. 21.154.
Παισός See Ἀπαισός.
Παλλάς See Ἀθηναίη.
Πάλμυς Trojan. Il. 13.792.
Πάμμων A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.250.
Παναχαιοί All the Achaeans , the Achaeans in gen. (see Ἀχαιός 2.b) Il. 2.404, Il. 7.73, 159 , 327, 385, Il. 9.301, Il. 10.1, Il. 19.193, Il. 23.236: Od. 1.239, Od. 14.369, Od. 24.32.

Πανδάρεος Father of Aedon (the proper name does not occur), who was the wife of Zethus and mother of Itylus . Aedon slew Itylus by mistake and was subsequently changed into a nightingale (ἀηδών) Od. 19.518; Pandareus's daughters carried off by a wind (their parents being destroyed), but brought up by Aphrodite Od. 20.66.

Πάνδαρος (ἀγλαός, ἀμύμων τε κρατερός τε, ἀντίθεος). The Trojan bowman, son of Lycaon-1. Leader of the men of Zeleia Il. 2.827; wounds Menelaus Il. 4.88, wounds Diomedes Il. 5.95, 795; with Aeneas attacks Diomedes Il. 5.168, Il. 5.171, Il. 5.246, and strikes him with his spear Il. 5.280. Killed by Diomedes Il. 5.290.
Πανδίων Greek. Bears Teucrus's bow Il. 12.372.
Πάνδοκος Trojan. Killed by Aias-1 Il. 11.490.
Πανέλληνες All the Hellenes (with extension of Ἕλληνες to the Greeks in gen.). App hardly to be distinguished from Ἀχαιοί in the same line (see Ἀχαιός 2.b) Il. 2.530.
Πανθοΐδης Patronymic from next. Of Poulydamas Il. 13.756, Il. 14.450, 454 , Il. 15.446, Il. 16.535 , Il. 18.250. Of Euphorbus Il. 16.808, Il. 17.70, 81 .

Πάνθοος Genit. Πάνθου, Dat. Πάνθῳ . An elder at Troy, apparently (Il. 16.807) a Dardanian, husband of Phrontis-1 and father of Euphorbus, Poulydamas and Hyperenor Il. 3.146 , Il. 15.522, Il. 17.9, 23, 40.
Πανοπεύς-1 (καλλίχορος, κλειτός ). A town or district of Phocis Il. 2.520, Il. 17.307: Od. 11.581.
Πανοπεύς-2. Father of Epeius Il. 23.665.
Πανόπη A Nereid Il. 18.45 .
Παρθένιος A Paphlagonian river Il. 2.854.

Πάρις often called Ἀλέξανδρος (βασιλεύς, δῖος, θεοειδής). Son of Priam and Hecabe. Carried off Helen from Menelaus and was her husband at Troy. Appears in the front of the Trojans Il. 3.16, but retires before Menelaus 30, reproached by Hector 38 , his duel with Menelaus 340, he is snatched away by Aphrodite and set down in his chamber 380, Helen comes to him 421 ; Hector comes to urge him to the field Il. 6.321, he goes 503, and joins Η. 514, kills Menesthius-1 Il. 7.8; in the assembly refuses to give up Helen Il. 7.355; wounds Diomedes with an arrow Il. 11.369, wounds Machaon with an arrow 505, wounds Eurypylus-2 with an arrow 581; kills Euchenor Il. 13.660, kills Deiochus Il. 15.341; Hector prophesies death to Achilles at the hands of Paris and Apollo Il. 22.359; how he flouted the goddesses Il. 24.28: etc.
Παρνησός A mountain of Phocis under which Delphi (Πυθώ) lay. Autolycus dwelt by it Od. 19.432, Od. 24.332. Παρνησόνδε [-δε], to Parnassus Od. 19.394 , 411, 466, Od. 21.220.
Παρρασίη A town of Arcadia Il. 2.608.
Πασιθέη A grace beloved by Hypnos Il. 14.269, promised to him by Hera 276.

Πάτροκλος -ου. Also genit. Πατροκλῆος 554 , Il. 17.670, Il. 23.65, 105, 221: Od. 11.468, Od. 24.16. Acc. -ῆα 602, Il. 16.125, 818, Il. 22.331. Voc. -εες 337, Il. 11.823, Il. 16.7, 126, etc. (ἄλκιμος, ἀμύμων, διΐφιλος, διογενής, δῖος, θεόφιν μήστωρ ἀτάλαντος , ἱππεύς, ἱπποκέλευθος , μεγαλήτωρ, Πατροκλῆος λάσιον κῆρ). Patronymic Μενοιτιάδης. Son of Menoetius and comrade of Achilles. Brings out Briseis at the bidding of Achilles Il. 1.337, 345; present with Achilles when the embassy arrives Il. 9.190; summoned by Achilles to ascertain who was the wounded man who passed with Nestor Il. 11.602, reaches Nestor's hut 644, on his way back encounters and succours the wounded Eurypylus-2 807 , Il. 15.390; delivers Nestor's appeal to Achilles Il. 16.2; arms at the bidding of Achilles Il. 16.126, and falls on the foe 257, fights with Sarpedon 427, slays him 480; against Achilles's advice drives the foe too far Il. 16.684, approaches the city 703, but retires before Apollo 710; Apollo brings about his end Il. 16.787, he is wounded by Euphorbus 806, mortally wounded by Hector 818, prophesies Hector's death 843, dies 855; the fight over his body Il. 17.1; Achilles hears of his death Il. 18.15; his corpse is rescued Il. 18.231; the lament of Briseis Il. 19.282; his spirit appears to Achilles Il. 23.65, the material for the pyre collected 110, the pyre 163, the winds summoned to make it burn 192, the funeral games 262; how he had been brought by Menoetius to the house of Peleus Il. 23.85 ; etc.: Od. 3.110; in the Shades Od. 11.468, Od. 24.16; Od. 24.77, 79 .
Παφλαγόνες Trojan. (μεγάθυμοι ἀσπισταί, μεγαλήτορες). The Paphlagonians, a people of the south shore of the Euxine between Heracleia and Cape Carambis Il. 2.851 , Il. 5.577, Il. 13.656, 661.
Πάφος In Cyprus. A seat of Aphrodite Od. 8.363.
Πειραΐδης Patronymic of Ptolemaeus Il. 4.228.
Πείραιος (δουρικλυτός). Patronymic Κλυτίδης-2. Son of Clytius-2. A comrade of Telemachus to whom Telemachus committed Theoclymenus Od. 15.539, 540, 544, Od. 17.55, 71, 74, 78, Od. 20.372.

Πειρίθοος (ἐρικυδής, θεόφιν μήστωρ ἀτάλαντος, μεγάθυμος). A Lapith. Son of Zeus and Dia (see Ἰξιόνιος), husband of Hippodameia-1 and father of Polypoetes Il. 2.741 ; Eurytion's disturbance at his marriage and the expulsion of the Centaurs Il. 2.742: Od. 21.296, 298; a warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.263: Od. 11.631; Il. 12.129, 182, Il. 14.318.
Πείροος Πείρως. Genit. Πείρεω 484. Trojan. Patronymic Ἰμβρασίδης. Father of Rhigmus. A leader of the Thracians Il. 2.844; slays Diores-1 Il. 4.520, 525, killed by Thoas-1 527; Od. 3.484.
Πείσανδρος-1 Trojan. Son of Antimachus. With his brother Hippolochus-2 killed by Agamemnon Il. 11.122 , 143.
Πείσανδρος-2 Trojan. killed by Menelaus Il. 13.601, 606, 611.
Πείσανδρος-3 (ἀρήϊος). Patronymic Μαιμαλίδης. A leader under Achilles Il. 16.193.
Πείσανδρος-4 (ἄναξ). Patronymic Πολυκτορίδης. One of the suitors. His gift to Penelope Od. 18.299; Od. 22.243. Killed by Philoetius Od. 22.268.
Πεισηνορίδης Patronymic of Ops Od. 1.429 , Od. 2.347, Od. 20.148.
Πεισήνωρ-1. Father of Cleitus-1 Il. 15.445.
Πεισήνωρ-2. An Ithacan herald Od. 2.38.

Πεισίστρατος (ἐϋμμελίης, ὄρχαμος ἀνδρῶν ). Patronymic Νεστορίδης. Son of Nestor. Greets Telemachus at Pylus Od. 3.36; Od. 3.400, 415, 454; accompanies Telemachus to Sparta Od. 3.482; at Sparta Od. 4.1, 155; eager for departure Telemachus rouses him Od. 15.46, 48; Od. 15.131, 166; they depart Od. 15.182, at Pylus takes Telemachus direct to the ship to avoid Nestor's hospitality 202 .
Πελάγων-1 Greek. (μέγας) Il. 4.295.
Πελάγων-2 Trojan. (ἴφθιμος). Comrade of Sarpedon, tended him when he was wounded Il. 5.695.
Πελασγικός Adj. from next of equally disputed meaning. Of Argus-2 Il. 2.681 . Of Zeus of Dodona Il. 16.233.

Πελασγοί Pelasgians, a name of much disputed meaning. T (ἐγχεσίμωροι) Applied to the men of Larisa Il. 2.840, 843, Il. 17.288 (in these two cases applied in sing. to Lethus). Also (δῖοι) to a section of the Trojan allies whose position is indicated by Dolon along with that of the Carians and others Il. 10.429. (δῖοι) In Odysseus's tale to Penelope applied to one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.177.

data.ref: Il. 17.288 (in these two cases applied in sing. to

definition: Πελίης Son of Poseidon and Tyro. Ruler of Iaolcus Od. 11.254, 256. Father of Alcestis Il. 2.715.
Πελλήνη A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.574.
Πέλοψ (πλήξιππος). Son of Tantalus and father of Atreus and Thyestes. The sceptre given to him by Hermes and by him to Atreus Il. 2.104, 105.
Περαιβοί Greek. (μενοπτόλεμοι). A people of north Thessaly led by Gouneus Il. 2.749.
Πέργαμος (ἱερή). The citadel of Troy containing (Il. 5.446) the temple of Apollo Il. 4.508, Il. 5.460 , Il. 6.512, Il. 7.21, Il. 24.700.
Περγασίδης Patronymic of Deicoon Il. 5.535.
Περίβοια-1. Daughter of Acessamenus and mother of Pelegon by the Axius Il. 21.142.
Περίβοια-2 (γυναικῶν εἶδος ἀρίστη). Daughter of Eurymedon-3 and mother of Nausithous by Poseidon Od. 7.57.
Περιήρης Father of Borus-2 Il. 16.177.
Περικλύμενος (ἀγέρωχος). Son of Neleus Od. 11.286.
Περιμήδης-1. Father of Schedius-2 Il. 15.515.
Περιμήδης-2. A comrade of Odysseus in his ship Od. 11.23, Od. 12.195.
Πέριμος Trojan. Patronymic Μεγάδης . Killed by Patroclus Il. 16.695.
Περίφας-1 (ἀγλαός, πελώριος ). An Aetolian, son of Ochesius. Killed by Ares Il. 5.842 , 847.
Περίφας-2. Patronymic Ἠπυτίδης. A Trojan herald. Apollo addresses Aeneas in his form Il. 17.323.
Περιφήτης-1 Trojan. killed by Teucrus Il. 14.515.
Περιφήτης-2 Greek. (Μυκηναῖος). Son of Copreus. Killed by Hector Il. 15.638.
Περκώσιος Adj. from next Il. 2.831, Il. 6.30, Il. 11.329.
Περκώτη A town of the Troad not far from the mouth of the Practius Il. 2.835, Il. 11.229, Il. 15.548.
Περσεύς-1 (πάντων ἀριδείκετος ἀνδρῶν). Son of Zeus by Danae and father of Sthenelus-2 Il. 14.320.
Περσεύς-2. Son of Nestor Od. 3.414 , 444.

Περσεφόνεια (ἀγαυή, ἁγνή, Διὸς θυγάτηρ, ἐπαινή). Daughter of Zeus and Demeter (it is no doubt to be understood that it was to the union in Il. 14.326 that she owed her being) and wife of Hades Il. 9.457, 569 : Od. 10.491, 494, 509, 534, 564, Od. 11.47, 213, 217, 226, 386, 635.

data.ref: Il. 14.326 that she owed her being) and wife of Hades

definition: Πέρση Daughter of Oceanus and mother by Eelius of Aeetes and Circe Od. 10.139 .
Περσηϊάδης Patronymic from Περσεύς-1. Of Sthenelus-2 Il. 19.116, 123.
Πετεών A Boeotian town Il. 2.500.
Πετεώς -εῶο (διοτρεφὴς βασιλεύς). Father of Menestheus Il. 2.552, Il. 4.327, 338 , Il. 12.331, 355, Il. 13.690.
Πήδαιον A town, apparently of the Troad, not identified Il. 13.172 .
Πήδαιος Trojan. Bastard son of Antenor. Killed by Meges Il. 5.69 .
Πήδασος-1 (ἀμπελόεσσα). A town of Pylus Il. 9.152 , 294.
Πήδασος-2 (αἰπεινή, αἰπήεσσα ). A town of the southern Troad on the Satnioeis probably to be identified with Assus opposite the northern end of Lesbos Il. 6.35; taken by Achilles Od. 3.92; Il. 21.87.
Πήδασος-3 Trojan. Son of Boucolion and Abarbaree. With his twin brother Aesepus-2 killed by Euryalus-1 Il. 6.21 .
Πήδασος-4 (ἀμύμων). One of the horses of Achilles, taken by him at Thebe-2 Il. 16.152. Killed by Sarpedon Il. 16.467.
Πηλεγών (κλυτὸς ἔγχεϊ). Son of the Axius and Periboea-1 and father of Asteropaeus Il. 21.141 , 152, 159.
Πηληϊάδης = next. Of Achilles Il. 1.146 , Il. 15.64, Il. 16.271, Il. 17.105, Il. 18.170, Il. 19.83, etc.: Od. 8.75.

Πηλεΐων Patronymic from next. Of Achilles Il. 1.188 , Il. 2.674, Il. 8.474, Il. 9.181, Il. 10.323, Il. 13.113, etc.: Od. 5.310, Od. 11.470, 551, Od. 24.18, 23. Πηλεΐωνάδε [-δε], to Achilles Il. 24.338 .

Πηλεύς (ἀμύμων, ἄναξ, γέρων, δαΐφρων, ἱππηλάτα, ἱππότα). Patronymic Αἰακίδης. King of Argus-2. Son of Aeacus, husband of Thetis, and father of Achilles and Polydora. His charge to his son Il. 9.252, Il. 11.783; he received the fugitive Phoenix-1 Il. 9.480; the visit to him of Nestor and Odysseus Il. 11.769 ; his (and Achilles') immortal horses Il. 16.381, 867, Il. 17.443, Il. 23.278; Epeigeus came as a suppliant to him and Thetis Il. 16.574; his armour, given by the gods Il. 18.84; his parentage Il. 21.189; he received the fugitive Patroclus Il. 23.89; his riches and good fortune Il. 24.534; etc.: Od. 11.478, 494, 505, Od. 24.36.
Πηληϊάδης Patronymic from prec. Of Achilles Il. 1.1 , 322, Il. 9.166, Il. 16.269, 653, 686, Il. 24.406, 431, 448: Od. 11.467, 557, Od. 24.15.
Πηλήϊος Adj. from Πηλεύς. Of or pertaining to Peleus Il. 18.60, 441.
Πηλιάς Adj. from next. Of or from Pelion. Of the spear of Achilles given to Peleus by Cheiron Il. 16.143, Il. 19.390, Od. 3.277, Il. 21.162, Il. 22.133.

Πήλιον (εἰνοσίφυλλον). A mountain in Magnesia, southeast of Ossa. The Centaurs driven from it by Peirithous Il. 2.744 (cf. Od. 21.295-304); Il. 2.757 ; the spear of Achilles came thence Il. 16.144, Il. 19.391: the threat of Otus-1 and Ephialtes to pile Ossa on Olympus and Pelion on Ossa Od. 11.315.
Πηνειός (ἀργυροδίνης). A river of Thessaly reaching the sea through the Vale of Tempe Il. 2.752, 753, 757.
Πηνέλεως -έωο (ἄναξ, δαΐφρων) . A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.494; Il. 13.92; slays Ilioneus Il. 14.487, 489, 496; slays Lycon Il. 16.335 , 340; wounded by Poulydamas Il. 17.597.

Πηνελόπεια (ἐχέφρων, περίφρων , πολύδωρος). Daughter of Icarius-2, sister of Iphthime, wife of Odysseus and mother of Telemachus. Bids Phemius change his song Od. 1.328; her stratagem in the matter of the web Od. 2.94, Od. 19.138, Od. 24.129; hears of her son's departure and of the plot against him Od. 4.675; appears to the suitors and rebukes Antinous Od. 16.409, is put off with fair words by Eurymachus 434; welcomes her son home Od. 17.36, he tells her his story 108; she hears the disguised Odysseus being struck Od. 17.492; summons Odysseus Od. 17.508, who declines to come at that time 560; she appears again in the μέγαρον beautified (Od. 18.187) by Athene Od. 18.158, rebukes her son 215, relates to Eurymachus Odysseus's parting charge 250, suggests gifts 274, which are sent for 290; when the suitors have gone appears again Od. 19.53, rebukes Melantho 89 , converses with Ο. 103, bids Eurycleia wash him 357, he interprets Penelope's dream 535; she sets down the bow, etc., for the contest Od. 21.1; is summoned by Eurycleia after the destruction of the suitors Od. 23.1, cannot clearly recognize Ο. 85, to convince her he speaks of his bed 171, she recognizes him fully 205, the pair retire 289, he relates his adventures to her 310, his charge to her before leaving the city 350; etc.

data.ref: Od. 17.508, who declines to come at that time

definition: Πηρείη Said to have been in Thessaly. The horses of Eumelus reared there Il. 2.766.
Πηρώ (ἰφθίμη, θαῦμα βροτοῖσιν ). Daughter of Neleus. Her father's requirement of her suitors Od. 11.287.
Πιδύτης Trojan. killed by Odysseus Il. 6.30.
Πιερίη A district lying to the north of the Thessalian Mt. Olympus Il. 14.226 : Od. 5.50.
Πιτθεύς Father of Aethra Il. 3.144.
Πιτύεια Probably to be identified with Lampsacus (the modern Lampsaki) on the Hellespont Il. 2.829 .
Πλαγκταί The wandering (πλάζω) or the dashing (πλήσσω) rocks (represented also as smoking Od. 12.202) Od. 12.61, Od. 23.327.
Πλάκος (ὑλήεσσα). A mountain dominating Thebe-2 Il. 6.396, 425, Il. 22.479.
Πλάταια A Boeotian town Il. 2.504.
Πλευρών A town of Aetolia Il. 2.639, Il. 13.217, Il. 14.116.
Πλευρώνιος Adj. from prec. Of Ancaeus-2 Il. 23.635.
Πληϊάδες The Pleiades, a cluster of stars in the constellation Taurus Il. 18.486: Od. 5.272.
Ποδαλείριος (ἰητὴρ ἀγαθός). Son of Asclepius. With his brother Machaon chief surgeon of the Greeks and leader of the men of Tricca, etc. Il. 2.732, Il. 11.833.
Ποδάργη Dam of Xanthus-5 and Balius (see Ἅρπυια in Lex.) Il. 16.150, Il. 19.400 .
Πόδαργος-1. One of Hector's horses Il. 8.185.
Πόδαργος-2. One of Menelaus's horses Il. 23.295.

Ποδάρκης (μενοπτόλεμος, ὄζος Ἄρηος ). Son of Iphiclus-1 and younger brother german of Protesilaus. On Podarces's death succeeded to his leadership Il. 2.704, Il. 13.693 (his followers here called Φθῖοι).
Ποδῆς Trojan. (ἀφνειός τʼ ἀγαθός τε). Son of Eetion-2 and boon companion of Hector Il. 17.575. Killed by Menelaus Il. 17.578; Il. 17.590.
Ποιάντιος (Son) of Poeas. Of Philoctetes Od. 3.190.
Πολίτης-1 (βοὴν ἀγαθός). Son of Priam and Hecabe. Swift of foot Il. 2.791; Il. 13.533, Il. 15.339, Il. 24.250.
Πολίτης-2 (ὄρχαμος ἀνδρῶν). One of the companions of Odysseus in his ship Od. 10.224.
Πολυαιμονίδης Patronymic of Amopaon Il. 8.276.
Πόλυβος-1 Trojan. Patronymic Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor Il. 11.59.
Πόλυβος-2 (δαΐφρων). Father of Eurymachus Od. 1.399, Od. 2.177, Od. 15.519, Od. 18.349, Od. 21.320, etc.
Πόλυβος-3. Dwelt in Thebes-2. The presents given by him and his wife Alcandra to Menelaus and Helen Od. 4.126.
Πόλυβος-4 (δαΐφρων). Made the ball with which the Phaeacians played Od. 8.373.
Πόλυβος-5 (δαΐφρων). One of the suitors Od. 22.243. Killed by Eumaeus Od. 22.284.
Πολύδαμνα Wife of the Egyptian Thon. Her gift of drugs to Helen Od. 4.228.
Πολυδεύκης (κρατερόφρων, πὺξ ἀγαθός ). Son of Tyndareus and Leda, brother of Castor-1 and Clytaemnestra and half-brother of Helen. See under Κάστωρ-1.
Πολυδώρη (καλή). Daughter of Peleus, wife of Borus-2, and by the Spercheius mother of Menesthius-2 Il. 16.175.
Πολύδωρος-1 (ἀντίθεος). Patronymic Πριαμίδης. Son of Priam and Laothoe and brother of Lycaon-2. Killed by Achilles Od. 3.407, 419, Il. 21.91 ; Il. 22.46.
Πολύδωρος-2. Nestor beat him at spear-throwing Il. 23.637.
Πολυθερσεΐδης Patronymic of Ctesippus Od. 22.287.
Πολύϊδος-1 Trojan. Son of Eurydamas-1. With his brother A bas killed by Diomedes Il. 5.148.
Πολύϊδος-2 (ἀγαθός, μάντις). Father of Euchenor Il. 13.663, 666.
Πολυκάστη (καλή). Nestor's youngest daughter. Washed Telemachus Od. 3.464.
Πολυκτορίδης Patronymic of Peisandrus-4 Od. 18.299, Od. 22.243.
Πολύκτωρ-1 (ἀφνειός). Given as his father's name by the disguised Hermes to Priam Il. 24.397 .
Πολύκτωρ-2. See Ἴθακος.
Πολυμήλη (χορῷ καλή). Daughter of Phylas and by Hermes mother of Eudorus. Afterwards wife of Echeclees Il. 16.180.
Πολύμηλος Trojan. Patronymic Ἀργεάδης . Killed by Patroclus Il. 16.417.
Πολυνείκης (ἀντίθεος). Son of Oedipodes and Epicaste. Asks the Mycenaeans for aid in attacking his brother Eteocles Il. 4.377.
Πολύνηος Patronymic Τεκτονίδης. Father of Amphialus Od. 8.114.
Πολύξεινος (θεοειδής). Son of Agasthenes and a leader of the Epeians Il. 2.624.
Πολυπημονίδης Patronymic of Apheidas Od. 24.305.

Πολυποίτης (κρατερός, μενοπτόλεμος ). Son of Peirithous and Hippodameia-1. With Leonteus leader of the men of Argissa, etc. Il. 2.740 ; Il. 6.29; his defence with Leonteus of the wall Il. 12.129, 182; wins the prize in putting the weight Il. 23.836, 844, 848.
Πολυφείδης (ὑπέρθυμος). Son of Mantius and father of Theoclymenus Od. 15.249, 256; succeeded Amphiaraus in his seership Od. 15.252; fled to Hyperesia Od. 15.254.

Πολύφημος-1, also called simply Κύκλωψ (ἄγριος, ἀθεμίστια εἰδώς , ἀνδροφάγος, ἀντίθεος , κρατερός, μεγαλήτωρ , μένος ἄσχετος, πέλωρ ). One of the Cyclopes (q.v.), son of Poseidon and Thoosa (Od. 1.71). Had only one eye (Od. 9.333, 383 , 397). Odysseus visits his cave in his absence Od. 9.216; his cave and flocks described Od. 9.218; he returns to the cave and finds Odysseus and his companions there Od. 9.233; his greeting and subsequent barbarous behaviour Od. 9.252 ; is blinded Od. 9.371; Odysseus and his surviving companions escape him Od. 9.424; he prays to Poseidon for vengeance Od. 9.528; etc.
Πολύφημος-2 (ἀντίθεος). A warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.264.
Πολυφήτης Trojan. (ἀντίθεος). Il. 13.791.
Πολυφόντης (μενοπτόλεμος). Son of Autophonus. With Maeon leader of the ambush at Thebes-1 against Tydeus Il. 4.395.
Ποντεύς A Phaeacian Od. 8.113 .
Ποντόνοος θεράπων of Alcinous Od. 7.179, 182 , Od. 8.65, Od. 13.50, 53.
Πορθεύς Father of Agrius, Melas and Oeneus, and grandfather of Tydeus and Meleagrus Il. 14.115 .

Ποσειδάων (ἄναξ, γαιήοχος, ἐννοσίγαιος, γαιήοχος ἐ., κλυτὸς ἐ., ἐνοσίχθων, κρείων ἐ., εὐρυσθενής, κυανοχαίτης). Son of Cronus and Rhea, and brother of Zeus, Hades, Hera and Demeter. Father (1) by Iphimedeia of Otus-1 and Ephialtes; (2) by Periboea-2 of Nausithous; (3) by Tyro of Neleus and Pelias; (4) by Thoosa of Polyphemus-1, and (5) of Cteatus and Eurytus-2. By lot (Il. 15.187, 190) got the sea as his realm. With Hera and Athene tried to put Zeus in bonds Il. 1.399; complains to Zeus of the building of the Greek wall Il. 7.445, with Apollo subsequently destroys the wall Il. 12.17, 34; proceeds from Samothrace to the ships Il. 13.10, and encourages the Greeks 43, retires by order of Zeus Il. 15.218; in the Battle of the Gods challenges Apollo Il. 21.436, who declines 461; etc.: his bitterness against Odysseus on account of his son Polyphemus-1 Od. 1.20, 68; Telemachus finds the Pylians sacrificing to him Od. 3.4; destroys Aias-2 on the Gyraean rock Od. 4.502 ; raises the sea against Odysseus on his passage to Phaeacia Od. 5.291, Od. 7.271 ; in the tale of Demodocus releases Ares Od. 8.344; lay with Tyro in the Enipeus Od. 11.241; lay with Iphimedeia Od. 11.305; turns the Phaeacian ship to stone Od. 13.159; etc.

data.ref: 190) got the sea as his realm.

definition: Ποσιδήϊος Adj. from prec. Il. 2.506. In neut. Ποσιδήϊον, a temple of Poseidon Od. 6.266.

Πουλυδάμας (ἀγαπήνωρ, ἀγαυός , ἀμώμητος, ἀμύμων , ἐγχέσπαλος, μεγάθυμος , πεπνυμένος). Patronymic Πανθοΐδης. Son of Panthous. Comrade of, and born in the same night with, Hector; excelled in counsel (Il. 18.249). Advises against attempting the ditch with chariots Il. 12.60 ; unsuccessfully advises Hector to give up the attack Il. 12.210; advises Hector to retire Il. 13.725; slays Prothoenor-2 Il. 14.449; slays Mecisteus-2 Il. 15.339; slays Otus-2 Il. 15.518 ; eludes the spear of Meges Il. 15.521; wounds Peneleos Il. 17.600; unsuccessfully advises Hector to retire to the city Il. 18.249; etc.
Πράκτιος A river (now Bergaz Chai) flowing into the Hellespont on the Asiatic side Il. 2.835.
Πράμνειος Applied to a wine of unknown growth Il. 11.639: Od. 10.235.

Πριαμίδης Patronymic from next. Of Hector Il. 2.817 , Il. 5.684, Il. 7.112, Il. 11.295, Il. 13.40, Il. 15.597, Il. 17.449, Od. 3.77, etc. Of Paris Il. 3.356 . Of Antiphus-3 Il. 4.490. Of Helenus-1 Il. 6.76 , Il. 13.586. Of Doryclus Il. 11.490. Of Deiphobus Il. 13.157. Of Lycaon-2 Od. 3.87 . Of Polydorus-1 Od. 3.408.

Πρίαμος (ἀγακλεής, ἄναξ, γέρων, δαΐφρων, διοτρεφὴς βασιλεύς, ἐϋμμελίης , θεοειδής, θεόφιν μήστωρ ἀτάλαντος, μεγαλήτωρ, μέγας). Patronymic Δαρδανίδης, Λαομεδοντιάδης. King of Troy. Son of Laomedon, grandson of Ilus-1, and great-grandson of Trus-1, who was son of Erichthonius, who was son of Dardanus-1, who was son of Zeus. Father (1) by Hecabe of Deiphobus, Hector, Helenus-1, Laodice-1, Paris and Polites-1; also (though Hecabe is not here named) of Cassandra; (2) by Castianeira of Gorgythion; (3) by Laothoe of Lycaon-2 and Polydorus-1; (4) by unnamed mothers of Agathon, Antiphonus, Antiphus-3, Chromius-2 and his brother Echemmon, Dius , Hippothous-2, Mestor, Pammon, and Troilus; and (5) of Cebriones, Democoon, Doryclus, Isus and Medesicaste, all described as bastards. At the beginning of the war had fifty sons Il. 24.495 (cf Il. 6.244), eleven of whom were by one mother, presumably by Hecabe Il. 24.496. Twelve daughters and their husbands lived with him Il. 6.248 . Sitting on the wall he summons Helen to point out the Greek chiefs Il. 3.161; is summoned to the plain to perform the oath-sacrifice Il. 3.250 , returns 303; his palace described Il. 6.242; advises sending to the Greeks to propose a truce for the burning of the dead Il. 7.368; his charge to the gate-keepers Il. 21.526; sees Hector in danger from Achilles Il. 22.25, and vainly beseeches him to take refuge 38; Iris sent by Zeus bids him go to the ships to ransom Hector's corpse Il. 24.171, Hecabe vainly dissuades him 201, his sons prepare his chariot 265, he departs 322, he encounters Hermes 349, he reaches the hut of Achilles 448, who receives him graciously 507, he retires to rest 643, he returns to the city with the corpse 689; etc.: Od. 3.107, 130, Od. 5.106, Od. 11.421, 533, Od. 13.316, Od. 14.241, Od. 22.230.

data.ref: Il. 6.244), eleven of whom were by one mother, presumably by

definition: Προθοήνωρ-1. A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.495.
Προθοήνωρ-2 Greek. Son of Areilycus-1. Killed by Poulydamas Il. 14.450, 471.
Πρόθοος (θός). Son of Tenthredon and leader of the Magnetes Il. 2.756, 758.
Προθόων Trojan. killed by Teucrus Il. 14.515.
Προῖτος Husband of Anteia. (See under Βελλεροφόντης) Il. 6.157, 160, 163, 164, 177.

Πρόκρις Daughter of Erechtheus, king of Athens (grandson of the hero of the same name), and wife of Cephalus. She is siad to have been unwittingly killed by Cephalus with an unerring dart given to her by Artemis. Named Od. 11.321.
Πρόμαχος Patronymic Ἀλεγηνορίδης. A Boeotian. Killed by Acamas-1 Il. 14.476, 482, 503.
Πρόνοος Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.399.
Προτιάων Father of Astynous-2 Il. 15.455.
Πρυμνεύς A Phaeacian Od. 8.112 .
Πρύτανις Trojan. killed by Odysseus Il. 5.678.
Πρωρεύς A Phaeacian Od. 8.113 .

Πρωτεσίλαος (ἀρήϊος, μεγάθυμος ). Son of Iphiclus-1 and elder brother german of Podarces. Leader of the men of various towns lying about the west coast of the Pagasaean Gulf. Was slain in landing first of the Greeks and was succeeded by Podarces Il. 2.698, 706, 708; the position of his ships Il. 13.681; fighting round his ship Il. 15.705; the ship set on fire Il. 16.122, the fire extinguished 286, 293 .

Πρωτεύς (Αἰγύπτιος, γέρων ἅλιος νημερτής, ἴφθιμος). The Old Man of the Sea, a servant of Poseidon and father of Eidothee Od. 4.365, 385; his transformations on being seized in Pharos by Menelaus and his comrades Od. 4.454, his advice to Μ. 471, tells of the fates of Aias-2and Agamemnon 491.
Πρωτώ A Nereid Il. 18.43 .
Πτελεός-1 A town of Pylus Il. 2.594 .
Πτελεός-2 (λεχεποίης). A town of the realm of Protesilaus Il. 2.697.
Πτολεμαῖος Patronymic Πειραΐδης. Father of Eurymedon-1 Il. 4.228.
Πυγμαῖοι A supposed (dwarfish) race represented as warred on by cranes Il. 3.6.
Πυθώ (ἠγαθέη, πετρήεσσα ). A town of Phocis, later called Delphi Il. 2.519, Il. 9.405: Od. 8.80. Πυθώδε [-δε], to Pytho Od. 11.581.

Πυλαιμένης (ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, Πυλαιμένεος λάσιον κῆρ). Father of Harpalion and leader of the Paphlagonians Il. 2.851 . Killed by Menelaus Il. 5.576; Il. 13.643. (He is represented as alive in Il. 13.658.)

data.ref: Il. 13.643. (He is represented as alive in

definition: Πύλαιος Trojan. (ὄζος Ἄρηος). Son of Lethus. A leader of the Pelasgians (1) Il. 2.842.
Πυλάρτης-1 Trojan. Killed by Aias-1 Il. 11.491.
Πυλάρτης-2 Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.696.
Πυλήνη A town of Aetolia Il. 2.639.
Πυλοιγενής See Lexicon.

Πύλος (αἰπὺ (ἐϋκτίμενον) πτολίεθρον, ἠγαθέη, ἠμαθόεις, ἱερή, Νηλήϊος). Nestor's capital and kindom, on the west coast of the Peloponnesus, of uncertain site Il. 1.252, 269, Il. 2.77, 591, Il. 9.153, 295, Il. 11.682, 689, 712, 716: Od. 1.93, 284, Od. 2.214, 308, 326, 359, Od. 3.4, 485, Od. 4.599, 633, 639, 702, 713, Od. 5.20, Od. 11.257, 285, 459, Od. 14.180, Od. 15.42, 193, 226, 236, 541, Od. 16.131, Od. 17.109, Od. 21.108, Od. 24.152, 430. Πύλονδε [-δε], to Pylos Il. 11.760: Od. 2.317, Od. 3.182, Od. 4.656, Od. 13.274, Od. 16.24, 142 , Od. 17.42. Πυλόθεν [-θεν], from Pylos Od. 16.323. In Il. 5.397 apparently a different Pylos is meant.

data.ref: Il. 5.397 apparently a different Pylos is meant.

definition: Πύλων Trojan. killed by Polypoetes Il. 12.187.
Πυραίχμης Leader of the Paeonians Il. 2.848. Killed by Patroclus Il. 16.287.
Πύρασος-1 (ἀνθεμόεις). A town in the realm of Protesilaus with a τέμενος of Demeter Il. 2.695.
Πύρασος-2 Trojan. Killed by Aias-1 Il. 11.491.
Πύρις Trojan. killed by Patroclus Il. 16.416.
Πυριφλεγέθων See Κώκυτος.

Ῥαδάμανθυς (ἀντίθεος, ξανθός ). Son of Zeus and Europa (daughter of Phoenix-2) and brother of Minos Il. 14.322: in Elysium Od. 4.564; the Phaeacians conveyed him to visit Tityus, apparently in Euboea Od. 7.323.
Ῥεία Ῥέα. By Cronus mother of Zeus, Hades, Poseidon, Hera and Demeter Il. 14.203, Il. 15.187.
Ῥεῖθρον A harbour of Ithaca Od. 1.186.
Ῥήνη Mother by Oeleus-1 of Medon-1 Il. 2.728.
Ῥηξήνωρ (ἀντίθεος). Son of Nausithous, brother of Alcinous, and father of Arete. No male heir Od. 7.63; Od. 7.146 .
Ῥῆσος-1. King of the Thracians; son of Eioneus-2. His horses Il. 10.435, he and his comrades killed by Diomedes and Odysseus 474, 494, 519.
Ῥῆσος-2. An unknown river Il. 12.20.
Ῥίγμος Trojan. (ἀμύμων). Son of Peiroos. Killed by Achilles Od. 3.485.
Ῥίπη A town of Arcadia Il. 2.606.
Ῥοδίος An unknown river Il. 12.20.
Ῥόδιοι Greek. (ἀγέρωχοι). The Rhodians Il. 2.654 .
Ῥόδος Rhodes Il. 2.654, 655, 667.
Ῥύτιος (εὖ ναιετόωσα). A city of Crete Il. 2.648 .
Σαγγάριος A river flowing through Phrygia and falling into the Euxine Il. 3.187, Il. 16.719.
Σαλαμίς The island home of Aias-1 Il. 2.557, Il. 7.199.
Σαλμωνεύς (ἀμύμων). Father of Tyro Od. 11.236 .

Σάμη (with u.l. Σάμος 246, Od. 9.24, Od. 16.249), Σάμος-2 Il. 2.634 )with u.l. Σάμη(· 671, 845, Od. 15.29. Mod. Cephallenia, Cephalonia (παιπαλόεσσα). An island forming part of the realm of Odysseus Il. 2.634. In Od. associated with Doulichium, Zacynthus and Ithaca Od. 1.246, Od. 9.24, Od. 16.123, 249, Od. 19.131. The home of Ctesippus Od. 20.288. The channel between Ithaca and Samos Od. 4.671, 845, Od. 15.29. Σάμηνδε [-δε], to Samos Od. 15.367.
Σάμος-1 (ὑλήεσσα). The Thracian Samos, Samothrace Il. 24.78, 753. So Σ. Θρηϊκίη 12.

Σαρπηδών (ἀντίθεος, δῖος, χαλκοκορυστής). Son of Zeus by Laodameia (Il. 6.199) and with Glaucus-2 leader of the Lycians Il. 2.876; reproves Hector Il. 5.471, 493; is wounded by Tlepolemus-1 and slays him Il. 5.629, 633, 647, 655, 658, 663, Hector neglects him 683, he is rescued by his comrades 692; Il. 12.101, 292 , 307; his address to Glaucus-2 Il. 12.310; Il. 12.379, 392; breaks the wall Il. 12.397; Il. 14.426; Zeus foretells his death Il. 15.67; Il. 16.327, 419 , 433, 445, 464; wounds the horse Pedasus-4 Il. 16.466; misses Patroclus Il. 16.477; is mortally wounded by Patroclus Il. 16.479, appeals to Glaucus-2 492, 496, dies 502; Il. 16.522, 533, 541; the fight over his body Il. 16.553, 559, 638, 649, it is taken by the Greeks and stripped 663, Zeus charges Apollo with his funeral rites 667, 678; Il. 17.150, 162; Achilles sets down his armour as a prize Il. 23.800.
Σατνιόεις (ἐϋρρείτης). A river of the southern Troad falling into the Aegean a little north of Cape Lecton Il. 6.34, Il. 14.445, Il. 21.87.
Σάτνιος Trojan. Patronymic Ἠνοπίδης. Son of Enops-1 and a naiad. Killed by Aias-2 Il. 14.443.

Σειρῆνες (ἁδιναί, θεσπέσιαι ). Mythical beings (apparently from the dual (Od. 12.52, 167) two in number) with irresistibly seductive voices. Described Od. 12.39, 42, 44, 52, 158; Odysseus passes their island safely Od. 12.167, 198, Od. 23.326.

data.ref: 167) two in number) with irresistibly seductive voices.

definition: Σέλαγος (πολυκτήμων πολυλήϊος). Father of Amphius-2; dwelt in Paesus Il. 5.612.
Σεληπιάδης Patronymic of Euenus Il. 2.693.
Σελλήεις-1. A river of the Troad not identified Il. 2.839, Il. 12.97.
Σελλήεις-2. A river in the country of the next, or according to others in Elis Il. 2.659, Il. 15.531.
Σελλοί v.l. σʼ Ἑλλοί (ἀνιπτόποδες χαμαιεῦναι) . The interpreters or priests of the oracle of Zeus at Dodona Il. 16.234 .
Σεμέλη Daughter of Cadmus and by Zeus mother of Dionysus Il. 14.323, 325 .
Σήσαμος A Paphlagonian town Il. 2.853.
Σηστός A city on the northwest of the Hellespont, a little above Abydus on the other side Il. 2.836.
Σθενέλαος Trojan. Son of Ithaemenes. Killed by Patroclus Il. 16.586.

Σθένελος-1 (ἀγλαός). Patronymic Καπανηϊάδης. Son of Capaneus and companion of Diomedes Il. 2.564; acting as chariot-driver to Diomedes Il. 4.367, 403, Il. 5.108, 111, 241, 319, 835, Il. 8.114; drives off Aeneas's horses Il. 5.319; replies to Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.403, is rebuked by Diomedes 411; Il. 9.48, Il. 23.511 .
Σθένελος-2. Patronymic Περσηϊάδης. Son of Perseus-1 and father of Eurystheus Il. 19.116 , 123.
Σιδόνες See Σιδόνιοι.
Σιδονίη Σιδών Od. 15.425 (εὖ ναιομένη, πολύχαλκος ). A maritime city of Phoenicia Od. 13.285, Od. 15.425. Σιδονίηθεν [-θεν], from Sidonia Il. 6.291.
Σιδόνιοι Σιδόνες Il. 23.743 (πολυδαίδαλοι). The inhabitants of prec., celebrated as craftsmen Il. 6.290 , Il. 23.743: visited by Menelaus Od. 4.84; Od. 4.618, Od. 15.118.
Σικανίη Perhaps the country in western Sicily inhabited by the Sicani of history Od. 24.307.

Σικελοί Perhaps a people on the coast of Italy opposite Ithaca and the same as the Siculi of history. Apparently they were slave-dealers Od. 20.383. In sing. of the female servant who attended to Laertes Od. 24.211, 366 , 389.
Σικυών (εὐρύχορος). In Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.572; the home of Echepolus-2 Il. 23.299.
Σιμόεις A river of the Trojan plain north of Troy Il. 4.475; its junction with the Scamander Il. 5.774; Il. 5.777, Il. 6.4, Il. 12.22, Od. 3.53, Il. 21.307.
Σιμοείσιος (ἠΐθεος θαλερός). Patronymic Ἀνθεμίδης. Son of Anthemion. Named from prec. (Il. 4.477). Killed by Aias-1 Il. 4.474, 488.
Σίντιες (ἀγριόφωνοι). The inhabitants of Lemnos Il. 1.594: Od. 8.294.
Σίπυλος A mountain of Lydia, a branch of Tmolus. Niobe turned to stone here Il. 24.615.
Σίσυφος (κέρδιστος ἀνδρῶν). Patronymic Αἰολίδης. King of Ephyra-2. Father of Glaucus-1 Il. 6.153, 154: tormented in the Shades Od. 11.593.
Σκαιαί πύλαι. A gate of Troy, probably on the north west Il. 3.145, 149, Il. 6.237, 307, 393, Il. 9.354, Il. 11.170, Il. 16.712, Il. 18.453, Il. 22.6, 360. Σκαιαί alone Il. 3.263 .
Σκαμάνδριος-1 Trojan. (αἵμων θήρης). Son of Strophius. A great hunter. Killed by Menelaus Il. 5.49.
Σκαμάνδριος-2. Hector's name for Astyanax Il. 6.402.
Σκαμάνδριος-3. Adj. from next Il. 2.465, 467 .
Σκάμανδρος See Ξάνθος-1.
Σκάνδεια The port of Cythera Il. 10.268.
Σκάρφη A Locrian town Il. 2.532.

Σκύλλη (πετραίη). Daughter of Crataeis. A destructive female monster inhabiting a high rock opposite to the rock of Charybdis. The rock described Od. 12.73. Scylla described Od. 12.85; Od. 12.108, 125 , 223, 231; Odysseus passes between Scylla and Charybdis losing six comrades to Scylla Od. 12.235, 245, 261, Od. 23.328; Od. 12.310; Odysseus comes again to the rock Od. 12.430, escapes Σ. 445.
Σκῦρος-1. The Aegean island. Neoptolemus brought up there Il. 19.326: Odysseus took him thence to Troy Od. 11.509. Σκυρόθεν [-θεν], from Scyrus Il. 19.332.
Σκῦρος-2 (αἰπεῖα). A place (probably not the same as prec.) taken by Achilles Il. 9.668.
Σκῶλος A Boeotian town Il. 2.497.
Σμινθεύς The mouse-god, identified by the Greeks with Apollo . Called ἀργυρότοξος 37, 451. Protector of Chryse, Cilla and Tenedos Il. 1.39.

Σόλυμοι (κυδάλιμοι). Apparently a people inhabiting part of Lycia or a neighbouring country. Bellerophon's fight with them Il. 6.184; Isandrus killed fighting with them Il. 6.204: Poseidon descries Odysseus from their mountains Od. 5.283.
Σούνιον (ἱρόν). The southeast point of Attica Od. 3.278.

Σπάρτη (εὐρεῖα, καλλιγύναιξ ). The chief city of Lacedaemon Il. 2.582, Il. 4.52: Od. 1.93, Od. 2.214, 359, Od. 11.460, Od. 13.412. Σπάρτηνδε [-δε], to Sparta Od. 1.285. Σπάρτηθεν [-θεν], from Sparta Od. 2.327, Od. 4.10. See also Λακεδαίμων 2.
Σπειώ A Nereid Il. 18.40 .

Σπερχειός (ἀκάμας, διιπετὴς ποταμός ). A river flowing through Hellas into the Malian Gulf. Father by Polydora of Menesthius-2 Il. 16.174, 176; the lock of Achilles dedicated to the river Il. 23.142, 144.
Στέντωρ (μεγαλήτωρ χαλκεόφωνος). A Greek of very powerful voice Il. 5.785.
Στιχίος Greek. Il. 13.195, 691. Killed by Hector Il. 15.329.
Στρατίη A town of Arcadia Il. 2.606.
Στρατίος Son of Nestor Od. 3.413 , 439.
Στρόφιος Father of Scamandrius-1 Il. 5.49.
Στύμφηλος A town of Arcadia Il. 2.608.

Στύξ (ἀάατον Στυγὸς ὕδωρ, κατειβόμενον Στυγὸς ὕδωρ, ὅρκος δεινός, Στυγὸς αἰπὰ ῥέεθρα). The terrestrial Styx was a river and cataract in Arcadia (but the Titaressus is called (Il. 2.755) a branch of the Styx). The name transferred to the chief river of the underworld Il. 8.369: Od. 10.514. The Styx invoked in oaths (with apparently confusion between the upper and under rivers) Il. 2.755, Il. 14.271, Il. 15.37: Od. 5.185.

data.ref: Il. 2.755) a branch of the Styx).

definition: Στύρα τά. A town of Euboea Il. 2.539.
Σύμη An island to the north of Rhodes. Σύμηθεν [-θεν], from Syme Il. 2.671.
Συρίη A mythical island, the home of Eumaeus, apparently represented as to the north of Ortygia . Described Od. 15.403.
Σφῆλος Patronymic Βουκολίδης. Father of Iasus-1 Il. 15.338.
Σχεδίος-1. Son of Iphitus-1. With his brother Epistrophus-1 leader of the men of Phocis Il. 2.517. Killed by Hector Il. 17.306.
Σχεδίος-2. Son of Perimedes-1. Also described as a leader of the men of Phocis. Killed by Hector Il. 15.515.
Σχερίη (ἐρατεινή, ἐρίβωλος ). The new home of the Phaeacians to which (Od. 6.8) they were brought by Nausithous Od. 5.34 , Od. 7.79, Od. 13.160.
Σχοῖνος A Boeotian town Il. 2.497.
Σῶκος Trojan. (δαΐφρων, εὐηφενής , ἱππόδαμος, ἰσόθεος φώς ). Patronymic Ἱππασίδης-1. Son of Hippasus. Wounds and with his brother Charops is killed by Odysseus Il. 11.427 , 428, 440, 450, 456.
Ταλαιμένης By the Gygaean Lake father of Mesthles and Antiphus-2 Il. 2.865 .
Ταλαϊονίδης Patronymic of Mecisteus-1 Il. 2.566, Il. 23.678.

Ταλθύβιος (θεῷ ἐναλίγκιος αὐδήν, θεῖος, ὀτρηρός, πεπνυμένος). A herald of Agamemnon. Sent with Eurybates-1 to bring away Briseis Il. 1.320; sent to bring the Greek oath-sacrifice Il. 3.118; sent for Machaon to attend to Menelaus Il. 4.192, 193; with Idaeus-1 stops the fight between Aias-1 and Hector Il. 7.276; Il. 19.196, 250, 267, Il. 23.897.
Τάνταλος Son of Zeus and father of Pelops. Tormented in the Shades Od. 11.582.
Τάρνη (ἐριβῶλαξ). Apparently a town of the Maeonians (Μῄονες) 44.
Τάρταρος (βαθύς, ἠερόεις). The gulf in which the Titans were confined. Described Il. 8.13, 481.
Τάρφη A Locrian town Il. 2.533.
Τάφιοι (ληΐστορες, φιλήρετμοι ). The inhabitants of next, a piratical and slave-dealing race. Their king Mentes-2 Od. 1.105, 181, 419; Od. 14.452, Od. 15.427, Od. 16.426.
Τάφος The largest of a group of islands lying between the island Leucas and Acarnania Od. 1.417.
Τεγέη A town of Arcadia Il. 2.607.

Τειρεσίας (ἄναξ, μάντις ἀλαός ). The blind seer of Thebes-1. He only in the Shades had his mental powers unimpaired (Od. 10.493). Odysseus sent to the Shades by Circe to consult him Od. 10.490, 524, 537, 565, Od. 11.32, 50, 89, 165, 479, Od. 23.323; he appears to Odysseus Od. 11.90; his converse with Odysseus Od. 11.92, 139, 151; Odysseus remembers his advice Od. 12.267, 272; Odysseus relates to Penelope his advice and the troubles which he foretold Od. 23.248.
Τεκτονίδης Patronymic of Polyneus Od. 8.114.
Τέκτων Patronymic Ἁρμονίδης. Father of Phereclus Il. 5.59.
Τελαμών (ἀγαυός, ἀμύμων). Father of Aias-1 and Teucrus Il. 8.283, Il. 13.177, Il. 17.284, 293: Od. 11.553.
Τελαμωνιάδης Patronymic from prec. Of Aias-1 Il. 8.224 , Il. 9.623, Il. 11.7, Il. 13.709, Il. 15.289, Il. 17.235, Il. 18.193, etc.: Od. 11.543.
Τεμέση Perhaps in Cyprus Od. 1.184.

Τένεδος An Aegean island in sight of Troy Il. 1.38, 452; sacked by Achilles Il. 11.625; the cave between Tenedos and Imbros where Poseidon shackled his horses Il. 13.33: Nestor puts in there on his return from Troy Od. 3.159.
Τενθρηδών Father of Prothous Il. 2.756.
Τερπιάδης Patronymic of Phemius Od. 22.330.
Τευθρανίδης Patronymic of Axylus Il. 6.13.
Τεύθρας Greek. (ἀντίθεος). Killed by Hector Il. 5.705.

Τεῦκρος (ἀμύμων, ἄναξ, κοίρανος λαῶν). Son of Telamon. The Grecian bowman, apparently full brother of Aias-1 (see κασίγνητος 1.a in Lex.) Il. 6.31; shows his archery against the Trojans Il. 8.266, 273, 281, 292; aims at Hector Il. 8.300 , 309; Hector wounds him Il. 8.322, he is rescued by Aias-1 330; Il. 12.336, 350 , 363, 371, 372; wounds Glaucus-2 Il. 12.387, Il. 16.511, Glaucus-2 and Sarpedon Il. 12.400 ; Il. 13.91; slays Imbrius-1 Il. 13.170, 182; Il. 13.313 , Il. 14.515, Il. 15.302 , 437; aims at Hector Il. 15.458, but his string breaks 462, 466, 484; is beaten by Meriones in the archery contest Il. 23.859, 862, 883.
Τευταμίδης Patronymic of Lethus Il. 2.843.
Τηθύς (μήτηρ). Associated with Oceanus in the rearing of Hera Il. 14.201, 302.

Τηλέμαχος (δαΐφρων, θεοειδής , θεοείκελος, ἱερὴ ἲς Τηλεμάχοιο, κυδάλιμος, μεγάθυμος, μεγαλήτωρ, πεπνυμένος, φαίδιμος). Only child of Odysseus and Penelope. Referred to by his father at Troy Il. 2.260, Il. 4.354: in his absent father's house in Ithaca receives Athene who comes in the likeness of Mentes-2 Od. 1.113, she advises him to go to Pylus and Sparta 279; he calls an assembly Od. 2.1; prepares for the journey Od. 2.337, departs accompanied by Athene in the likeness of Mentor-2 413; they reach Pylus Od. 3.1 , he addresses Nestor 79, who bids him go to Sparta 323, he departs with Peisistratus 481; they reach Sparta Od. 4.1 , next day he tells Menelaus his errand 316, Menelaus detains him hospitably 587; Antinous and companions lie in wait for him at Asteris Od. 4.774, 842; Athene urges him to go home Od. 15.10, he and Peisistratus depart 182, on reaching Pylus Peisistratus goes to his home leaving Telemachus at the ship 193; Theoclymenus approaches him Od. 15.223, and is taken on board 279, they sail for Ithaca 284; Telemachus lands near Eumaeus's hut to avoid the suitors and dispatches the ship to the city Od. 15.495; he reaches the hut and finds his disguised father there Od. 16.11, his father reveals himself 187; he leaves him and departs for the city Od. 17.1, is received by the maids and Penelope 31, disposes of Theoclymenus 71, tells his mother how he has fared 108; his sneeze Od. 17.541; Penelope reproaches him for allowing ill usage of the disguised Odysseus Od. 18.215; he and Odysseus remove the arms Od. 19.4; he arranges the contest for the suitors Od. 21.118; he orders Eumaeus to give the bow to Ο. 369; arms for the fight and takes his stand beside his father Od. 21.431, kills Amphinomus Od. 22.91, brings arms 101, kills Euryades 267 , is wounded by and kills Amphimedon 277, kills Leocritus 294 , saves Phemius and Medon-3 354, carries out the slaying of the unfaithful maids 461; he leaves the city with his father Od. 23.367, his father's address to him and the fight with the Ithacans Od. 24.506; etc.

data.ref: Il. 4.354: in his absent father's house in

definition: Τήλεμος Patronymic Εὐρυμίδης. A seer among the Cyclopes Od. 9.509.
Τηλέπυλος (αἰπὺ πτολίεθρον). The city of the Laestrygonians Od. 10.82, Od. 23.318.
Τηλεφίδης Patronymic from Τήλεφος, king of the Mysians-1. Of Eurypylus-3 Od. 11.519.
Τηρείη The 'steep hill' of Tereia may possibly have been not far from Lampsacus, the modern Lampsaki Il. 2.829 .
Τηΰγετον (περιμήκετος). A mountain range west of Sparta Od. 6.103. [Cunliffe prints -ος]
Τιθωνός (ἀγαυός). Son of Laomedon. Husband of Eos and father of Memnon Il. 11.1, Od. 3.237: Od. 5.1.
Τίρυνς (τειχιόεσσα). A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.559.
Τίτανος (Τιτάνοιο λευκὰ κάρηνα). A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.735.

Τιταρησσός (in the MSS. Τιταρήσιος( ἱμερτός, καλλίρροον ὕδωῤ. Now the Europus, flowing into the Peneius (in Il. 2.755 called a tributary of the Styx). The waters of the two rivers do not mingle Il. 2.751.

data.ref: Il. 2.755 called a tributary of the

definition: Τιτῆνες (ὑποταρτάριοι). The sons of Uranus and Ge, confined by Zeus in Tartarus . Hera's oath by them Il. 14.279. Called Οὐρανίωνες 898; also ἔνερθε θεοί 274, ἐνέρτεροι θεοί 225.

Τιτυός (Γαιήϊος υἱός, ἐρικυδής ). Son of Ge. Rhadamanthys conveyed by the Phaeacians to visit him, apparently in Euboea Od. 7.324; laid violent hands on Leto and was tormented by vultures in the Shades Od. 11.576.

Τληπόλεμος-1 (δουρικλυτός, ἠΰς τε μέγας τε). Patronymic Ἡρακλεΐδης. Son of Heracles and Astyocheia. Leader of the Rhodians Il. 2.653, 657, 661; fights with Sarpedon Il. 5.628, 632, 648, killed by Sarpedon Hom. Il. 5.656, Hom. Il. 5.660, Hom. Il. 5.668.
Τληπόλεμος-2 Trojan. Patronymic Δαμαστορίδης-1. Killed by Patroclus Il. 16.416.
Τμῶλος (νιφόεις). A mountain range of Lydia south of Sardis Il. 2.866, Od. 3.385.
Τρηχίς A town of Argus-2 in Hellas, near the mouth of the Spercheius Il. 2.682 .
Τρῆχος Greek. (αἰχμητής). An Aetolian. Killed by Hector Il. 5.706.
Τρίκκη Τρίκη (ἱππόβοτος). A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Podaleirius and Machaon Il. 2.729, Il. 4.202.
Τριτογένεια See Lexicon.
Τροιζήν A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.561.
Τροίζηνος (διοτρεφής). Patronymic Κεάδης. Father of Euphemus Il. 2.847.

Τρῶες (ἀγαυοί, ἀγέρωχοι , ἀγήνορες, αἰχμηταί , ἀσπισταί, ἱππόδαμοι , μεγάθυμοι, μεγαλήτορες , πύκα θωρηκαί, ὑπερηνορέοντες, ὑπέρθυμοι, ὑπερφίαλοι, φιλοπτόλεμοι, χαλκοχίτωνες). The people of the city or land of Troy, the Trojans Il. 2.13, 123, 816, Il. 3.209, Il. 4.4, Il. 5.9, Il. 6.95, Il. 7.80, Il. 10.418, Il. 16.708, Il. 17.404, Il. 22.155, etc.: Od. 1.237 , Od. 3.85, 100, 220, Od. 4.243, 249, 330, Od. 8.220, 503, Od. 11.513, Od. 13.266, Od. 22.36, Od. 24.27, 31. Apparently a separate clan of Trojans (the men of Zeleia) Il. 2.826 . The general body fighting on the Trojan side Il. 1.152, Il. 2.15, Il. 3.2, Il. 4.21, Il. 5.27, Il. 6.1, Il. 7.7, Il. 8.11, Il. 9.1, Il. 10.38, Il. 11.56, Il. 12.3, Il. 13.1, Il. 14.15, Il. 15.6, Il. 16.42, Il. 17.2, Il. 18.11, Il. 19.63, Od. 3.3, Il. 21.25, Il. 22.11, Il. 23.23, etc.: Od. 3.86, Od. 4.254, 257, 273, 275, Od. 5.310, Od. 8.82, 504, 513, Od. 11.169, 383, 532, 547, Od. 12.190, Od. 14.71, 367, Od. 17.119, Od. 18.261, Od. 22.228. So Τρώων υἷες 38. The Trojans proper distinguished From the allies Il. 2.815, Il. 3.451, Il. 6.111, 227 , Il. 9.233, Il. 11.220 , 564, Il. 12.108, Il. 13.755, Il. 17.14, 362, Il. 18.229. From the Dardanians Il. 8.154. From the Dardanians and allies Il. 3.456, Il. 7.348, 368, Il. 8.497. From the Lycians Il. 4.197, 207, Il. 6.78 , Il. 11.285, Il. 15.424 , 485, Il. 16.564, 585, 685. From the Lycians and Dardanians Il. 8.173 , Il. 11.286, Il. 13.150 , Il. 15.425, 486, Il. 17.184. From the Leleges Od. 3.96.

Τρωϊάς Τρῳάς. Fem. adj. Trojan, like next (2) Il. 9.139, 281, Il. 16.831 : Od. 13.263. Absol. in pl., (the) Trojan women (βαθύκολποι, ἑλκεσίπεπλοι ) Il. 6.442, Il. 7.297, Il. 18.122, Il. 22.105, 514, Il. 24.215, 704.
Τρωϊκός Trojan Il. 10.11, Il. 23.464. In a sense corresponding to Τρῶες 2 Il. 16.369, Il. 17.724, Il. 21.296.
Τρωΐλος (ἱππιοχάρμης). A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.257.

Τρώϊος-1 Τρῳός-1. Trojan Il. 17.127 , 255, 273, Il. 18.179. Trojan, like Τρωϊκός 2 Il. 5.461, Il. 13.262 , Il. 16.393. Absol. in fem. pl., (the) Trojan women (ἐϋπλόκαμοι) Il. 3.384 , 411, 420, Il. 6.380, 385, Il. 18.339, Il. 22.57, 430, 434, 476: Od. 4.259.
Τρώϊος-2 Τρῳός-2. Of Trus-1 Il. 5.222 , Il. 8.106, Il. 23.291, 378.
Τρώς-1. Son of Erichthonius and father of Ilus-1, Assaracus and Ganymedes. His horses Il. 5.265; Od. 3.230 , 231.
Τρώς-2 Trojan. Patronymic Ἀλαστορίδης . Killed by Achilles Od. 3.463.

Τυδεύς (ἀγαυός, Αἰτώλιος , δαΐφρων, δῖος, ἱππηλάτα, ἱππόδαμος, ἱππότα, μεγάθυμος, σακέσπαλος). Patronymic Οἰνεΐδης. Son of Oeneus and Althaea, married to a daughter (Deipyle) of Adrestus-1 and father of Diomedes. His mission to the Cadmeians Il. 4.384, Il. 10.285; described Il. 5.800; perished at Thebes-1 Il. 6.222, buried there Il. 14.114; etc.: Od. 3.167.
Τυνδάρεος Husband of Leda and by her father of Castor-1 and Polydeuces Od. 11.298 , 299. And of Clytaemnestra Od. 24.199. Also nominal father of Helen Il. 3.236 (daughter of Zeus ).

Τυρώ (βασίλεια γυναικῶν, εὐπατέρεια). Daughter of Salmoneus and wife of Cretheus. Brought into comparison with Penelope Od. 2.120; by Poseidon mother of Pelies and Neleus Od. 11.235, 254; by Cretheus mother of Aeson, Pheres and Amythaon Od. 11.235, 258.
Τυφωεύς A monster put in bonds by Zeus in the country of the Arimoi Il. 2.782 , 783.
Τυχίος Made a shield for Aias-1 Il. 7.220.
Ὑάδες The Hyades, a group of stars near the Pleiades Il. 18.486 .
Ὑάμπολις A town of Phocis Il. 2.521.
Ὕδη (πίων). Apparently a district of Maeonia (Μῃονίη) Od. 3.385.
Ὑλακίδης (υ). Patronymic of Castor-2 Od. 14.204.
Ὕλη (ῦ). A Boeotian town Il. 2.500, Il. 5.708, Il. 7.221.
Ὕλλος (ἰχθυόεις). A river of Maeonia (Μῃονίη) flowing into the Hermus Od. 3.392.
Ὑπειροχίδης Patronymic of Itymoneus Il. 11.673.
Ὑπείροχος Trojan. killed by Odysseus Il. 11.335.
Ὑπείρων Trojan. (ποιμὴν λαῶν). Killed by Diomedes Il. 5.144.
Ὑπέρεια-1. A fountain believed to have been in the town of Pherae . The people living about it led by Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.734; Il. 6.457.
Ὑπέρεια-2 (εὐρύχορος). The old home of the Phaeacians, near the Cyclopes Od. 6.4.
Ὑπερήνωρ (ἱππόδαμος, ποιμὴν λαῶν ). Son of Panthous. Killed by Menelaus Il. 14.516, Il. 17.24.
Ὑπερησίη A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.573. Ὑπερησίηνδε [-δε], to Hyperesia In reference to the flight of Polypheides hither Od. 15.254.
Ὑπεριονίδης Ὑπερίων. See Lexicon.
Ὑποθῆβαι (ἐϋκτίμενον πτολίεθρον). A Boeotian town Il. 2.505.
Ὑπονήϊος Lying under Mount Neium (Neritum). Of Ithaca Od. 3.81 .
Ὑποπλάκιος Lying under Mount Placus. Of Thebe-2 Il. 6.397 .
Ὑρίη A Boeotian town on the Euripus Il. 2.496.
Ὑρμίνη A town of Elis Il. 2.616 .
Ὑρτακίδης Patronymic from next. Of Asius-2 Il. 2.837 , 838, Il. 12.96, 110, 163.
Ὕρτακος Father of Asius-2 Il. 13.759, 771.
Ὕρτιος Patronymic Γυρτιάδης. A leader of the Mysians-1. Killed by Aias-1 Il. 14.511.
Ὑψήνωρ-1 Trojan. (δῖος). Son of Dolopion. Killed by Eurypylus-2 Il. 5.76.
Ὑψήνωρ-2 Greek. (ποιμὴν λαῶν). Patronymic Ἱππασίδης-2. Mortally wounded by Deiphobus Il. 13.411.
Ὑψιπύλη Daughter of Thoas-2. By Ieson mother of Euneus Il. 7.469.
Φαέθουσα (νύμφη ἐϋπλόκαμος). Daughter of Eelius and Neaera. With Lampetie in charge of the oxen of the Sun Od. 12.132.
Φαέθων One of the horses of the Dawn Od. 23.246.
Φαίδιμος King of the Sidonians. The mixing-bowl given by him to Menelaus Od. 4.617, Od. 15.117.
Φαίδρη Daughter of Minos and wife of Theseus. Having calumniated her innocent stepson Hippolytus and being detected made away with herself. Named Od. 11.321.

Φαίηκες (ἀγαυοί, ἀγχίθεοι , ἀντίθεοι, δολιχήρετμοι , μεγάθυμοι, ναυσικλυτοί , φιλήρετμοι). A people, their home called Scheria, represented (Od. 6.204) as being the outermost of civilized communities. Their transference from Hypereia-2 to Scheria Od. 6.3; their city described Od. 6.262; their ships and seamanship Od. 6.270, Od. 7.34, 108, Od. 8.557, Od. 13.76; their intolerance of strangers Od. 7.32; the skill of their women Od. 7.109; their skill in dancing and ball-play Od. 8.260, 370; conductors home of strangers and Poseidon's threat thereanent Od. 8.564, Od. 13.125, he turns to stone the ship that had borne Odysseus 159; etc.

data.ref: Od. 6.204) as being the outermost of civilized communities.

definition: Φαῖνοψ-1. Father of Xanthus-3 and Thoon-1 Il. 5.152.
Φαῖνοψ-2. Father of Phorcys-1 Il. 17.312.
Φαῖνοψ-3. Patronymic Ἀσιάδης. Son of Asius-2. Favourite guest-frend (ξεῖνος) of Hector Il. 17.583.
Φαιστός-1 (εὖ ναιετόωσα). A city of Crete Il. 2.648: part of the fleet of Menelaus wrecked near it Od. 3.296.

data.ref: Il. 2.648: part of the fleet of

definition: Φαῖστος-2 Trojan. Son of Borus-1. Killed by Idomeneus Il. 5.43.
Φάλκης Trojan. Il. 13.791. Killed by Antilochus Il. 14.513.
Φᾶρις A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.582.
Φάρος An island off Egypt Od. 4.355.
Φαυσιάδης Patronymic of Apisaon-1 Il. 11.578.
Φεαί No doubt the mod. Katakolo Od. 15.297.
Φειά An unknown town, apparently of Pylus or Arcadia Il. 7.135.
Φείδας Greek. Il. 13.691.
Φείδιππος Son of Thessalus and with his brother Antiphus-1 a leader of the men of Nisyrus, Cos, etc. Il. 2.678.
Φείδων King of the Thesprotians Od. 14.316, Od. 19.287.
Φενεός A town of Arcadia Il. 2.605.
Φεραί A town of the realm of Eumelus lying west of the Boebean Lake Il. 2.711: Od. 4.798.
Φέρεκλος Son of Tecton. A skilled craftsman; built ships for Paris. Killed by Meriones Il. 5.59.
Φέρης.-1 Son of Cretheus and Tyro Od. 11.259. He was father of Admetus.
Φέρουσα A Nereid Il. 18.43 .
Φηγεύς (μάχης εὖ εἰδὼς πάσης). Son of Dares. With his brother Idaeus-2 attacks Diomedes Il. 5.11, killed by Diomedes 15 .
Φήμιος (θεῖος ἀοιδός). Patronymic Τερπιάδης. A bard who sang among the suitors under compulsion Od. 1.154 , 337, Od. 16.252, Od. 17.263; spared by Odysseus Od. 22.331; Od. 24.439.
Φηραί-1 (ζάθεαι) A town of Pylus Il. 9.151 , 293.
Φηραί-2 Φηρή (ἐϋκτιμένη). The home of Diocles Il. 5.543: represented as a half-way stage between Pylus and Sparta Od. 3.488, Od. 15.186.

data.ref: Il. 5.543: represented as a half-way stage between

definition: Φῆρες.-2 See Κένταυροι.
Φηρή See Φηραί-2.
Φηρητιάδης Patronymic from Φέρης. Of Eumelus (grandson) Il. 2.763, Il. 23.376.

Φθίη Locative Φθίηφι 323 (βωτιάνειρα, ὲριβῶλαξ , ἐρίβωλος, μήτηρ υήλων ). The chief part of the realm of Peleus, of undefined position and extent, lying north of Mt. Othrys and west of the Pagasaean Gulf Il. 1.155, Il. 2.683, Il. 9.253, 363, 395, 439, 479, 484, Il. 11.766, Il. 16.13, Il. 19.299, 323: Od. 11.496. Φθίηνδε [-δε], to Phthia Il. 1.169, Il. 19.330.
Φθῖοι Greek. (μεγάθυμοι). Adj. from prec. Applied absol. to the followers of Medon-1 and of Podarces Il. 13.686 , 693, 699.
Φθῖρες (ὄρος ἀκριτόφυλλον). A mountain of Caria not identified Il. 2.868.
Φιλητορίδης Patronymic of Demouchus Od. 3.457.

Φιλοίτιος (ὄρχαμος ἀνδρῶν, δῖος ). Odysseus's herdsman. Greets the disguised Odysseus Od. 20.185; Od. 20.254; ordered to close the gate of the courtyard Od. 21.240, closes it 388; slays Peisandrus-4 Od. 22.268, and Ctesippus 285 ; Od. 22.359.

Φιλοκτήτης (ἀγλαός, ἄναξ, τόξων ἐῢ εἰδώς). Son of Poeas (see Ποιάντιος). Leader of the men of Methone, etc., but left at Lemnos suffering from the bite of a water-snake and his place taken by Medon-1 Il. 2.718, the Greeks destined to bring him to Troy to their aid 725: his safe return from Troy Od. 3.190; his skill in archery Od. 8.219.
Φιλομηλεΐδης Apparently a patronymic Menelaus tells how on an unspecified occasion in Lesbos Odysseus overcame him in wrestling Od. 4.343, Od. 17.134.
Φλέγυες or Φλεγύαι (μεγαλήτορες). A people represented as warred on by Ares Il. 13.302.
Φοῖβος See Ἀπόλλων.

Φοίνικες (ἀγαυοί, ναυσίκλυτοι , πολυπαίπαλοι). The Phoenicians, a maritime and trading people, the inhabitants of Φοινίκη, Phoenicia. Il. 23.744 : Od. 13.272; carried off Eumaeus Od. 15.415, 419, 473. See also Σιδονίη, Σιδόνιοι . In sing., Phoenician Od. 14.288. In fem., Φοίνισσα Od. 15.417.
Φοινίκη Phoenicia, a country on the coast of Syria between Mt. Lebanon and the sea Od. 4.83, Od. 14.291.

Φοῖνιξ-1 (ὰντίθεος, ἄττα γεραιέ , γέρων ίππηλάτα, Διῒ φίλος , διοτρεφής, παλαιγενής ) Son of Amyntor and an ancient retainer of Peleus. Chosen to lead the embassy to Achilles Il. 9.168, his speech to Α. 432, tells how he fled from his father to Phthia, how Peleus received him well and how he brought up Achilles 478, he remains with Achilles 658; a leader under Achilles Il. 16.196; in his form Athene exhorts Menelaus Il. 17.555 ; in the chariotrace set to note the running Il. 23.359, etc.
Φοῖνιξ-2 (τηλεκλειτός). Father of Europa, the mother by Zeus of Minos and Rhadamanthys Il. 14.321.
Φοίνισσα See under Φοίνικες.
Φόρβας-1. Apparently, King of Lesbos. Father of Diomede Il. 9.665.
Φόρβας-2 (πολύμηλος). Father of Ilioneus. His riches Il. 14.490.
Φόρκυς-1 (δαΐφρων). Son of Phaenops-2. A leader of the Phrygians Il. 2.862, Il. 17.218. Killed by Aias-1 Il. 17.312, 318.
Φόρκυς-2 (ἅλιος γέρων, ἁλὸς ἀτρυγέτοιο μέδων). Father of Thoosa Od. 1.72 ; his haven in Ithaca Od. 13.96, 345.
Φραδμονίδης Patronymic of Agelaus-1 Il. 21.257.
Φρόνιος Father of Noemon-3 Od. 2.386, Od. 4.630, 648 .
Φρόντις-1 (δῖα) Wife of Panthous Il. 17.40.
Φρόντις-2 Patronymic Ὀνητορίδης. Menelaus's pilot Od. 3.282.
Φρύγες Trojan. (αἰολόπωλοι, ἱππόμαχοι ). The Phrygians, a people on the Sangarius and about Lake Ascania Il. 2.862, Il. 3.185, Il. 10.431.
Φρυγίη (ἀμπελόεσσα). The land of the Phrygians Il. 3.184, 401, Il. 16.719, Il. 18.291, Il. 24.545.

Φυλάκη A town in the realm of Protesilaus lying about ten miles west of the Pagasacan Gulf Il. 2.695, 700; the home of Medon-1 Il. 13.696, Il. 15.335: the home of Phylacus-2 and Iphiclus-1 Od. 11.290 , Od. 15.236.
Φυλακίδης Patronymic from Φύλακος-2. Of Iphiclus-1 Il. 2.705, Il. 13.698.
Φύλακος-1 Trojan. killed by Leitus Il. 6.35.
Φύλακος-2. Husband of Clymene-3 and father of Iphiclus-1 Od. 15.231 .
Φύλας Father of Polymele; brought up Eudorus Il. 16.181, 191.
Φυλεΐδης Patronymic from next. Of Meges Il. 2.628 , Il. 5.72, Il. 13.692, Il. 15.519, 528, Il. 16.313, Il. 19.239.
Φυλεύς (Διῒ φίλος, ἱππότα ). Father of Meges Il. 2.628 , Il. 10.110, 175, Il. 15.530, Il. 23.637.
Φυλομέδουσα (βοῶπις). Mother of Menesthius-1 by Areithous-1 Il. 7.10 .
Φυλώ A handmaid of Helen at Sparta Od. 4.125, 133.
Φωκῆες Greek. The men of Phocis, in which Delphi (Πυθώ) was situated Il. 2.517, 525, Il. 14.516, Il. 17.307.
Χαλκίς-1 A town of Euboea Il. 2.537.
Χαλκίς-2 (ἀγχίαλος). A town of Aetolia Il. 2.648.
Χαλκίς-3 (καλλιρέεθρος). See Κρουνοί.
Χαλκωδοντιάδης Patronymic of Elephenor Il. 2.541, Il. 4.464.
Χάλκων Father of Bathyclees Il. 16.595.
Χάρις (δῖα θεάων, λιπαροκρήδεμνος ). In Il. the wife of Hephaestus Il. 18.382.
Χάριτες See χάρις 5 in Lexicon.
Χάροπος (ἄναξ). Father of Nireus by Aglaia Il. 2.672.
Χάροψ Trojan. Patronymic Ἱππασίδης-1. Son of Hippasus. With his brother Socus killed by Odysseus Il. 11.426 .

Χάρυβδις (δεινή, δῖα, ὀλοή) A destructive female being inhabiting a whirlpool under a rock opposite to the rock of Scylla. The rock and whirlpool described Od. 12.101; Od. 12.113; Odysseus passes between Scylla and Ch. Od. 12.235 , 260, Od. 23.327; Od. comes again to Ch. and again escapes Od. 12.428, 430, 436, 441.
Χείρων (δικαιότατος Κενταύρων). A Centaur. Gave medicaments to Asclepius Il. 4.219; taught Achilles their use Il. 11.832; furnished Peleus with a spear from Pelion Il. 16.143, Il. 19.390.
Χερσιδάμας Trojan. killed by Odysseus Il. 11.423.
Χίμαιρα (ἀμαιμακέτη). A monster of divine origin described Il. 6.180. Reared by Amisodarus Il. 16.328; killed by Bellerophon Il. 6.179
Χίος (παιπαλόεσσα). The Aegean island Od. 3.170, 172 .
Χλῶρις (περικαλλής). Daughter of Amphion-3 and wife of Neleus Od. 11.281.
Χρομίος-1. Son of Neleus Il. 4.295 : Od. 11.286.
Χρομίος-2. Son of Priam (his mother not named). With his brother Echemmon killed by Diomedes Il. 5.160.
Χρομίος-3 Trojan. killed by Odysseus Il. 5.677.
Χρομίος-4 Trojan. killed by Teucrus Od. 8.275.
Χρομίος-5 Trojan. (θεοειδής). Il. 17.218, 494, 534.
Χρόμις A leader of the Mysians-1 Il. 2.858.
Χρύση A town of the southern Troad, probably near the mouth of the Satnioeis Il. 1.37, 100, 390, 431, 451.
Χρυσηΐς (καλλιπάρῃος). Fem. patronymic from Chryses. Captured by Achilles at Thebe-2 and given to Agamemnon Il. 1.369 ; Il. 1.111, 143, 182; sent back to her father Il. 1.310, 439.

Χρύσης The priest of Apollo at Chryse, father of prec. Comes in vain to the ships to ransom his daughter Il. 1.11 , 370; prays to Apollo Il. 1.37 ; Calchas declares that to stay the plague his daughter must be restored Il. 1.93; she is restored Il. 1.442, 450 .
Χρυσόθεμις Daughter of Agamemnon Il. 9.145, 287.
Ψυρίη An island northwest of Chios Od. 3.171.
Ὠγυγίη An epithet or the name of Calypso's island of unknown meaning Od. 1.85, Od. 6.172, Od. 7.244, 254 , Od. 12.448, Od. 23.333 .
Ὠκαλέη A Boeotian town Il. 2.501.

Ὠκεανός (ἀκαλαρρείτης, ἀψόρροος , βαθυδίνης, βαθυρρείτης , βαθύρροος, Ὠ. ποταμός ). The river Oceanus, encircling the earth and flowing back upon itself Il. 1.423, Il. 3.5, Il. 5.6, Il. 7.422, Il. 21.485, Il. 16.151, Il. 18.240, 402, 489, 607, Il. 19.1, Il. 23.205: Od. 4.568, Od. 5.275, Od. 10.508, 511, Od. 11.13, 21, 158, 639, Od. 12.1, Od. 19.434, Od. 20.65, Od. 22.197, Od. 23.244, 347, Od. 24.11. Personified. A god Od. 3.7. Associated with Tethys in the rearing of Hera Il. 14.201, 302 Father (Il. 18.399) of Eurynome-1 and (Od. 10.139) of Perse. θεῶν γένεσις Od. 14.201 , 302. γ. πάντεσσιν Il. 14.246. Parent of all waters Il. 21.195 (but see Ξάνθος-1). δῶμʼ Ὠκεανοῖο Il. 14.311 .
Ὠκύαλος A Phaeacian Od. 8.111 .
Ὠλενίη A rock on the confines of Bouprasion Il. 2.617, Il. 11.757.
Ὤλενος A town of Aetolia Il. 2.639.
Ὧραι See ὥρη 1 in Lexicon.
Ὠρείθυια A Nereid Il. 18.48 .

Ὠρίων (Ὠαρίων) (κλυτός, πελώριος ). Carried off by Eos Od. 5.121, slain by Artemis 123 ; his beauty Od. 11.310; carries on his hunting in the Shades Od. 11.572. The constellation Il. 14.486, 488: Od. 5.274. κύων Ὠρίωνος, Sirius 22.29 .
Ὦρος Greek. Killed by Hector Il. 11.303.

Ὦτος-1 (ἀντίθεος). Son of Poseidon (nominally of Aloeus) and Iphimedeia. With his brother Ephialtes imprisoned Ares in a jar Il. 5.385: the size and beauty of the brothers Od. 11.308, they threaten to pile Ossa on Olympus and Pelion on Ossa 315.

data.ref: Il. 5.385: the size and beauty of the brothers

definition: Ὦτος-2 Greek. Killed by Poulydamas Il. 15.518.
Ὦψ Patronymic Πεισηνορίδης. Father of Eurycleia Od. 1.429, Od. 2.347, Od. 20.148.
